finding: SNP rs606714 was reported to affect the binding of transcription factors from the Forkhead box family, which are involved in microglial activation in neuronal cells. Although linked to microglial functions, no eQTL signals were found for SNPs associated with sTREM2.
title: A multi-omics approach identifies a blood-based miRNA signature of cognitive decline in two large observational trials

finding: This SNP was associated with both physical activity and heart failure, emphasizing the interplay between lifestyle choices and genetic predisposition.
title: Common- and rare-variant genetic architecture of heart failure across the allele frequency spectrum

finding: The variant rs2776741 was significantly associated with time to irreversible EDSS milestones in females as well, with aHR of 0.77 (p=0.010) for irEDSS3 and 0.74 (p=0.005) for irEDSS6.
title: Not all roads lead to the immune system: The Genetic Basis of Multiple Sclerosis Severity Implicates Central Nervous System and Mitochondrial Involvement

finding: This variant acted as a splice donor variant in high LD with the lead variant rs1472662 (r² = 0.71) within the gene RP11-420K8. Its predicted high impact on protein processing might be relevant for migraine.
title: Genome-wide analysis of 102,084 migraine cases identifies 123 risk loci and subtype-specific risk alleles

finding: The lead variant rs1472662 was associated with migraine and had a splice donor variant rs66880209 in high LD (r² = 0.71), indicating its potential impact on splicing and function in migraine-related biology.
title: Genome-wide analysis of 102,084 migraine cases identifies 123 risk loci and subtype-specific risk alleles

finding: This SNP was associated with early ischemic stroke and was linked to the gene CDK18 with a p-value of 2.38 x 10^-9. It demonstrated cis-eQTL activity within skeletal muscle tissue, indicating its role in upregulating CDK18.
title: Genome-wide association study of ischemic stroke risk in Sickle Cell confirms ADAMTS2, CDK18, uncovers 12 novel loci

finding: The sleep index variant rs975025 had strong evidence of shared causal genetic variants with DTI parameters such as mean axial diffusivity in the splenium of corpus callosum, with a posterior probability of colocalization analysis (PPH4) greater than 0.976.
title: Mapping sleep’s phenotypic and genetic links to the brain and heart: a systematic analysis of multimodal brain and cardiac images in the UK Biobank

finding: The variant rs10782582 showed strong evidence of being associated with cerebellar traits tied to sleep.
title: Mapping sleep’s phenotypic and genetic links to the brain and heart: a systematic analysis of multimodal brain and cardiac images in the UK Biobank

finding: Identified as a missense variant with suggestive deleterious effects, linked to a gene implicated in neurodevelopmental disorders.
title: Discovery of 42 Genome-Wide Significant Loci Associated with Dyslexia

finding: The study highlighted the Q367H variant in the MFN2 gene, represented by rs373211062, as a potentially pathogenic variant linked to late-onset distal myopathy, despite not being associated with peripheral neuropathy. This variant replaced glutamine with histidine at codon 367, a change believed to be hypermorphic due to the high conservation of the glutamine residue across vertebrate sequences. The study noted its very low allele frequency in population databases, alongside conflicting interpretations of its pathogenicity in Clinvar. It emphasized the increased inflammation in patient fibroblasts and myoblasts, underscoring the deleterious nature of the Q367H variant and suggesting a novel mechanism connecting MFN2 dysfunction with mtDNA-mediated inflammation.
title: The MFN2 Q367H variant from a patient with late-onset distal myopathy reveals a novel pathomechanism connected to mtDNA-mediated inflammation

finding: The SNP rs4245739 was located in the 3'UTR of the MDM4 gene, which encodes a regulator of p53. This SNP was associated with prostate cancer, indicating its potential role in cancer susceptibility through modulation of MDM4 expression.
title: A distinct class of pan-cancer susceptibility genes revealed by alternative polyadenylation transcriptome-wide association study

finding: The heterozygous variant rs55886062 (c.1679 T>G) was identified in one patient and was known to impact drug metabolism, leading to a severe toxic response to the chemotherapeutic agent utilized. This patient experienced an incomplete response to therapy with residual cancer, prompting a change in treatment strategy to a different chemotherapeutic in order to mitigate potential toxicity.
title: The Q-IMPROvE (Queensland-IMplementation of PRecision Oncology in brEast cancer) pilot study

finding: The variant rs7549256 at 1p36.22 was linked to Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second (FEV1)/FVC ratio and was in strong linkage disequilibrium with previously reported variants related to lung function, though specific effects were not available.
title: Leveraging global multi-ancestry meta-analysis in the study of Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis genetics

finding: The variant rs4130548 at 1p31.1 was implicated in Body Mass Index (BMI) and marked as the index variant for its association signal.
title: Leveraging global multi-ancestry meta-analysis in the study of Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis genetics

finding: This SNP near SRGAP2C was shown to have eQTL associations in blood and was nominally associated with increased breast cancer risk, highlighting its potential involvement in sex-specific mutation pathways.
title: The Genetic Determinants and Genomic Consequences of Non-Leukemogenic Somatic Point Mutations

finding: The variant rs12048727 was nominally significant for AUD in the Latin American population, demonstrating its potential relevance in diverse ancestries.
title: Multi-ancestry study of the genetics of problematic alcohol use in >1 million individuals

finding: This SNP (rs7519259) was associated with OUD at a GWS level (p=2.68×10⁻¹⁰), indicating contributions potentially linked to PDE4B, which may have implications for OUD and related phenotypes.
title: Genome-wide association study and multi-trait analysis of opioid use disorder identifies novel associations in 639,709 individuals of European and African ancestry

finding: The SNP was associated with the combined nonchemotherapy drug response (p=2.51 x 10^-8), participating notably in response to BI.2536, gefitinib, and belinostat. It lies in the NIBAN1 gene, which has implications in cancer cell survival and stress response.
title: Exome-wide association study reveals 7 functional variants associated with ex-vivo drug response in acute myeloid leukemia patients

finding: This SNP served as a cis-eQTL for CD247, significant for T-cell signaling, with links to multiple autoimmune conditions.
title: Leveraging pleiotropy identifies common-variant associations with selective IgA deficiency

finding: The downstream variant rs198379 at the NPPB locus was identified as associated with increased NT-proBNP and BNP circulating levels in GWAS. This variant was notably linked to risks of heart failure and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), suggesting its role in cardiac disease.
title: Circulating cardiovascular proteomic associations with genetics and disease

finding: The SNP rs11591147, specifically the PCSK9 R46L variant, was found to be associated with a significant lipid-lowering effect. Heterozygous carriers exhibited a reduction of 15.5 mg/dl (11.8%) in LDL-C levels, while homozygous carriers showed a 25.2 mg/dl (19.2%) decrease, with both associations being statistically significant (P<0.001). This finding indicated the variant's role in reducing cholesterol levels among older individuals without coronary heart disease.
title: Protective lipid-lowering genetic variants in healthy older individuals without coronary heart disease

finding: This SNP was situated within an intron of FNBP1L and was associated with AD with a meta-analysis P-value of 0.017, showing at least nominal replication across datasets.
title: Whole-genome sequencing reveals new Alzheimer’s disease-associated rare variants in loci related to synaptic function and neuronal development

finding: The SNP rs1410996, associated with AMD under the label FGAMD1, was one of the two very strong independent variants at the <italic>CFH</italic> locus identified shortly after its discovery. It exhibited a nearly perfect correlation with AMD risk and contributed significantly (p=9.6x10<sup>-618</sup>) to the overall association strength with AMD in the study.
title: Loss of CFHR5 function reduces the risk for age-related macular degeneration

finding: The SNP rs10922109, reported as a key variant associated with AMD under the label FGAMD1, was found to be in complete linkage disequilibrium with variant rs1410996. This variant similarly exhibited strong association signals in the context of AMD risk.
title: Loss of CFHR5 function reduces the risk for age-related macular degeneration

finding: The SNP rs570618 was linked with AMD, identified in the same context as rs1410996. It also displayed linkage with the well-established risk alleles at the <italic>CFH</italic> locus, contributing substantially to the genetic association observed with AMD in the study population.
title: Loss of CFHR5 function reduces the risk for age-related macular degeneration

finding: The SNP rs537634973 represented a third independent signal associated with AMD, tagged as FGAMD3. This signal demonstrated a highly significant association (p_cond=6.2x10<sup>-25</sup>) and was enriched in Finns, indicating its potential role in modifying AMD risk.
title: Loss of CFHR5 function reduces the risk for age-related macular degeneration

finding: The variant represented by chr1:196994128:C:CAA corresponds to the previously mentioned rs565457964 variant in <italic>CFHR5</italic>, which was strongly correlated with protection against AMD, giving additional confirmation of the significance of this protective variant.
title: Loss of CFHR5 function reduces the risk for age-related macular degeneration

finding: This variant in DOCK7 showed robust evidence of colocalization with other FA traits, indicating that it shared genetic variants across those traits.
title: Genome-wide association studies and multi-omics integrative analysis reveal novel loci and their molecular mechanisms for circulating polyunsaturated, monounsaturated, and saturated fatty acids

finding: Associated across multiple ancestries, this SNP is near TNFRSF1B, a gene implicated in cytokine signaling and linked to atopic dermatitis.
title: European and multi-ancestry genome-wide association meta-analysis of atopic dermatitis highlights importance of systemic immune regulation

finding: This SNP was validated as part of the genome-wide significant findings associated with immune cell distributions, specifically linked to immune phenotypes in previous studies.
title: Genome-wide association study reveals different T cell distributions in peripheral blood of healthy individuals at high genetic risk of type 1 diabetes and long COVID

finding: This SNP was validated in the context of CD8+ T cell types and had been associated with immune cell distributions in previous GWAS.
title: Genome-wide association study reveals different T cell distributions in peripheral blood of healthy individuals at high genetic risk of type 1 diabetes and long COVID

finding: Found to be significantly associated with immune cell distributions, this SNP was also related to previous findings in other studies on immune responses.
title: Genome-wide association study reveals different T cell distributions in peripheral blood of healthy individuals at high genetic risk of type 1 diabetes and long COVID

finding: Associated with the expression levels of 14 genes, this SNP was part of the significant genome-wide findings related to immune cell types.
title: Genome-wide association study reveals different T cell distributions in peripheral blood of healthy individuals at high genetic risk of type 1 diabetes and long COVID

finding: The SNP rs12082097 was identified in connection with the effects of omeprazole, a proton pump inhibitor. The findings indicated that omeprazole inhibited glioblastoma cell invasion and tumor growth in a study, which linked the use of PPIs to adverse outcomes in glioblastoma patients. This suggests that the presence of this SNP may influence the efficacy of PPI treatment and could relate to survival outcomes in patients receiving treatment for glioblastoma.
title: Proton pump inhibitors are detrimental to overall survival of patients with glioblastoma multiforme: results from a nationwide real-world evidence database

finding: The study identified rs2625222 as a novel genome-wide significant SNP associated with Alzheimer Disease (AD), located within the NFASC gene on chromosome 1. This finding was significant in both models used in the analysis and was supported by functional studies that indicated rs2625222 resides in a regulatory region in neurons and oligodendrocytes, influencing the expression of NFASC. Furthermore, rs2625222 was shown to be an eQTL for CNTN2, suggesting its role in gene expression related to neuronal function.
title: A genome-wide association study in Peruvians suggests new risk loci for Alzheimer Disease

finding: The SNP rs77449572 was identified as the sentinel variant at the intergenic locus on chromosome 1p22.2, reaching genome-wide significance with a p-value of 1.72 x 10^-9. It overlapped an enhancer element in cortex-derived neurospheres, suggesting a potential role in gene expression regulation related to trigeminal neuralgia (TN).
title: Genome-wide association study reveals genetic risk factors for trigeminal neuralgia

finding: SNP rs543311093 was part of the intergenic locus on chromosome 1p22.2 that reached genome-wide significance (p < 5.0 x 10^-8) associated with TN. Its specific functional implications were not detailed in the study, but it was included in the significant SNPs at this locus.
title: Genome-wide association study reveals genetic risk factors for trigeminal neuralgia

finding: Similar to rs543311093, SNP rs35117749 was also located within the intergenic locus on chromosome 1p22.2 and reached genome-wide significance for TN. The precise biological role of this SNP was not discussed in detail within the findings.
title: Genome-wide association study reveals genetic risk factors for trigeminal neuralgia

finding: This SNP was identified at the intergenic locus on chromosome 1p22.2, reaching genome-wide significance. rs71666259 overlapped enhancer elements in embryonic stem cells, indicating potential functional consequences related to TN.
title: Genome-wide association study reveals genetic risk factors for trigeminal neuralgia

finding: SNP rs116010656 was part of the intergenic region on chromosome 1p22.2 that was significantly associated with TN. It also overlapped enhancer elements in embryonic stem cells, suggesting its involvement in gene regulatory mechanisms.
title: Genome-wide association study reveals genetic risk factors for trigeminal neuralgia

finding: The rs12075 SNP, associated with the DUFFY blood group system, exhibited a significant difference between the indigenous Orang Asli population and cosmopolitan Malaysians, with a P-value of 0.0270.
title: Genomic map of blood group alleles in Malaysian indigenous Orang Asli population from whole genome sequences

finding: The rs586178 SNP, linked to the RH blood group system, presented a noteworthy distinction between the Orang Asli and cosmopolitan Malaysians, indicated by a P-value of 0.0000.
title: Genomic map of blood group alleles in Malaysian indigenous Orang Asli population from whole genome sequences

finding: The SNP rs41272536 at locus 1q25.3 showed a significant association with SLE with a P-value of 3.5×10⁻⁵². It was among the top significant non-HLA loci identified in the study contributing to SLE susceptibility in both ethnic groups.
title: Genome-wide Association Clustering Meta-analysis in European and Chinese Datasets for Systemic Lupus Erythematosus identifies new genes

finding: The rs6025 SNP, associated with Factor V Leiden, was identified as a risk variant for inherited thrombophilia, which resulted in a risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE) that was 2.05 times higher in Covid-19 patients compared to those without the infection.
title: Venous Thromboembolism in Ambulatory Covid-19 patients: Clinical and Genetic Determinants

finding: The variant c.1905+1G>A (rs3918290) was identified as a splice-site variant causing exon 14 skipping, leading to the production of an inactive protein, and was associated with severe fluoropyrimidine-related toxicity in South Asian, East Asian, and Middle Eastern patients.
title: DPYD genetic polymorphisms in non-European patients with severe fluoropyrimidine-related toxicity: A systematic review

finding: The c.557A>G (p.Tyr186Cys, rs115232898) variant was positively identified in African American patients with severe fluoropyrimidine-related toxicity, including a fatal case, showing a marked reduction in DPD activity.
title: DPYD genetic polymorphisms in non-European patients with severe fluoropyrimidine-related toxicity: A systematic review

finding: The SNP rs2790053 was associated with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG), showing an odds ratio (OR) of 1.35, and was also linked to elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) through colocalization with eQTL and sQTL acting on the gene TMCO1, which suggested that increased POAG risk was related to decreased expression of TMCO1.
title: Integrating genetic regulation and single-cell expression with GWAS prioritizes causal genes and cell types for glaucoma

finding: For rs116089225, a leading variant associated with IOP, it demonstrated a beta of -0.744; this SNP colocalized with eQTLs impacting TMCO1, implying that increased POAG risk correlated with the regulation of TMCO1 expression.
title: Integrating genetic regulation and single-cell expression with GWAS prioritizes causal genes and cell types for glaucoma

finding: Variant rs74315329 was a nonsense mutation in MYOC with a high POAG OR of 5.47 and was linked to a significant eQTL with PIGC that suggested promoter alterations might influence POAG risk.
title: Integrating genetic regulation and single-cell expression with GWAS prioritizes causal genes and cell types for glaucoma

finding: This SNP, located within the CR1 gene, was significantly associated with alterations in expression in both blood and brain eQTLs and displayed contrasting expression patterns associated with AD pathology.
title: Cell-type Specific Expression Quantitative Trait Loci Associated with Alzheimer Disease in Blood and Brain Tissue

finding: The study established that the minor allele of SNP rs11203366, part of the PADI4 haplotype, was associated with higher rates of infections and delayed wound healing in patients with diabetes mellitus (DM). Neutrophils carrying the G allele showed increased PADI4 expression levels and NET formation, thereby influencing clinical outcomes.
title: PADI4 minor haplotype as risk factor for excessive NET formation and associated wound healing disorders in diabetes mellitus

finding: Similar to rs11203366, SNP rs11203367 contributed to the PADI4 haplotype's association with detrimental clinical outcomes in DM patients. The C to T transition correlated with heightened PADI4 expression and increased incidence of delayed wound healing and infections in those homozygous for the minor allele.
title: PADI4 minor haplotype as risk factor for excessive NET formation and associated wound healing disorders in diabetes mellitus

finding: SNP rs874881 was found to be critical since it demonstrated the strongest correlation with PADI4 expression levels. The C to G change in this SNP aligned with heightened NET formation and worsened healing outcomes in diabetic patients, reinforcing the connection between this haplotype and adverse clinical events.
title: PADI4 minor haplotype as risk factor for excessive NET formation and associated wound healing disorders in diabetes mellitus

finding: The rs72688573/FAF1 variant was associated with LV mass to end-diastolic volume ratio and two HF risk factors, providing additional insight into its potential impact on HF.
title: Genome-wide association analysis and Mendelian randomization proteomics identify novel protein biomarkers and drug targets for primary prevention of heart failure

finding: Belonging to the polygenic risk profile (PRP-5), this SNP was positively associated with increased odds of polyvascular disease, contributing to an overall OR of 5.2 (p = 0.007).
title: Complexity of Coronary Disease and a Genetic Risk Profile in Patients with Type 2 Diabetes in Colombia

finding: Though not initially mentioned in the findings, it was indicated as the lead variant similar to rs10220464 in associated analyses, reaffirming its role in FEV1 impairment, thus establishing an implied link as a variant of interest related to lower lung function.
title: Multi-omic association study identifies DNA methylation-mediated genotype and smoking exposure effects on lung function in children living in urban settings

finding: The SNP rs112437613, located in the DAB1 gene, was identified as a novel genome-wide significant locus associated with Alzheimer’s disease (AD). The study reported an odds ratio of 2.28 (95% CI: 1.73-3.01, p=5.4×10⁻⁹) for this SNP among APOE-ε4 homozygous individuals, indicating that the presence of the T allele was associated with a higher risk of AD. Furthermore, survival regression models supported this finding, yielding a hazard ratio of 2.27 (CI: 1.75-2.95, p=7.8×10⁻¹⁰). The analysis highlighted a significant epistatic interaction between this SNP and the APOE locus, which was crucial in understanding the genetic underpinning of AD risk in ε4 carriers.
title: Whole genome analysis in APOE4 homozygotes identifies the DAB1-RELN pathway in Alzheimer’s disease pathogenesis

finding: The study reported that the duffy null allele (rs2814778) in the ACKR1 gene accounted for a high degree of variability in white blood cell and neutrophil counts in African Americans and Hispanic Latinos. This allele was noted to have arisen to high frequency in malaria-endemic regions as it provides resistance to Plasmodium vivax malaria.
title: Systematic comparison of phenome-wide admixture mapping and genome-wide association in a diverse biobank

finding: This SNP had strong evidence for association with periodontal disease and was also highlighted as having potential associations in inflammatory pathways related to colorectal cancer risk.
title: Two-sample Mendelian randomization analysis of associations between periodontal disease and risk of colorectal, lung, and pancreatic cancers

finding: SNP rs1052067, located at 1q22, was identified as a novel shared locus with a p-value of 2.76×10^-08, linking it to both COVID-19 and female-specific cancers.
title: Are female-specific cancers long-term sequelae of COVID-19? Evidence from a large-scale genome-wide cross-trait analysis

finding: This SNP, located in the intronic region of the FMN2 gene, was reported in previous GWAS studies and was associated with total body and heel BMD.
title: SEAD: an augmented reference panel with 22,134 haplotypes boosts the rare variants imputation and GWAS analysis in Asian population

finding: In the ANGPTL3 locus, rs6657050 was significantly associated with phosphatidylcholines PC(38:7) and PI(36:2) in the PROMIS study, highlighting its role in lipid regulation and cardiovascular risk.
title: Genome-wide analysis of blood lipid metabolites in over 5,000 South Asians reveals biological insights at cardiometabolic disease loci

finding: The SNP rs12411216 was reported to strongly associate with anti-WUPyV IgG levels, showing a P-value of 2.70e-30, indicating a significant role of MUC1 genetic variation in the immune response to this polyomavirus.
title: Human genomics of the humoral immune response against polyomaviruses

finding: The rs4072037 SNP was linked to differential splicing of the MUC1 gene, affecting Mucin1 protein isoforms. It was associated with higher IgG levels against WUPyV, indicating a genetic influence on the immune response and underscoring its established connection with gastric cancer risk.
title: Human genomics of the humoral immune response against polyomaviruses

finding: A variant (rs932335) in the HSD11B1 gene was found to be associated with colorectal cancer in a Chinese population, providing insights into cancer susceptibility.
title: Identification of potential core genes in hepatoblastoma via bioinformatics analysis

finding: The SNP rs192146294 on chromosome 1 was found to be significantly associated with Staphylococcus infection (p = 1.23 × 10<sup>−9</sup>), marking it as a valuable genetic determinant linked to this infectious disease.
title: The genetic architecture of human infectious diseases and pathogen-induced cellular phenotypes

finding: The study found that the presence of the C allele of SNP rs479200 of the EGLN1 gene was associated with increased severity in COVID-19 patients. Specifically, the genotype CC was significantly overrepresented in severe cases, with an adjusted odds ratio of 11.414 (2.564-50.812) for severe compared to asymptomatic patients, indicating that the C allele may serve as a risk factor for severe COVID-19 outcomes.
title: C allele of rs479200 of the host EGLN1 gene - a risk factor for severe COVID-19 (pilot study)

finding: The rs10801555 colocalizing signal was associated with age-related macular degeneration through its connection to the CFHR3 gene, indicating potential novel therapeutic targets in this pathway.
title: Systematic disease-agnostic identification of therapeutically actionable targets using the genetics of human plasma proteins

finding: The rare coding variant rs5361 in SELE was identified as a significant contributor to NPC risk, exhibiting an odds ratio of approximately 2.20. The mutation resulted in a S149R amino acid substitution in E-selectin, which altered endothelial cell function, thereby promoting NPC progression through enhanced cell migration and interaction with cancer cells.
title: Whole-Exome Sequencing Association Study Implicates Genetic Effects on Viral Oncogenesis and Tumor Microenvironment in Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma

finding: The SNP rs12082166 was reported in relation to the lymphotropic viruses, particularly Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), and its potential impact on malignancies in Latin America. This was outlined in a literature-based study which indicated a link between EBV infection and the immune environment, potentially influencing antibody responses to concurrent malaria infections. Thus, this SNP was considered a positive and original finding in the context of its association with EBV and its consequential effects on malaria immunity.
title: Impact of Epstein-Barr virus co-infection on natural acquired Plasmodium vivax antibody response

finding: The SNP rs16837903 was identified at locus 1q21.2 with an odds ratio (OR[95% CI]=0.88[0.85, 0.92]) and a P-value of 9.54×10−9, indicating a significant association with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF). This variant was linked to the gene MCL1, which showed increased expression in IPF patients' alveolar epithelial type I cells.
title: Common and rare variant analyses reveal novel genetic factors underlying Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis and shared aetiology with COVID-19

finding: The SNP rs143435072, located in ANGPTL7, was determined to be a strong risk factor for IPF with a P-value of 6.73×10−8 and OR[95% CI]=28.79 [8.51-97.43]. This rare loss-of-function variant was noted for its association with lower intraocular pressure and potential relevance in the pathogenesis of IPF through its role in angiogenesis.
title: Common and rare variant analyses reveal novel genetic factors underlying Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis and shared aetiology with COVID-19

finding: The SNP rs28363218 in RAD54L was associated with later menopause (p = 7.1 x 10<sup>-5</sup>), indicating its role in the determination of age at natural menopause.
title: Rare coding variants in five DNA damage repair genes associate with timing of natural menopause

finding: The SNP rs4606 from the RGS2 gene was associated with a higher risk of later-life hypertension following a history of early-onset PE, specifically the CG or GG genotypes, which were found to correlate with the risk after adjusting for age and BMI.
title: Genomic variation associated with cardiovascular disease progression following preeclampsia: A systematic review

finding: The rs575265 SNP in the CHADL gene was positively associated with Gilles de la Tourette syndrome (GTS) and obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). This finding arose from a meta-analysis of GWAS results, highlighting the relevance of this SNP in the genetic risk of these psychiatric conditions.
title: An oligogenic risk-model for Gilles de la Tourette syndrome based on whole-genome sequencing data

finding: The SNP rs76472767 was significantly associated with subsequent arterial ischemic stroke (AIS) with an odds ratio (OR) of 0.75, indicating a reduced risk for this phenotype. This finding was determined in the African ancestry genome-wide association study (AFR GWAS) with a corrected p-value of 3.69x10^-08.
title: Protein identification for stroke progression via Mendelian Randomization in Million Veteran Program and UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs3747973 was reassigned from NUCKS1 and Metazoa_SRP to SLC45A3, indicating it played a significant role linking trait-associated variants to traits in association with HDL.
title: Multi-omics Integration Identifies Genes Influencing Traits Associated with Cardiovascular Risks: The Long Life Family Study

finding: The study revealed that the <italic>rs1137101</italic> polymorphism (<italic>LEPR</italic>) was significantly correlated with obesity measures. In patients with metabolic syndrome, the frequency of the G allele was reported as 87%, while it was 91% in those without the syndrome. These findings highlighted a potential connection between <italic>LEPR</italic> gene variants and metabolic conditions within the Yakut population.
title: Polymorphism Q223R of the leptin receptor (LEPR) - a possible relationship with adaptation to non-tropical climate in Yakuts

finding: Previous studies indicated that the <italic>rs1137100</italic> polymorphism of the <italic>LEPR</italic> gene, associated with the K109R amino acid substitution, displayed a G allele frequency of 66.6% in the Yakut population, but no significant association was found with metabolic syndrome. The significance of this polymorphism was emphasized due to its involvement in distinguishing East Asian populations.
title: Polymorphism Q223R of the leptin receptor (LEPR) - a possible relationship with adaptation to non-tropical climate in Yakuts

finding: The SNP rs12071965 was associated with early detection biomarkers for pancreatic cancer, as discussed in a study by Kato and Honda indicating its relevance in diagnosing pancreatic cancer effectively.
title: PanCanAID – Pancreas Cancer Artificial Intelligence Driven Diagnosis in CT Scan Imaging: A Protocol for a Multicentric Ambispective Diagnostic Study

finding: The rs1205 polymorphism was associated with variables impacting glucose metabolism and hence related to COVID-19 complications.
title: COVID-19 and Indian population: a comparative genetic analysis

finding: This intronic variant within the MDM4 gene at 1q21.3 served as an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) specifically in brain tissues indicating its potential role in lung cancer susceptibility.
title: Genetic analysis of lung cancer reveals novel susceptibility loci and germline impact on somatic mutation burden

finding: Located within the MDM4 gene at 1q32.1, this variant demonstrated significant associations with lung cancer, contributing to the understanding of p53 regulation in cancer pathology.
title: Genetic analysis of lung cancer reveals novel susceptibility loci and germline impact on somatic mutation burden

finding: The rs301806 SNP was identified as a differentially active SNP (daSNV) with the highest normalized BRAIN-MAGNET cb score among 4 candidate SNPs in LD at a major depression-associated locus, suggesting its significant effect on NCRE function.
title: A novel functional genomics atlas coupled with convolutional neural networks facilitates clinical interpretation of disease relevant variants in non-coding regulatory elements

finding: Homozygosity for the H allele of FCGR2A (rs1801274) correlated with decreased clinical response, as it was associated with decreased odds of achieving a BILAG MCR at 6 months (p=0.02) in both RA and SLE. In RA, weak evidence suggested a better outcome associated with the R allele (p=0.04).
title: Comprehensive genetic and functional analysis of FcγRs in rituximab therapy for autoimmunity reveals a key role for FcγRIIIa on NK cells

finding: Similar findings to rs3969910 were reported, emphasizing that the homozygous V allele in FCGR3A was associated with improved clinical outcomes, including a twofold increased likelihood of achieving a BILAG MCR (p=0.03) and significant odds improvements when possessing multiple V alleles.
title: Comprehensive genetic and functional analysis of FcγRs in rituximab therapy for autoimmunity reveals a key role for FcγRIIIa on NK cells

finding: The intronic variant rs2092504 in the TMEM51 gene was also significantly associated with Raynaud's syndrome. This suggests a possible role of transmembrane proteins in the pathophysiology of vascular dysfunction present in RS.
title: The α2A-adrenergic receptor (ADRA2A) modulates susceptibility to Raynaud’s syndrome

finding:
The rs2228145 SNP in the IL-6 receptor (
IL6R) was associated with decreased C-reactive protein (CRP) levels across all tested continental ancestries in the UK Biobank. The association was robust, showing a large overall effect with a beta of -0.11 per standard deviation of normalized CRP per C allele, an extremely significant p-value of 7.55 × 10−255. However, Mendelian randomisation analyses using this SNP did not show a causal effect on severe malaria case status or any severe malaria sub-phenotype. The odds ratio for the association with severe malaria was found to be 1.14 (95% CI 0.56 – 2.34, p = 0.713), indicating no positive association despite the SNP's strong association with CRP.
title: The effect of genetically proxied IL-6 signalling on severe malaria: A Mendelian randomisation analysis

finding: The rs142000963-T variant, corresponding to the lamin A R644C mutation, was found to positively associate with hepatic steatosis in a large cohort from the Michigan Genomics Initiative (MGI). The analysis indicated an odds ratio of 1.7 (P=0.02) for this association, suggesting that individuals with this variant had a higher likelihood of developing hepatic steatosis, which was also corroborated by functional studies showing increased lipid droplet accumulation in hepatoma cells expressing the R644C variant.
title: LMNA R644C associates with hepatic steatosis in a large cohort and increases cellular lipid droplet accumulation in vitro

finding: The non-coding variant rs1527365-T in the PARP1 locus was identified as protective for overall CHIP, with an odds ratio (OR) of 0.88 (95% CI: 0.85-0.91) and a significant p-value of 7.0 x 10^-13. This allele was associated with decreased expression of PARP1 in whole blood.
title: Germline genomic and phenomic landscape of clonal hematopoiesis in 323,112 individuals

finding: Similar to rs13107325, SNP rs76934732 displayed pronounced positive or negative mean Z-scores across cerebellar features. This SNP was implicated in GWAS analyses concerning total cerebellar volume.
title: The genetic architecture of human cerebellar morphology supports a key role for the cerebellum in recent human evolution and psychopathology

finding: The missense variant rs1061170, which substitutes histidine with tyrosine (H/Y) at position 402 of the Complement Factor H (CFH) protein, led to biased measurements of protein levels. This variant influenced the accuracy of effect size measurements but did not result in false identifications of pQTLs.
title: Plasma Proteome Variation and its Genetic Determinants in Children and Adolescents

finding: The SNP rs723177 was associated with increased placental weight and acted as an eQTL affecting FCGR2A and FCGR2B, implicating its role in maternal antibody transfer.
title: Genome-wide association study of placental weight in 179,025 children and parents reveals distinct and shared genetic influences between placental and fetal growth

finding: The SNP rs33931638 was identified as significant in the trans-ancestry GWAS of whole amygdala volume and showed a decrease in p-value in relation to the European mega-analysis, indicating its relevance in the genetic architecture of amygdala volume.
title: The Genetic Architecture of Amygdala Nuclei

finding: As a part of the overlapping SNPs associated with BMI, WC, and HC, this SNP substantiated the causal association with PCOS, highlighting its significance in the genetic architecture of obesity.
title: Both general- and central- obesity are causally associated with polycystic ovarian syndrome: Findings of a Mendelian randomization study

finding: In the NPR1 gene, nonsynonymous variant rs35479618 was associated with increased blood pressure, indicating that variants impairing the function of NPR1 generally increase hypertension risk.
title: Analysis of 200,000 exome-sequenced UK Biobank subjects implicates genes involved in increased and decreased risk of hypertension

finding: Similar to rs35479618, the nonsynonymous variant rs116245325 in NPR1 was found to be associated with increased blood pressure, further supporting NPR1's relationship with hypertension.
title: Analysis of 200,000 exome-sequenced UK Biobank subjects implicates genes involved in increased and decreased risk of hypertension

finding: Variant rs61757359 in the NPR1 gene was associated with decreased blood pressure, suggesting a nuanced role of specific variants in modulating hypertension risk, despite the propensity for NPR1 variants to generally increase risk.
title: Analysis of 200,000 exome-sequenced UK Biobank subjects implicates genes involved in increased and decreased risk of hypertension

finding: The intergenic lead variant rs12752585:G>A was reported to decrease the risk for SARS-CoV-2 infection with an odds ratio (OR) of 0.98 (95% CI = 0.97–0.98, P = 1.5 × 10^-11) and it increased MUC1 expression in esophagus mucosa.
title: A second update on mapping the human genetic architecture of COVID-19

finding: The missense variant rs35154152:T>C (p.Ser279Gly) at locus 1q22 was noted to decrease the risk for hospitalization (OR = 0.88, 95% CI = 0.86–0.90, P = 5.6 × 10^-22) but not for infection.
title: A second update on mapping the human genetic architecture of COVID-19

finding: The intronic variant rs11208552:G>T in JAK1 provided protective effects against critical illness and hospitalization with ORs of 0.92 and 0.95, respectively (P = 5.5 × 10^-10 and 2.2 × 10^-9).
title: A second update on mapping the human genetic architecture of COVID-19

finding: The variant rs2814778 was noted for its association with Benign Ethnic Neutropenia (BEN) predominantly in African Americans. This SNP was highlighted to suggest the benefits of genotype screening for interpreting neutropenia, thus underscoring its clinical relevance in improving patient care and avoiding unnecessary invasive procedures.
title: Leveraging genomic diversity for discovery in an EHR-linked biobank: the UCLA ATLAS Community Health Initiative

finding: The rs890293 SNP in the CYP2J2 gene was identified as being significantly associated with susceptibility to Alzheimer's disease specifically in the Chinese Han population. The study highlighted that this polymorphism could play a role in the pathophysiology of Alzheimer's disease, linking genetic factors to the metabolic pathways involved in inflammation and lipid metabolism.
title: Association of plasma and CSF cytochrome P450, soluble epoxide hydrolase and ethanolamides metabolism with Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The rs1541255 A>G polymorphism in ATP2B4 was associated with higher plasma PfHRP2 concentrations, lower parasite densities, and a significantly increased sequestration index, indicating a complex role in malaria protection.
title: The impact of malaria-protective red blood cell polymorphisms on parasite biomass in children with severe Plasmodium falciparum malaria

finding: The lead SNP rs1801274, identified only by ReAD, has confirmed associations with ulcerative colitis in several studies of European ancestry.
title: A powerful replicability analysis of genome-wide association studies

finding: The splice donor variant rs56043070 (c.89+1G>A) resulted in loss of function of GCSAML, which was associated with urticaria, showing an Odds Ratio (OR) of 1.24 and a p-value of 6.9×10−12.
title: A global atlas of genetic associations of 220 deep phenotypes

finding: The rare East Asian missense variant rs151193009 (p.Arg93Cys) in PCSK9 was significantly associated with the usage of salicylic acids and derivatives, with an Odds Ratio (OR=0.75) and a p-value of 7.1×10−11, indicating a potential protective effect against thromboembolic diseases.
title: A global atlas of genetic associations of 220 deep phenotypes

finding: The lead SNP, rs10737681, located between CFHR4 and CFHR1 in the CFHR gene cluster, was associated with a significant increase in CFHR5 plasma levels, with a beta of +81.33 ± 8.67 (p = 6.49E-21). This SNP demonstrated a genome-wide significant association with CFHR5 levels in a total sample of 2967 individuals.
title: Elevated plasma Complement Factor H Regulating Protein 5 is associated with venous thromboembolism and COVID-19 severity

finding: The SNP rs10494747 exhibited a borderline significant association with CFHR5 levels, where the A-allele was linked to an increase in CFHR5 levels (+47.60 ± 8.92, p = 9.83E-08). This SNP was located approximately 343 kb from rs10737681 and showed moderate linkage disequilibrium (r² ≈ 0.10) with the lead SNP.
title: Elevated plasma Complement Factor H Regulating Protein 5 is associated with venous thromboembolism and COVID-19 severity

finding: The variant rs148010464, found in the intergenic region of PLA2G4A/LINC01036 at locus 1q31.1, was also unique to South Asia and was associated with similar stroke types as rs528002287. The findings were significant, as PLA2G4A was implicated in various metabolic processes and was upregulated in response to improvements in sleep quality, highlighting the genetic influences on stroke risk and comorbid conditions in the South Asian population.
title: Ethnic and region-specific genetic risk variants of stroke and its comorbid conditions can define the variations in the burden of stroke and its phenotypic traits

finding: The SNP rs35288741 was identified as a repressive SNP-DRE located in the eSNP bin associated with transcriptional regulation of the gene NUAK2. Deletion of the rs35288741 region resulted in a significant reduction of repression of NUAK2, indicated by a p-value of 0.038 from a one-sided unpaired t-test. This SNP's impact on NUAK2 underscores its role in influencing gene expression in response to dexamethasone treatment.
title: Assessment of glucocorticoid-induced enhancer activity of eSNP regions using STARR-seq reveals novel molecular mechanisms in psychiatric disorders

finding: The rs72673189 SNP was associated with the development of levodopa-induced dyskinesia (LiD) in Parkinson's disease patients. It was located in the LRP8 locus and was reported to have a hazard ratio (HR) of 2.77, indicating a significantly higher probability of developing LiD (p = 1.53 × 10^-8).
title: Genetic meta-analysis of levodopa induced dyskinesia in Parkinson’s disease

finding: The rs278853 SNP was identified as a significant variant in the DNAJB4 locus and was nominally associated with LiD (p = 4.40 × 10^-6), suggesting an independent signal related to the risk of developing dyskinesia.
title: Genetic meta-analysis of levodopa induced dyskinesia in Parkinson’s disease

finding: pgBoost linked rs35249183, fine-mapped for eosinophil count (PIP 1.00), to TNFRSF8 at a distance of 24kb to the TSS. This SNP is within a cCRE exhibiting distal enhancer characteristics and is linked to a GWAS variant associated with eosinophil count, identifying TNFRSF8 as a biologically plausible target gene involving lymphocyte growth.
title: Linking regulatory variants to target genes by integrating single-cell multiome methods and genomic distance

finding: Variants within the RGS4 gene including rs2661319 predicted relative responsiveness to atypical antipsychotic treatment in individuals of African ancestry.
title: Pharmacogenomic diversity in psychiatry: Challenges and Opportunities in Africa

finding: The rs2842030 variant in the RGS4 gene also predicted treatment response, indicating a notable role of this gene in pharmacogenomic outcomes.
title: Pharmacogenomic diversity in psychiatry: Challenges and Opportunities in Africa

finding: Homozygous patients for the C allele of rs951439 in the RGS4 gene displayed a more favorable response to perphenazine treatment compared to quetiapine or ziprasidone.
title: Pharmacogenomic diversity in psychiatry: Challenges and Opportunities in Africa

finding: The rs1026417-C variant located within the FMN2 gene at 1q43 was associated with decreased blood NfL levels. This finding is significant because FMN2 is involved in cytoskeleton assembly and neuro-axonal integrity, linking it to neurodegeneration.
title: Genome-wide Association Study Meta-analysis of Neurofilament light (NfL) levels in blood reveals novel loci related to neurodegeneration

finding: The loss-of-function variant rs151193009 was significantly associated with lower LDL-C levels and explained part of the variance in LDL-C. It was also linked to a lower risk of cardiovascular disease outcomes including carotid plaque, major occlusive vascular events, and ischemic stroke.
title: PCSK9 genetic variants and risk of vascular and non-vascular diseases in Chinese and UK populations

finding: Associations of rs11591147 with higher risk of respiratory diseases were reported, including acute upper respiratory tract infections and asthma. These findings were observed in the context of previous studies, corroborating its associations with non-vascular disease outcomes despite being nominally significant.
title: PCSK9 genetic variants and risk of vascular and non-vascular diseases in Chinese and UK populations

finding: SNP rs2495477 was independently associated with LDL-C levels at genome-wide significance, contributing to the genetic score related to LDL-C, although further specific associations with health outcomes were not emphasized in the context provided.
title: PCSK9 genetic variants and risk of vascular and non-vascular diseases in Chinese and UK populations

finding: Similar to rs2495477, rs11206517 showed independent association with LDL-C levels. However, detailed associations with specific disease outcomes were not highlighted, indicating a focus on its contribution to the overall genetic score for LDL-C.
title: PCSK9 genetic variants and risk of vascular and non-vascular diseases in Chinese and UK populations

finding: This SNP was associated with plasma protein levels of IL6R in STEMI patients, showing significant effects at all timepoints assessed (genotype β=0.42, p=1.6×10^-5), indicating its relevance across different disease stages.
title: Single-cell dissection of the immune response after acute myocardial infarction

finding: This SNP was identified to regulate soluble IL6R levels in both STEMI patients and controls, influencing trans-signaling pathways related to IL-6, which were particularly active during the first 24 hours post-MI.
title: Single-cell dissection of the immune response after acute myocardial infarction

finding: The MUTYH rs36053993 variant showed a significant association with PrCa risk (p=0.031) in the North American dataset. This variant results in a p.G368D amino acid change and is linked to pathogenic associations with colorectal carcinomas.
title: Germline sequencing of DNA-damage-repair genes in two hereditary prostate cancer cohorts reveals new disease risk-associated gene variants

finding: This SNP was associated with rapid progression subtype (Subtype III) of Parkinson's disease, indicating it may contribute to faster disease progression.
title: Comprehensively modeling heterogeneous symptom progression for Parkinson’s disease subtyping

finding: Associated with rapid progression subtype (Subtype III), potentially influencing the rate of symptom worsening in patients.
title: Comprehensively modeling heterogeneous symptom progression for Parkinson’s disease subtyping

finding: Found to be associated with rapid progression subtype (Subtype III), suggesting a role in quickening symptom development in patients.
title: Comprehensively modeling heterogeneous symptom progression for Parkinson’s disease subtyping

finding: This SNP was linked to mild progression subtype (Subtype I), indicating a possible role in the slow development of Parkinson's disease.
title: Comprehensively modeling heterogeneous symptom progression for Parkinson’s disease subtyping

finding: The SNP rs2166172 was identified in the 1p22.2 locus and was significantly associated with hospitalized COVID-19 at a genome-wide significant level, contributing to understanding genetic factors influencing severe COVID-19.
title: Single cell sequencing analysis uncovers genetics-influenced CD16+monocytes and memory CD8+T cells involved in severe COVID-19

finding: The SNP rs6679677 mapped to the PTPN22 gene, which is known for its role in autoimmune disorders, further supporting its association with rheumatoid arthritis.
title: New Genetic Insights in Rheumatoid Arthritis using Taxonomy3®, a Novel method for Analysing Human Genetic Data

finding: The genetic variant rs7554873 was found to be close to the FCGR2B gene, which encodes for a receptor implicated in immune responses and neuroinflammation. The study suggested an association of this SNP with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) by relating it to chronic inflammation, although no direct causal association was identified.
title: Polygenic associations and causal inferences between serum immunoglobulins and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis

finding: The SNP rs1004819 was identified as the main disease-associated variant in the IL23R gene among German patients with Crohn's disease. This finding highlighted the association of this variant with the disease, establishing rs1004819 as significant in influencing the trait within the studied population.
title: The missing link between genetic association and regulatory function

finding: The G allele of rs3903239, which linked to atrial fibrillation, was found to be less frequent in LLIs, thereby indicating a lower risk of cardiovascular disorders and better survival probability to older ages.
title: Genetic variants associated with longevity in long-living Indians

finding: This variant was identified to be near the <italic>CLU</italic> locus and exhibited significant replication across various cohorts, showing an association with clusterin biology relevant to AAO.
title: Genetic Associations with Age at Dementia Onset in the PSEN1 E280A Colombian Kindred

finding: The rare variant in <italic>HSPG2</italic> showed suggestive association with dementia onset, implicating heparin sulfate dynamics in Alzheimer's disease pathology.
title: Genetic Associations with Age at Dementia Onset in the PSEN1 E280A Colombian Kindred

finding: The rs3918290 variant in the DPYD gene was found to have a significantly enriched frequency in the Reddy group, related to severe toxicities in cancer patients treated with fluorouracil.
title: Endogamy and high prevalence of deleterious mutations in India: evidence from strong founder events

finding: The rs2297595 variant in the DPYD gene exhibited a significantly higher frequency in the Yadav group, linked to potential severe toxicities in patients receiving fluorouracil treatment.
title: Endogamy and high prevalence of deleterious mutations in India: evidence from strong founder events

finding: The C allele of rs10803164 was found to have pleiotropic effects on blood cell trait variance, indicating its significant role in affecting multiple blood phenotypes.
title: Genome-wide analyses of variance in blood cell phenotypes provide new insights into complex trait biology and prediction

finding: This SNP was nominated as a putative causal variant and was a lead variant from the adiponectin meta-analysis.
title: A multi-ancestry genome-wide meta-analysis, fine-mapping, and gene prioritization approach to characterize the genetic architecture of adiponectin

finding: The rs11591147 variant in PCSK9 was associated with improved survival from cardiovascular death or heart transplant in patients diagnosed with ischemic heart disease (HR 0.78, P=0.03) after controlling for confounding factors.
title: Combining Genetic Proxies of Drug Targets and Time-to-event analyses From Longitudinal Observational Data To Identify Target Patient Populations

finding: Associated with pulmonary function in Europeans, rs11205303 exhibited around 14 times higher frequency in Europeans compared to Africans.
title: Genome-wide Association Study of Pulmonary Function in Europeans and Africans from the UK Biobank Identifies Distinct Variants

finding: The SNP rs6656401 near CR1 was shown to associate with elevated Alzheimer’s disease risk and was corroborated with the observed pTau associations.
title: Genome-wide meta-analysis for Alzheimer’s disease cerebrospinal fluid biomarkers

finding: The lead SNP rs6668622 showed a strong association with male susceptibility to COVID-19 outcomes, with a significant P-value indicating a relationship with the IVNS1ABP gene.
title: AncestryDNA COVID-19 Host Genetic Study Identifies Three Novel Loci

finding: The variant rs111972040 was linked with COVID-19 hospitalization outcomes in the meta-analysis, associated with the SRRM1 gene.
title: AncestryDNA COVID-19 Host Genetic Study Identifies Three Novel Loci

finding: The SNP rs2131902 located at chromosome 1q21.3 was identified as a protective allele with an odds ratio less than 1 compared to the major allele. Its significance increased when focusing on lung and liver metastasis subtypes, suggesting it could be a causal variant specifically influencing metastasis risk in these contexts.
title: Functional annotation with expression validation identifies novel metastasis-relevant genes from post-GWAS risk loci in sporadic colorectal carcinomas

finding: A rare frameshift variant associated significantly with the phenotype 'other cataract' (H26), reaching a p-value of 6.2e-9. This connection with FOXC3 was previously suggested in familial studies.
title: Whole-genome sequencing of half-a-million UK Biobank participants

finding: A homozygous carrier of this loss of function variant had notably low plasma LDL levels, being common in Africans but extremely rare among Europeans.
title: Whole-genome sequencing of half-a-million UK Biobank participants

finding: Found to be significantly associated with the 'other cataract' phenotype, reinforcing the linkage between FOXC3 and ocular diseases.
title: Whole-genome sequencing of half-a-million UK Biobank participants

finding: The SNP rs12133641 was identified as having a replicated cis-eQTL association with IL-6R, suggesting it plays a crucial role in the genetic regulation of IL-6 levels and its related signaling mechanisms.
title: Genetic analysis of blood molecular phenotypes reveals regulatory networks affecting complex traits: a DIRECT study

finding: The SNP rs12082227 was identified as a positive and original finding related to the response to chemoradiotherapy (CRT) in patients with locally advanced rectal cancer. The study indicated that pre-existing tumoral B cell infiltration, correlated with the presence of this SNP, was associated with a favorable response to CRT. This context was significant because it highlighted immune responses as a critical factor in determining patient response to therapy, suggesting that genomic markers such as this SNP could aid in predicting treatment outcomes.
title: Human Gene and Microbial Analyses Suggest Immunotherapy-like Mechanisms in Complete Response to Radiotherapy in Rectal Cancer

finding: The SNP rs3001038 was identified at the 1p31.1 locus with the lowest P value (P = 1.84 × 10^-12) and was functionally related to altered expression of the fever response gene PTGER3. It was associated with febrile seizures, showing an odds ratio (OR) of 1.14, indicating a risk-increasing allele corresponding to increased PTGER3 expression.
title: Genome-wide association study of febrile seizures identifies seven new loci implicating fever response and neuronal excitability genes

finding: At the 1q32.1 locus, the SNP rs1518111 was confirmed as associated with febrile seizures with a P value of 1.02 × 10^-10 and an OR of 1.16. This SNP was shown to influence IL10 expression, wherein the risk allele was linked to lower IL10 expression.
title: Genome-wide association study of febrile seizures identifies seven new loci implicating fever response and neuronal excitability genes

finding: This SNP indicated a potential positive effect on offspring birthweight, implicating pathways involved in serine biosynthesis rather than glycine degradation.
title: Causal effects of maternal circulating amino acids on offspring birthweight: a Mendelian randomisation study

finding: The rs2814778-CC genotype, predominantly found in individuals of African ancestry, was associated with lower baseline white blood cell (WBC) counts in the absence of disease. This genotype predisposed carriers to be more likely to undergo diagnostic investigations such as bone marrow biopsies due to lowered WBC counts and led to the discontinuation of medications like azathioprine due to concerns regarding toxicity. The clinical reference ranges for WBC counts were not properly calibrated to account for this genotype, resulting in misinterpretation of benign lower counts as pathology. These findings highlighted the implications of this genetic predisposition in clinical care, contributing to a disparity in how different populations manage drug-induced leukopenia and benign neutropenia.
title: Clinical consequences of a polygenic predisposition to benign lower white blood cell counts

finding: The intronic variant rs67579710 in THBS3 was found to be protectively associated against hospitalization due to COVID-19 and previously linked to reduced lung function.
title: Mapping the human genetic architecture of COVID-19 by worldwide meta-analysis

finding: This variant is part of a complex locus known for structural variants, associated with risk factors pertinent to lung function.
title: Mapping the human genetic architecture of COVID-19 by worldwide meta-analysis

finding: The SNP rs12030738 was associated with the classification and response prediction of tumors treated with ICIs, as indicated by the correlations found in the review of FDA-approved immune checkpoint inhibitors. This SNP's relevance was connected to the stratification methodologies employed in the study.
title: Tumor genomic subtypes orthogonal to mutation burden predict the efficacy of immune checkpoint therapy

finding: The variant rs11557080, located in the 3' UTR of RAB29, emerged as noteworthy in the analysis, displaying a p-value of 0.0034. Previous studies had suggested an interaction between RAB29 and LRRK2 activity, indicating its potential relevance in the context of LRRK2 parkinsonism.
title: LRRK2-Associated Parkinsonism With and Without In Vivo Evidence of Alpha-Synuclein Aggregates

finding: The SNP rs11591147 was identified as a direct causal variant associated with the PCSK9 gene for LDL-C. TGVIS maintained a credible set with a CS-Pratt value of 0.492, suggesting a strong connection to the gene-tissue pair PCSK9-Whole_Blood.
title: Uncovering causal gene-tissue pairs and variants: A multivariable TWAS method controlling for infinitesimal effects

finding: The SNP rs11206517 was also identified as a direct causal variant linked to LDL-C through the PCSK9 gene. It remained significant with a CS-Pratt value after applying the threshold.
title: Uncovering causal gene-tissue pairs and variants: A multivariable TWAS method controlling for infinitesimal effects

finding: SNP rs74048016 showed a larger deleterious effect on lung function as PM10 measurements increased, with the C allele associated with decreased expression of HES4 and increased expression of C1orf159 in blood.
title: Genome-wide gene-air pollution interaction analysis of lung function in 300,000 individuals

finding: There was significant evidence that the effects of rs145330152 differed by sex, with males having an effect approximately 1.8 times larger than females (95% CI: 1.15 - 2.5). This illustrates a potential sex-specific influence on genetic risk for DLB.
title: Identification of a sex-specific genetic signature in dementia with Lewy bodies: a meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies

finding: The SNP rs2636014 was identified to be under positive selection, indicating its potential role in regulating T-cell activities. This SNP was found in weak LD with rs2476601, which discordantly affected autoimmune diseases and basal cell carcinoma.
title: Extensive antagonistic variants across human genome

finding: The intronic variant rs10788884 in the SLC5A9 gene was associated with urinary xylose concentrations, a new metabolite association. It exhibited strong eQTL effects in kidney tissues, indicating its significant role in kidney function.
title: Genome-wide characterization of 54 urinary metabolites reveals molecular impact of kidney function

finding: This SNP was studied to be highly associated with low-density lipoprotein cholesterol.
title: VAREANT: a bioinformatics application for gene variant reduction and annotation

finding: The MUTYH c.1103G>A (p.Gly368Asp, rs36053993) was one of the two variants classified as pathogenic and exceeding 1% prevalence in the population, associated with autosomal recessive colorectal adenomatous polyposis.
title: Unveiling the Landscape of Reportable Genetic Secondary Findings in the Spanish Population: A Comprehensive Analysis Using the Collaborative Spanish Variant Server Database

finding: The SNP rs141749679 was associated with the hub gene SORT1, which was identified in astrocytes, implicating this gene in the context of AD.
title: Single-cell RNA sequencing data reveals rewiring of transcriptional relationships in Alzheimer’s Disease associated with risk variants

finding: The rs412543 polymorphism in GSTM1 was associated with increased risk of treatment-related adverse events, including hepatotoxicity among adults treated for tuberculosis.
title: Pharmacogenetics of tuberculosis treatment toxicity and effectiveness in a large Brazilian cohort

finding: The missense SNP rs2642438 in the MARC1 gene was previously shown to be protective against cirrhosis and associated with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease and hepatic lipid composition.
title: Genome-wide association study of liver fat, iron, and extracellular fluid fraction in the UK Biobank

finding: The missense mutation rs188273166 at SLC30A10 was associated with extracellular fluid and linked to liver health.
title: Genome-wide association study of liver fat, iron, and extracellular fluid fraction in the UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs77868538 was significantly associated with Chinese Vocabulary - Knowledge (CVK) and showed a very strong correlation with CVD_Total (r=0.97). It was located within the gene TNR (Tenascin R), which is involved in brain development.
title: A genome-wide association study of Chinese and English language abilities in Hong Kong Chinese children

finding: SNP rs16848469 was associated with both CVD_Total and CVK_Total and mapped to the TNR gene, which is deeply implicated in cognitive performance and human brain development.
title: A genome-wide association study of Chinese and English language abilities in Hong Kong Chinese children

finding: The SNP rs11591147 was associated with a partial loss-of-function variant in the PCSK9 gene among 440,371 UK Biobank participants. The study found that individuals carrying this variant had a median time-averaged difference in plasma LDL-C levels of 12.0 mg/dL compared to non-carriers, and 14.5 mg/dL among those not on lipid lowering therapy. This reduction in LDL-C levels contributed to the estimation of a reduced lifetime risk of major cardiovascular events by 57% if LDL lowering initiated at age 30.
title: A NATUrally Randomized trial Evaluating a vaccine-like strategy to lower LDL by inhibiting PCSK9 on the lifetime risk of major cardiovascular events (NATURE-PCSK9)

finding: The NLRP3 rs10157379 T > C variant was associated with symptoms such as fatigue, myalgia, hyperalgesia, and malaise in the acute infectious phase, indicating that abnormal NLRP3 activation may lead to exaggerated immune responses contributing to these symptoms.
title: Chronic fatigue, depression and anxiety symptoms in Long COVID are strongly predicted by neuroimmune and neuro-oxidative pathways which are caused by the inflammation during acute infection

finding: The NLRP3 rs10754558 C > G variant was found to be associated with similar symptoms of fatigue, myalgia, hyperalgesia, and malaise during the acute infectious phase, reinforcing the notion that NLRP3 inflammasome activation plays a role in the underlying pathology related to the cytokine storm in acute COVID-19.
title: Chronic fatigue, depression and anxiety symptoms in Long COVID are strongly predicted by neuroimmune and neuro-oxidative pathways which are caused by the inflammation during acute infection

finding: The SNP rs3766916 was identified as a credible variant colocalizing with genes TRIM46 and GON4L, suggesting a potential causal role in retinal traits associated with age-related ocular disorders.
title: Genome-wide analysis of genetic pleiotropy and causal genes across three age-related ocular disorders

finding: SNP rs4845712 was found to have a high linkage disequilibrium with rs3766916 and was located in an intron of the EFNA4 gene, which plays a critical role in axonal guidance in the optic nerve.
title: Genome-wide analysis of genetic pleiotropy and causal genes across three age-related ocular disorders

finding: The SNP rs36053993, related to the mutation c.C1178T in the MUTYH gene, was detected in 0.53% (3 out of 571) of patients with ESCC. It was identified solely in Caucasian patients in this study.
title: Comprehensive Study of Germline Mutations and Double-Hit Events in Esophageal Squamous Cell Cancer

finding: The SNP rs762307622, which corresponds to the mutation c.C458T in the MUTYH gene, was found in 0.35% (2 out of 571) of ESCC patients and was only detected in Asian (Chinese) individuals.
title: Comprehensive Study of Germline Mutations and Double-Hit Events in Esophageal Squamous Cell Cancer

finding: This variant was associated with increased pulmonary function, highlighting its role related to lung health measurements in COVID-19 contexts.
title: Integration of GWAS and multi-omic QTLs identifies uncharacterized COVID-19 gene-biotype and phenotype associations

finding: The SNP rs12082223 was identified in the context of research on epithelial ovarian cancer. Notably, the study found that high expression of folate receptor alpha (FRα), which correlates with the presence of specific mutations in affected tumors, linked to this SNP. The findings suggested possible associations with targetable mutations in FRα-expressing tumors, thereby implicating rs12082223 in the therapeutic potential of combinations of FRα-targeting agents with PI3K and FGF/R inhibitors.
title: Folate receptor alpha protein expression in ovarian serous cystadenocarcinoma tumors of The Cancer Genome Atlas: exploration beyond single-agent therapy

finding: SNP rs4949677-A in MSH4 was associated with increased risk of early death (HR=1.33, 95% CI: 1.07-1.65, p=0.0018), where A/A carriers had a notably lower median survival time of 9.2 years.
title: The impact of germline variants in DNA repair pathways on survival and temozolomide toxicity in adults with glioma

finding: The rs3219489-G variant in MUTYH was suggestively associated with improved survival (HR=0.69, 95% CI: 0.54-0.88, p=0.0034); G allele carriers showed median survival times of 16.9 years.
title: The impact of germline variants in DNA repair pathways on survival and temozolomide toxicity in adults with glioma

finding: The rs5745366-T polymorphism in MSH4 was linked to improved survival (HR=0.33, 95% CI: 0.15-0.72, p=0.0010), with C/T genotype carriers living a median of 13.6 years.
title: The impact of germline variants in DNA repair pathways on survival and temozolomide toxicity in adults with glioma

finding: The rs4844610 SNP in the CR1 locus was found to have significant associations in a larger meta-analysis, with a P-value of 5.76e-18, linking it to AD pathology.
title: Connecting genomic and proteomic signatures of amyloid burden in the brain

finding: The SNP rs121908309 was associated with a heterozygous stop-gain variant p.R398* in one patient. This finding contributed to the understanding of genetic factors in Parkinson's disease (PD), establishing a connection between GBA variants and PD risk.
title: Accurate long-read sequencing identified GBA variants as a major genetic risk factor in the Luxembourg Parkinson’s study

finding: The SNP rs2230288 was linked to a homozygous missense variant p.E365K/p.E365K found in two PD patients. This finding highlighted the role of GBA variants in parkinsonism, further establishing the significance of GBA-related genetic risks for PD.
title: Accurate long-read sequencing identified GBA variants as a major genetic risk factor in the Luxembourg Parkinson’s study

finding: The SNP rs138498426 was identified as a splice site variant (p.T408T). It was located within 2bp of the exon boundary and classified as a variant of unknown significance (VUS), thus providing insight into the potential complexities of GBA variant assessments in relation to PD.
title: Accurate long-read sequencing identified GBA variants as a major genetic risk factor in the Luxembourg Parkinson’s study

finding: The SNP rs3176466 near CDKN2C was found to have a positive association with FVC (P=4.59×10^-8, β=0.0236). No other significant previous associations were noted.
title: Multi-trait and multi-ancestry genetic analysis of comorbid lung diseases and traits improves genetic discovery and polygenic risk prediction

finding: The SNP rs188468174 at the RUNX3 locus on chr.1p36.11 exhibited a significant association with serum IgA levels, showing a Beta of 0.88 and a P-value of 3.42×10^-92, confirming its role in regulating IgA production.
title: Genetic regulation of serum IgA levels and susceptibility to common immune, infectious, kidney, and cardio-metabolic traits

finding: The SNP rs73100295 at the GPATCH2 locus was identified as a novel locus with an observed significant association with serum IgA levels, having a Beta of 0.36 and a P-value of 3.91×10^-8.
title: Genetic regulation of serum IgA levels and susceptibility to common immune, infectious, kidney, and cardio-metabolic traits

finding: This SNP associated with TNFSF4 locus displayed a significant correlation with IgA levels (Beta=0.06, P=1.06×10^-16), suggesting a link to immune responses.
title: Genetic regulation of serum IgA levels and susceptibility to common immune, infectious, kidney, and cardio-metabolic traits

finding: The SNP rs12142220 was part of a linkage analysis that produced a maximum combined multipoint logarithm of odds (LOD) score of 2.98, indicating a strong association with inherited oculopharyngodistal myopathy (OPDM) in affected individuals.
title: A CCG expansion in ABCD3 causes oculopharyngodistal myopathy in individuals of European ancestry

finding: The SNP rs490680 contributed to a maximum combined multipoint LOD score of 2.98, identifying it within a ~24 Mb linkage region associated with OPDM.
title: A CCG expansion in ABCD3 causes oculopharyngodistal myopathy in individuals of European ancestry

finding: The SNP rs1801265 was identified as achieving a LOD score of 2.98 in the analysis, highlighting its significant association with the pattern of muscle weakness in OPDM and related genetic modalities.
title: A CCG expansion in ABCD3 causes oculopharyngodistal myopathy in individuals of European ancestry

finding: The study identified rs147138607 as significantly associated with incident cardiovascular disease (CVD) among individuals with type 2 diabetes (T2D) with a hazard ratio (HR) of 1.23 (95% CI 1.15 – 1.32), P = 3.6×10^-9. This intergenic variant was located between the CACNA1E and ZNF648 genes.
title: Time-to-Event Genome-Wide Association Study for Incident Cardiovascular Disease in People with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus

finding: In the full model, rs140159474 was significant with an HR of 1.23 (95% CI 1.14 – 1.33), P = 5.0×10^-8. It was identified as an insertion/deletion variant in linkage disequilibrium with rs147138607.
title: Time-to-Event Genome-Wide Association Study for Incident Cardiovascular Disease in People with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus

finding: Previously shown to have gene-by-diabetes synergism on CVD risk and mentioned for its relation to GLUL expression changes in endothelial cells.
title: Time-to-Event Genome-Wide Association Study for Incident Cardiovascular Disease in People with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus

finding: The SNP rs764862951 was identified as a coding variant in the TNNT gene, which is associated with known cardiomyopathies.
title: Deep representation learning of electrocardiogram reveals novel insights in cardiac structure and functions and connections to cardiovascular diseases

finding: The SNP rs548640610 was found to reside within neuron and astrocyte-specific regulatory elements and located in an intron of CHRM3, which is expressed in the cortex region of the brain. It was predicted to occur in a region with strong enrichment for transcriptional coactivators suggesting its involvement in memory formation.
title: Rare genetic coding variants associated with age-related episodic memory decline implicate distinct memory pathologies in the hippocampus

finding: This SNP was a 3 prime UTR variant mapping to the S100PBP gene and was part of a critical community linked with two other significant SNPs, namely rs2904106 and rs237475, indicating shared pathways in ME/CFS pathology.
title: Genetic Risk Factors for ME/CFS Identified using Combinatorial Analysis

finding: At the  <italic>LEPR</italic> locus, rs10493377 exhibited a significant association with childhood BMI, demonstrating a transient effect that peaked at six months.
title: Characterization of the genetic architecture of BMI in infancy and early childhood reveals age-specific effects and implicates pathways involved in Mendelian obesity

finding: Found in the <italic>TNNI3K</italic> locus, rs10493544 was associated with BMI, showing increasing significance into later childhood.
title: Characterization of the genetic architecture of BMI in infancy and early childhood reveals age-specific effects and implicates pathways involved in Mendelian obesity

finding: The SNP rs545608 within the <italic>SEC16B</italic> locus displayed notable associations with childhood BMI, highlighting ongoing effects related to body composition.
title: Characterization of the genetic architecture of BMI in infancy and early childhood reveals age-specific effects and implicates pathways involved in Mendelian obesity

finding: As the strongest association with BMI identified in the study, rs2767486 in the <italic>LEPR</italic> locus peaked at six months, indicating a critical role in early weight development.
title: Characterization of the genetic architecture of BMI in infancy and early childhood reveals age-specific effects and implicates pathways involved in Mendelian obesity

finding: Located downstream of rs2767486 in the <italic>LEPR</italic> locus, rs10889551 was acknowledged for its independent association with BMI at early childhood, reinforcing its role in appetite regulation.
title: Characterization of the genetic architecture of BMI in infancy and early childhood reveals age-specific effects and implicates pathways involved in Mendelian obesity

finding: The SNP rs12071784 was identified as having a positive and original finding in relation to muscle-invasive bladder cancer (MIBC) and its response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy. Specifically, tumors with Genomically Unstable (GU) and Urothelial-like (Uro) subtypes exhibited higher proportions of pathological response and superior survival compared to the Basal-Squamous (Ba/Sq) subtype after receiving cisplatin-based chemotherapy. This finding emphasized that the genetic variability related to this SNP may influence the efficacy of treatment in patients with these bladder cancer subtypes.
title: Different responses to neoadjuvant chemotherapy in urothelial carcinoma molecular subtypes

finding: The HindIII polymorphism rs11118133 showed that the inherited genetic control did not account for the observed decrease in CR1 density on erythrocytes among COVID-19 patients. Both HH homozygous (high CR1 density) and HL/LL (medium/low CR1 density) genotypes exhibited a decrease in CR1/E density. However, the decrease was proportionally larger among individuals with the HH genotype, indicating that the higher the inherited density, the larger the acquired decrease observed during infection. This suggests that the CR1/E density reduction is an acquired phenomenon in COVID-19 rather than a genetically determined factor.
title: Acquired decrease of the C3b/C4b receptor (CR1, CD35) and increased C4d deposits on Erythrocytes from ICU COVID-19 Patients

finding: The rs1969869 SNP showed a strong association with DNA methylation levels at the 1q21.1 DMR, with a p-value < 10^-13. This SNP was linked to increased methylation levels in both blood and brain samples of PPMS patients, indicating its role in controlling genetic risk for the development of primary progressive MS.
title: Implication of DNA methylation changes at chromosome 1q21.1 in the brain pathology of Primary Progressive Multiple Sclerosis

finding: Similar to rs1969869, the SNP rs4950357 displayed significant associations with CpG methylation, reaching a p-value < 10^-8. It was part of the genetic variations controlling methylation at the 1q21.1 locus, further supporting the genetic predisposition to PPMS.
title: Implication of DNA methylation changes at chromosome 1q21.1 in the brain pathology of Primary Progressive Multiple Sclerosis

finding: The T allele at rs509325 was associated with decreased age at adiposity peak (AP) with an effect size of -0.003 years (P=1×10^-8) and increased age at adiposity rebound (AR) (effect size=0.12 years, P=5×10^-16). It was also linked to decreased BMI at the AR (-0.08 kg/m^2, P=5×10^-8) and impacted early and late childhood slopes, suggesting a substantial role in childhood BMI development.
title: A framework for conducting time-varying genome-wide association studies: An application to body mass index across childhood in six multiethnic cohorts
