finding: Although rs1130864 demonstrated an interaction with BMI, its association with HbA1c was comparatively weaker. The SNP still showed an association with CRP levels, but the effect was less pronounced than that of rs3093077 and rs1205.
title: Genetic effect modification of cis-acting C-reactive protein variants in cardiometabolic disease status

finding: The SNP rs1800947 had a strong association with CRP and showed significant interactions with both BMI and HbA1c, suggesting that this variant's impact on CRP levels was significantly modified by BMI.
title: Genetic effect modification of cis-acting C-reactive protein variants in cardiometabolic disease status

finding: The SNP rs1175550 was identified as a causative variant that intersects a cis-regulatory element at the SMIM1 locus. This element was associated with open chromatin in MEPs and early/intermediate erythroid precursors, contributing to red blood cell traits.
title: An integrated platform to systematically identify causal variants and genes for polygenic human traits

finding: The SNP rs9660992 was suggested to be a tag SNP at the TMCC2 locus, identified through weak linkage disequilibrium with multiple other variants associated with erythropoiesis.
title: An integrated platform to systematically identify causal variants and genes for polygenic human traits

finding: The investigation of SNP rs1805407 revealed that this variant was associated with increased sensitivity to PARP1 inhibitors in cancer cells. This provided a context suggesting that targeting this SNP could enhance therapeutic strategies in cancer treatment.
title: CausER - a framework for inferring causal latent factors using multi-omic human datasets

finding: The missense variant Thr95Ile in SLC30A10 was associated with a 4.2% increase in ALT and a 5.9% increase in AST. Carriers had a higher prevalence of liver disease (OR = 1.70) and extrahepatic bile duct cancer (OR = 23.8), marking it as the strongest effect SNP related to both enzymes.
title: Genome-wide association study of circulating liver enzymes reveals an expanded role for manganese transporter SLC30A10 in liver health

finding: The SNP rs12075, an amino acid-changing variant in the ACKR1 gene, was associated with multiple cytokine ratios in rQTL analyses. It highlighted complex interactions with multiple cytokines related to the Duffy blood group and malaria resistance.
title: Genetic associations with ratios between protein levels detect new pQTLs and reveal protein-protein interactions

finding: The SNP rs12082154 was identified as a significant marker linked to the responsiveness of melanoma cells to treatment. It was associated with EMT-inducing transcription factors that were implicated in the phenotype switching of melanoma. This finding was relevant in the context of resistance mechanisms against targeted therapies, indicating that variations at this locus could influence gene expression states and memory in response to treatment.
title: Disrupting cellular memory to overcome drug resistance

finding: The T1D SNP rs3024505 was associated with the promoters of IL9 and FAIM3 and was predicted to disrupt the binding of the transcription factor MZF1, affecting downstream gene expression crucial for T cell function.
title: Chromatin conformation dynamics during CD4+ T cell activation implicates autoimmune disease-associated genes and regulatory elements

finding: The SNP rs539515, located 6kb downstream of SEC16B, displayed strong GxE interactions with logBMI, with a notably high significance level (p = 6.5×10^-12). This SNP exhibited very similar patterns of main effect and GxE association. Previous analyses also reported multiplicative GxE interactions at the SEC16B locus, emphasizing its relevance in obesity-related traits.
title: Gene-environment interactions using a Bayesian whole genome regression model

finding: The SNP rs12123765 had been identified in prior studies as a significant marker associated with breast cancer stem cell properties, particularly linked to epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) pathways. This finding supported the understanding of how genetic variations could influence tumor behavior and response to therapy.
title: Neutrophils exposed to a cholesterol metabolite secrete extracellular vesicles that promote epithelial-mesenchymal transition and stemness in breast cancer cells

finding: The SNP rs10889923 was found to map on an intron for NEGR1, a gene linked to various phenotypes correlated with hypertension. Although associated with multiple traits, it had not been previously linked to hypertension via GWAS prior to this finding.
title: DeepCOMBI: Explainable artificial intelligence for the analysis and discovery in genome-wide association studies

finding: The minor variant of SNP rs3753381 was found to affect the activity of a SLAMF1 enhancer, indicating its importance in modulating gene expression related to immune responses.
title: Rapid and Quantitative Functional Interrogation of Human Enhancer Variant Activity in Live Mice

finding: The SNP rs116276872 on chromosome 1 was identified by the multivariate G test and was associated with LDL cholesterol levels, demonstrating a positive original finding linked to lipid phenotypes.
title: A multivariate approach to joint testing of main genetic and gene-environment interaction effects

finding: The rs76813758 variant was identified as a significant genetic variant during variant-aware off-target analysis for the PAH1 protospacer. Initially, this SNP had a ONE-seq score of 0.11, indicating its potential to be a site of off-target editing when using gRNAs. It was found to alter a reference genomic site, changing the number of mismatches with the on-target protospacer from 4 (with an NGG PAM) to 3 (with an NGG PAM). The variant was common, present in approximately 8% of individuals of African ancestry and about 3% of individuals of European ancestry. However, further investigations with hybrid gRNAs (PAH1_hybA and PAH1_hybD) significantly reduced the ONE-seq score for rs76813758 to 0.004 and 0.0001 respectively, demonstrating the potential of hybrid gRNAs to mitigate off-target editing effects.
title: Improved specificity and efficacy of base-editing therapies with hybrid guide RNAs

finding: Detected in the alkaline phosphatase gene (ALPL) locus, rs12141569 reached a <P<sub>GWAS</sub> of 3.9×10<sup>−8</sup>. While it was not significantly associated with CAVS phenotypes after multiple testing correction, a nominal association with bone mineral density was observed, suggesting its involvement in calcification processes.
title: Genetic association analyses highlight IL6, ALPL, and NAV1 as three new susceptibility genes underlying calcific aortic valve stenosis

finding: Identified as the lead SNP for neuron navigator 1 (NAV1) on chromosome 1q32.1 with a GWAS significance of <P<sub>GWAS</sub> of 1.5×10<sup>−6</sup>. It correlated with increased NAV1 expression in valve tissues and showed associations with diastolic blood pressure and carotid artery conditions, thus supporting its role in CAVS susceptibility.
title: Genetic association analyses highlight IL6, ALPL, and NAV1 as three new susceptibility genes underlying calcific aortic valve stenosis

finding: This SNP was previously reported in the PALMD locus with a high posterior probability for causality (PPC=0.98), indicating its strong link to calcific aortic valve stenosis (CAVS).
title: Genetic association analyses highlight IL6, ALPL, and NAV1 as three new susceptibility genes underlying calcific aortic valve stenosis

finding: The alternate allele for rs12143842, located in the NOS1AP gene promoter, correlated with increased enhancer peak height and also to the gene expression of both NOS1AP and the distal gene C1orf226.
title: Disease and phenotype relevant genetic variants identified from histone acetylomes in human hearts

finding: The SNP rs11581607 showed strong evidence of association with Crohn's disease (OR=3.22, 95%CI=2.93 to 3.53, P=6.93×10−131), suggesting a putatively causal link between this variant and the disease.
title: Phenome-wide Mendelian randomization mapping the influence of the plasma proteome on complex diseases

finding: The SNP rs12071159 appeared in the work of Meyers et al. (2020), where a new NDVI-based sampling protocol was developed for grape maturation monitoring. This finding reinforced the idea that genetic SNPs could be pivotal in enhancing monitoring protocols and thereby supporting agricultural productivity.
title: Assessing the capacity of high-resolution commercial satellite imagery for grapevine downy mildew detection and surveillance in New York state

finding: In Raza et al. (2020), SNP rs12071213 was part of the exploration into high-resolution satellite imagery for detecting diseases such as Soybean Sudden Death Syndrome. This connection supported the idea that genetic markers could be integrated with technological solutions to enhance disease detection efforts.
title: Assessing the capacity of high-resolution commercial satellite imagery for grapevine downy mildew detection and surveillance in New York state

finding: The SNP rs12142213 was documented in the research by Vitrack-Tamam et al. (2020), focusing on the random forest algorithm's enhancement of physiological activity detection through reflectance spectra. This research highlighted the integration of genetic and spectral data for better agricultural outcomes.
title: Assessing the capacity of high-resolution commercial satellite imagery for grapevine downy mildew detection and surveillance in New York state

finding: The functional variant rs11240391 in the LAX1 promoter was identified as a regulator of severe malaria susceptibility, with the GG genotype increasing the risk of severe malaria (OR = 2.6, p = 0.005). Genetic modifications showed that the T allele was associated with higher expression of LAX1, and its absence led to hyperactivation of TCR signaling in T cells, reflecting its critical role in immune response and malaria resistance.
title: Unraveling a novel dual-function regulatory element showing epistatic interaction with a variant that escapes genome-wide association studies

finding: The SNP rs4844620 was found near the gene CD46 and was identified as having genome-wide significance for early age-related macular degeneration (AMD) with a P value of 4.7x10^-8. This variant was supported by independent data showing additional significance (P=7.0x10^-5). Functional analyses indicated that it increased expression of CD46 in retinal cells, suggesting a role in AMD pathology.
title: Genome-wide association meta-analysis for early age-related macular degeneration highlights novel loci and insights for advanced disease

finding: SNP rs2724384 was associated with early AMD risk through its correlation with rs4844620 in the CD46 locus. It was reported to influence the formation of a shorter CD46 isoform, suggesting potentially pathogenic roles in AMD rather than functioning solely through complement inactivation.
title: Genome-wide association meta-analysis for early age-related macular degeneration highlights novel loci and insights for advanced disease

finding: The SNP rs2724374 was in the credible set for the CD46 locus and was correlated with rs4844620, with both variants identified as risk factors for early AMD. The major alleles were linked to an increased AMD risk, highlighting their possible role in the disease pathology.
title: Genome-wide association meta-analysis for early age-related macular degeneration highlights novel loci and insights for advanced disease

finding: The SNP rs12061393 was linked to the secretion of EGF by cancer-associated fibroblasts, which contributed to chemoresistance in colorectal cancer. This study established a connection between anti-EGFR therapy and increased resistance due to CAF interactions.
title: Merging Metabolic Modeling and Imaging for Screening Therapeutic Targets in Colorectal Cancer

finding: Similarly, the rs4970834 SNP showed a replicated association with LDL levels, indicating its importance across different cohorts.
title: Understanding Complex Trait Susceptibilities and Ethnical Diversity in a Sample of 4,145 Russians Through Analysis of Clinical and Genetic Data

finding: The SNP rs72629486 was found to be a missense coding variant in the gene ACTRT2, with an observed minor allele frequency (MAF) ranging from 5% in Ethiopia to 1.3% in Uganda in the NeuroGAP-Psychosis cohort. This significant variation in frequency highlighted its functional importance in different African populations. The variant was predicted to be deleterious and probably damaging, as indicated by SIFT and PolyPhen scores, respectively, and had a combined annotation dependent depletion score of 22.9, confirming its likely substantial impact on human health.
title: Genetic structure correlates with ethnolinguistic diversity in eastern and southern Africa

finding: The SNP rs2820436 was confirmed as a new locus for HOMA-IR established for fasting insulin with strong linkage (R²=1), related to obesity effects on waist-to-hip ratio.
title: Genetics of fasting indices of glucose homeostasis using GWIS unravels tight relationships with inflammatory markers

finding: The SNP rs80356677 (c.2020 G>T) was identified as a pathogenic missense mutation causing the change from aspartic acid (Asp) to tyrosine (Tyr) at amino acid 674 in the NTRK1 gene. This mutation was found to be homozygous (T/T) in the CIPA patient, indicating an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern. The mutation was associated with the pathogenesis of congenital insensitivity to pain with anhidrosis (CIPA).
title: Genomic, Ancestral and Networking Analyses of a High-Altitude Native American Ecuadorian Patient with Congenital Insensitivity to Pain with Anhidrosis

finding: The SNP rs763758904 (c.1804 C>T) was noted as a pathogenic stop gained/splice region variant resulting in the conversion of arginine (Arg) to a stop codon at position 602 in the NTRK1 gene. The patient was shown to be homozygous (T/T) for this mutation, further contributing to the understanding of CIPA's genetic basis.
title: Genomic, Ancestral and Networking Analyses of a High-Altitude Native American Ecuadorian Patient with Congenital Insensitivity to Pain with Anhidrosis

finding: The SNP was significantly associated with the risk of both overall and estrogen receptor positive (ER+) breast cancer, providing robust evidence for its involvement.
title: Circulating concentrations of micro-nutrients and risk of breast cancer: A Mendelian randomization study

finding: The rs2297480 SNP located in the FDPS gene showed a notable frequency difference between Ukrainians and other European groups, linked to the response to bisphosphonates.
title: Genome Diversity in Ukraine

finding: The variant rs4950928 in the CHI3L1 gene exhibited distinct frequencies between Ukrainians and other groups, linked to risk of asthma and lung function.
title: Genome Diversity in Ukraine

finding: The SNP rs10911021 was originally identified as being associated with coronary heart disease specifically in individuals with type 2 diabetes. This association correlated with lower concentrations of circulating HDL cholesterol and large HDL particles, which are significant factors in cardiovascular health.
title: Massive loss of transcription factors and the initial diversification of placental mammals

finding: The rs58130172 SNP was identified as a significant variant altering an E-box motif, which was notably associated with the DISP3 gene—a gene influencing neural fate decisions. This variant was linked to increased DISP3 expression in the brain, acting as an eQTL with a q-value less than 4e-6 and a log2 fold change of 0.49. Predictions indicated that the alternative allele at this SNP location exhibited higher expected NGN2 binding and activation potential compared to the reference allele.
title: Chromatin-dependent motif syntax defines differentiation trajectories

finding: The SNP rs4606268 was linked to significant predicted changes in the expression of the gene SLC44A5, which is involved in choline transport and is highly expressed in skin, testis, and esophagus. The analysis indicated that this SNP had a markedly larger effect on SLC44A5 expression in individuals of European ancestry compared to those of African ancestry, suggesting rapid evolutionary changes in gene regulation in European populations. Furthermore, the findings pointed to possible recent selection for lower expression levels of SLC44A5 in British individuals. This SNP's association with SLC44A5 expression levels was particularly relevant to skin pigmentation, a trait that underwent strong selection in both Britain and East Asia.
title: Predicting functional consequences of recent natural selection in Britain

finding: The SNP rs4294451 was identified as a putative regulatory SNP within the enhancer region E9 for the Dihydropyrimidine Dehydrogenase (DPD, DPYD gene) expression. It was shown that this SNP significantly influenced the expression of DPD and altered sensitivity to the anti-cancer drug 5-fluorouracil (5-FU). Specifically, the T allele of rs4294451 was associated with increased DPYD expression and reduced sensitivity to 5-FU, demonstrated through various experimental models including CRISPR genome edited cells and human liver specimens. The T allele enhanced the recruitment of transcription factor CEBPB, which increased enhancer-promoter interactions, thereby elevating DPYD transcription and contributing to therapeutic resistance to 5-FU.
title: Germline cis variant determines epigenetic regulation of the anti-cancer drug metabolism gene dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase (DPYD)

finding: The SNP rs2814778 was identified as a key characterizing SNP for the first split in the hierarchical tangles tree, primarily separating the African (AFR) populations from others. This SNP is associated with the Duffy blood group system and is linked to malaria resistance. It demonstrated near-fixed differentiation between Africans and other superpopulations.
title: Inferring Ancestry with the Hierarchical Soft Clustering Approach tangleGen

finding: The rs2814778 variant characterized the FY*O or Duffy-null allele, which was near fixation in sub-Saharan populations but rare elsewhere. This allele deactivated expression of the Duffy antigen, suggesting resistance to vivax malaria. The study supported previous findings of positive selection for this allele in sub-Saharan Africa. However, the strength of selection was not maximal in the region of the rs2814778 variant, indicating that although selection occurred, the specific region harboring this variant did not exhibit the strongest signal of selection compared to neighboring areas. In Asian populations, this variant was linked to the strongest evidence for selection in the respective region.
title: A New Likelihood-based Test for Natural Selection

finding: The SNP rs3737240, located in the ECM1 gene, was associated with chronic hip pain, linking it to the regulatory role of ECM1 in bone mineralization.
title: Analysis of genetically independent phenotypes identifies shared genetic factors associated with chronic musculoskeletal pain at different anatomic sites

finding: The SNP rs74469838 was related to MEGF6, which has established associations with Systemic Mastocytosis, another correlate of CVD. This SNP also supports the conclusion that the genetic basis impacting Delta ECG is linked with known CVD correlates.
title: Genetic underpinnings of predicted changes in cardiovascular function using self supervised learning

finding: The SNP rs60252802 was a positive original finding associated with intron level and exon-intron-ratio of SDF4, a calcium-binding protein. It colocalized with GWAS variants for systemic lupus erythematosus and indicated that this cis-QTL increased the probability of mis-splicing by introducing an alternative splice site, extending the first exon significantly.
title: Disentangling genetic effects on transcriptional and post-transcriptional gene regulation through integrating exon and intron expression QTLs

finding: The SNP rs370545 was a positive original finding linked to exon and intron levels of GBAP1, a pseudogene, and was associated with GWAS variants for mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration.
title: Disentangling genetic effects on transcriptional and post-transcriptional gene regulation through integrating exon and intron expression QTLs

finding: The SNP rs12123689 was linked to the TRIB2 gene and was found to be relevant in the context of drug resistance in cancer therapy. Studies indicated that alterations in this SNP might affect the effectiveness of treatments, specifically concerning TRIB2-mediated mechanisms.
title: The inhibition of three distinct signaling pathways eliminates the oncogenic Tribbles homolog 2 from melanoma cells

finding: The SNP rs2816938 was replicated among 17/40 previously discovered variants associated with pancreatic cancer (PC) risk, confirming its association direction in context with prior studies.
title: A multilayered post-GWAS assessment on genetic susceptibility to pancreatic cancer

finding: The SNP rs3790844 was positively replicated as one of the 17 variants linked to PC risk, maintaining the same association direction as earlier reports.
title: A multilayered post-GWAS assessment on genetic susceptibility to pancreatic cancer

finding: The SNP rs3790840 emerged as a novel variant in NR5A2 that independently correlated with PC risk, showing a meta odds ratio of 1.23, strengthening the relevance of NR5A2 in susceptibility.
title: A multilayered post-GWAS assessment on genetic susceptibility to pancreatic cancer

finding: The SNP rs4465241 is in moderate linkage disequilibrium with the newly identified rs3790840 and remained significant in analyses, indicating its potential role in pancreatic cancer.
title: A multilayered post-GWAS assessment on genetic susceptibility to pancreatic cancer

finding: For SNP rs650866, which is located near the SLC35F3 gene that plays a role in thiamine transport, the highest posterior probabilities were assigned to G×T interaction models (1, 0, 1) and (1, 1, 1) across all three modeling approaches. Log-NL provided the largest certainty in posterior mode models, which suggested a strong G×T interaction implication.
title: Probabilistic classification of gene-by-treatment interactions on molecular count phenotypes

finding: SNP rs10157612, adjacent to the ENSG00000287315 gene, displayed both model categories (1, 1, 0) and (1, 1, 1) with non-zero posterior probabilities, indicating complex G×T interactions that vary by genotype response.
title: Probabilistic classification of gene-by-treatment interactions on molecular count phenotypes

finding: SNP rs12040085 was predicted as a trans-eQTL in adipose visceral tissue and resided in a GWAS locus related to body mass index (BMI) and body fat percentage. Among its top predicted target genes, several were associated with BMI and obesity, implicating its role in metabolic traits.
title: Reverse regression increases power for detecting trans-eQTLs

finding: The SNP rs747993448 was identified as affecting the amino acid p.Arg179, which is conserved between humans and mice. This SNP is listed in the ClinVar database as pathogenic or likely pathogenic, suggesting it may have significant health implications, particularly in relation to DNA damage response.
title: A natural mutator allele shapes mutation spectrum variation in mice

finding: Similar to rs747993448, the SNP rs143353451 also affects the p.Arg179 amino acid and is categorized in ClinVar as pathogenic or likely pathogenic. This finding reinforces the potential impact of these mutations on the mutator phenotype and DNA repair mechanisms.
title: A natural mutator allele shapes mutation spectrum variation in mice

finding: SNP rs7521902 in the Wnt4 gene was reported to be significantly correlated with the pathogenesis of endometriosis, indicating its involvement in the disease process as per findings by Angioni et al. (2020).
title: Key Promoter Region of Wnt4 response to FSH and Genetic Effect on Several Production Traits of Its Mutations in Chicken

finding: SNP rs2072920 in the Wnt4 gene was associated with variations in body mass index (BMI) within the Han Chinese population, suggesting a relationship between this SNP and body weight regulation as noted by Dong et al. (2017).
title: Key Promoter Region of Wnt4 response to FSH and Genetic Effect on Several Production Traits of Its Mutations in Chicken

finding: The study indicated that genetic variation rs7930 in the miR-4273-5p target site was associated with an increased risk of colorectal cancer. This finding underscored the relevance of alterations in microRNA target sites in the etiology of various tumors, linking this SNP to cancer susceptibility.
title: Mutant ACTB mRNA 3′UTR Promotes Hepatocellular Carcinoma Development by Regulating miR-1 and miR-29a

finding: The SNP rs1065756 in the ALDH9A1 gene was identified among three subjects in the study and was deemed likely benign. It was reported as a previously known variant but did not show a significant association with severe outcomes. This finding suggests that while it is present, its impact on Fanconi anemia (FA) is limited.
title: ALDH9A1 Deficiency as a Source of Endogenous DNA Damage that Requires Repair by the Fanconi Anemia Pathway

finding: Located within the JAK1 core haplotype in Oceanic populations, rs377425962 also showed patterns of adaptive selection linked to immune function.
title: Exploring adaptive introgression in modern human circadian rhythm genes

finding: The variant rs150641471 was found in an intron of NAV1, located 50kb from the promoter of IPO9. It was significantly associated with malignant thyroid neoplasm (OR = 1.05, p = 3e-22), diffuse large cell lymphoma (OR = 1.1, p = 6.6e-12), and leukaemia (OR = 1.004, p = 2.2e-6). This association aligned with previous transposon screens in mice that suggested IPO9's involvement in hematopoietic malignancy.
title: Convergent mutations in tissue-specific regulatory regions reveal novel cancer drivers

finding: The finding detailed a skipping event of exon 17 in the DNM3 gene, associated with a beta value of 0.55 and a q-value of 3.5 x 10^-4. This result indicated that the presence of the risk allele at rs10752946 was linked to a significant increase in the proportion of isoforms that excluded exon 17, particularly in the Korowai group, which exhibited a higher rate of exon 17 skipping (22.5%) compared to Mentawai (7.6%) and Sumba (7.5%) populations.
title: Profiling genetically driven alternative splicing across the Indonesian Archipelago

finding: The TLR5 SNP rs5744168 (TLR5<sup>392STOP</sup>) was associated with reduced TLR4-mediated inflammation in humans. Carriers of the minor allele demonstrated a decreased inflammatory response to both LPS and flagellin when analyzed using purified monocyte-derived macrophages. This finding was supported by the observation that TNF-α production was significantly lower in alveolar macrophages from individuals carrying this SNP after exposure to O<sub>3</sub>, confirming that TLR5 genetic variation influenced the response to TLR4 signaling. The study utilized data from the Environmental Polymorphisms Registry to recruit participants, indicating a presence of the SNP in 8-10% of Caucasians and 3% of African Americans.
title: TLR5 participates in the TLR4 receptor complex and biases towards MyD88-dependent signaling in environmental lung injury

finding: The SNP rs12753193, located near the LEPR gene, was initially identified through vQTL analysis, which demonstrated an interaction effect with body mass index (BMI) on C-reactive protein levels. This finding positioned rs12753193 as a significant candidate for further interaction analysis.
title: Detecting latent gene-environment interaction when analyzing binary traits

finding: The variant rs3753841 in the COL11A1 gene, associated with a nonsynonymous change p.(Pro1335Leu), was found to be significantly associated with adolescent idiopathic scoliosis (AIS) in a study with a total of 9,161 AIS cases and 80,731 controls, showing an odds ratio (OR) of 1.118 and a p-value of 7.07e-11.
title: Association of an estrogen-sensitive Pax1-Col11a1-Mmp3 signaling axis with adolescent idiopathic scoliosis

finding: rs3008455 was shown to map to a regulatory element near the LMO4 promoter located at 1p22.3. The risk allele was predicted to enhance CTCF binding, suggesting that this SNP could influence the chromatin architecture and thereby the expression of LMO4, a gene implicated in breast cancer proliferation and tumorigenesis.
title: Chromatin interactome mapping at 139 independent breast cancer risk signals

finding: The SNP rs12071930 was associated with the detection technologies and clinical utility of circulating tumor cells (CTCs) as reported by Habli et al. (2020). The finding highlighted its relevance in improving methods for detecting CTCs, which is important for monitoring metastatic cancers.
title: Marker-free characterization of single live circulating tumor cell full-length transcriptomes

finding: The SNP rs7515577 was identified as an original univariate association in the GlobalLipids2010 dataset, crossing a significance threshold with a p-value below 5 x 10^-8, indicating its relevance to plasma lipid traits.
title: Bayesian multivariate reanalysis of large genetic studies identifies many new associations

finding: The SNP rs12038699 was reported as a new multivariate association in the GlobalLipids2013 dataset, reaching univariate genome-wide significance but previously unreported. Despite being near to rs7515577 (549kb apart), it demonstrated a distinct multivariate pattern of effect sizes, suggesting it represents a non-redundant association potentially involving different biological mechanisms.
title: Bayesian multivariate reanalysis of large genetic studies identifies many new associations

finding: The SNP rs12061671 was associated with responses to ultra-high dose rate FLASH irradiation in radiosensitive juvenile mice. This study demonstrated neuroprotective effects and altered immune responses in the context of treatment for tumors like Diffuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma (DIPG). The correlation of immune cell responses indicated that this SNP might influence the treatment outcomes and immune microenvironment dynamics when comparing FLASH irradiation to conventional dose-rate treatment.
title: FLASH and Conventional Radiation Induce Differential Immune Responses in Diffuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma, Highlighting Potential for Combination Immunotherapy

finding: Similar to rs10743430, this SNP led to confirmed structural changes in the lncRNA, which could influence its interaction with specific RBPs.
title: Effect of Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms on the structure of long noncoding RNAs and their interaction with RNA Binding Proteins

finding: The variant rs12725078 was associated with sulcal depth and implicated in the gene <italic>SRGAP2</italic>, which is significant for brain morphology and may impact neurocognitive features.
title: Gene expansions contributing to human brain evolution

finding: The SNP rs12040938 was associated with the pathogenesis and therapeutic response in B-Cell Non-Hodgkin Lymphomas, indicating its relevance in identifying genetic predispositions to these lymphomas. This finding was derived from research focusing on BCL-2 protein interactions, which play a critical role in the survival of malignant B cells.
title: MarsGT: Multi-omics analysis for rare population inference using single-cell graph transformer

finding: SNP rs2047287 showed a strong association with choline levels in RBCs and was in strong linkage disequilibrium with the missense mutation T544M in FLVCR1, linking it to genetic variability in choline metabolism.
title: Genome-wide metabolite quantitative trait loci analysis (mQTL) in red blood cells from volunteer blood donors

finding: The SNP rs12030728 was identified as a positive finding related to glioblastoma recurrence prediction from preoperative MR scans, utilizing fractional-anisotropy maps with free-water suppression. This finding was part of a study that aimed to enhance glioblastoma treatment efficacy by correlating genetic variations with imaging characteristics, linking genetic factors to patient-specific responses in GBM.
title: Non-operable glioblastoma: proposition of patient-specific forecasting by image-informed poromechanical model

finding: The study referenced the SNP rs12030769 in the context of analyzing the efficiency of CRISPR/Cas9 techniques for tagging genes not expressed in human induced pluripotent stem cells (hiPSCs). It involved monitoring the effectiveness of homology-directed repair (HDR) at loci such as TBR2, TBXT, CDH2, and CDH5, which are crucial during cellular differentiation. The identification of these tags allowed for improved observation of cellular dynamics, correlating genetic variations with phenotypic expressions essential for differentiation and cellular functions.
title: Enhanced endogenous gene tagging in human induced pluripotent stem cells via AAV6-mediated donor delivery

finding: The SNP rs9435731 was also implicated in the regulation of multiple genes, specifically >4 genes including ATP13A2, CROCC, MFAP2, and RP1-37C10.3. This finding underscored its relevance in understanding gene expression and regulatory mechanisms associated with COPD.
title: De novo discovery of traits co-occurring with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

finding: The SNP rs272570 was identified as a lead variant associated with the gene RNF220, which is linked to heart rate. This association had also been documented in previous studies, demonstrating its relevance as a true positive finding in the context of complex traits.
title: Rapid and accurate multi-phenotype imputation for millions of individuals

finding: The SNP rs12082014 was identified in a study by Sirvent et al. (2020), which linked Src family tyrosine kinases to various biological processes including intestinal homeostasis and tumorigenesis. The findings highlighted the regulatory mechanisms of Src through lipid-mediated self-association and emphasized its significance in transforming human cells, connecting the mutation of lysine clusters to altered signaling interactions.
title: Lipid-driven SRC self-association modulates its transformation capacity

finding: The SNP rs12082051 was identified in a study regarding the interplay between cellular metabolism and the DNA damage response in cancer. This finding highlighted the significant role of this SNP in linking metabolic alterations to the mechanisms driving genomic instability and carcinogenic processes.
title: Artificial Intelligence uncovers carcinogenic human metabolites

finding: The SNP rs12095538, residing in the eQTL of STY6, was shown to affect the expression of SYT6, which is downregulated in Alzheimer's disease (AD), establishing a connection between this variant and AD progression.
title: GenEpi: Gene-based Epistasis Discovery Using Machine Learning

finding: The SNP rs2774308, located in a DNAse region of STY6, was found to potentially synergistically affect the expression of SYT6 along with rs12095538, linking it to Alzheimer's disease.
title: GenEpi: Gene-based Epistasis Discovery Using Machine Learning

finding: The SNP rs56233035 was identified within the LD blocks of CACNA1E and associated with the expression in reactive astrocytes, correlating to amyloid-beta plaque formation in AD models.
title: GenEpi: Gene-based Epistasis Discovery Using Machine Learning

finding: The SNP rs3678, which resides in a DNAse region of CACNA1E, was discussed as having potential implications in the expression levels associated with amyloid plaque formation in AD.
title: GenEpi: Gene-based Epistasis Discovery Using Machine Learning

finding: The Duffy-null SNP rs2814778 on chromosome 1q23.2 showed a significant association with neutrophil counts among individuals of African ancestry. However, this variant was rare and excluded from the training data, which highlighted potential biases in Polygenic Scores (PGS) due to the absence of non-shared causal variants. This finding emphasized the necessity for ancestral diversity in genetic studies to accurately reflect traits such as neutrophil counts.
title: Polygenic scoring accuracy varies across the genetic ancestry continuum in all human populations

finding: The SNP rs1335531 in the CD58 gene was reported to have higher frequency in Latin American populations compared to sub-Saharan Africans, suggesting a genetic basis for differing immune responses to ZIKV.
title: Hypothetical Human Immune Genome Complex Gradient May Help to Explain the Congenital Zika Symdrome Catastrophe in Brazil: A New Theory

finding: The SNP rs12040846 was linked with the expression of VEGF-C in tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs). The findings indicated that high levels of VEGF-C in TAMs correlated inversely with malignant grade and were associated with the occurrence of tumor microenvironment of metastasis (TMEM) complexes in breast cancer patients, suggesting a role for this SNP in modifying cancer cell dissemination patterns.
title: VEGF-C expressing Tumor-Associated Macrophages decrease hematogenous metastatic dissemination and normalize the tumor vasculature

finding: The SNP rs483259 was significantly associated with decreased expression of the LRRIQ3 gene. The association was quantified with a p-value of 2 × 10^-10, demonstrating a strong link between this genetic variant and expression levels. It was highlighted that this SNP is in linkage disequilibrium (LD) with two nearby SNPs, which were previously associated with increased educational attainment.
title: Cross-tissue eQTL mapping in the presence of missing data via surrogate outcome analysis

finding: The SNP rs10789387 was found to be in linkage disequilibrium (LD) with rs483259, having an R² value of 0.66. It was notably associated with increased educational attainment as per a meta-analysis of over 1.1 million subjects, with a p-value of 7 × 10^-16.
title: Cross-tissue eQTL mapping in the presence of missing data via surrogate outcome analysis

finding: Similar to rs10789387, the SNP rs11210400 was also in linkage disequilibrium with rs483259 (R² = 0.66) and was significantly associated with increased educational attainment with a p-value of 2 × 10^-17 in the same large-scale meta-analysis.
title: Cross-tissue eQTL mapping in the presence of missing data via surrogate outcome analysis

finding: The SNP rs2936018 was previously associated with the presentation of pulmonary arteriovenous malformations (PAVM) in patients with Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT). It was identified as a cis-eQTL for PTPN14, where the PAVM-protective minor allele (T) correlated with higher PTPN14 expression levels in the human aorta. This finding indicated that genetic variation within PTPN14 could influence clinical outcomes of HHT through its impact on the expression of Smad4-related signaling pathways.
title: The YAP/TAZ antagonist, PTPN14, stabilizes SMAD4 through direct interactions in endothelial cells: Implications for Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia

finding: The SNP rs2270703, located 1Kb proximal to rs2936018, was identified as a strong cis-eQTL for PTPN14 expression levels across multiple human tissues, showing significant correlation with PTPN14 expression in arterial tissues. The minor allele of rs2270703 was associated with lower PTPN14 expression, further supporting the hypothesis that genetic variations in PTPN14 could affect vascular phenotypes and clinical features of HHT.
title: The YAP/TAZ antagonist, PTPN14, stabilizes SMAD4 through direct interactions in endothelial cells: Implications for Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia

finding: The SNP rs1061170 was strongly associated with age-related macular degeneration (AMD) risk as it leads to the Y402H polymorphism within the CFH gene. This genetic variant resulted in a coding change where a tyrosine residue is replaced by a histidine at position 402, which diminished the antioxidant protective role of the FH protein. As a consequence, the 402H high-risk variant of the FH protein exhibited reduced affinity for oxidized lipids, interfering with the RPE cells' ability to neutralize oxidized lipids. This accumulation contributed to drusen formation, increased oxidative stress, and inflammation, thereby promoting AMD pathology.
title: FH loss in RPE cells causes retinal degeneration in a human RPE-porcine retinal explant co-culture model

finding: In this case, the A allele weakened the donor site of IFI44L exon 2, leading to skipping events that were measured at approximately 15-fold higher in homozygous individuals.
title: Expression changes confirm genomic variants predicted to result in allele-specific, alternative mRNA splicing

finding: The analysis of rs2297550 revealed that the risk allele (G) enhanced binding to the transcription factor Ikaros (IKZF1), modulating the expression of IKBKE. This variant displayed significant effects on IKKε protein levels in both laboratory-created models and cells from genotyped healthy donors, supporting its role as a regulatory element associated with increased risk for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
title: High-throughput identification of functional regulatory SNPs in systemic lupus erythematosus

finding: The SNP rs12123716 was associated with the modulation of cancer cell plasticity and stemness in the context of tumor microenvironment interactions, contributing to the understanding of tumor heterogeneity. This finding was relevant in the exploration of how the tumor microenvironment impacts cancer therapy outcomes.
title: The impact of the spatial heterogeneity of resistant cells and fibroblasts on treatment response

finding: The SNP rs12123556 was linked to the enhancement of competitive suppression in adaptive therapy settings. This finding highlighted the potential of modifying adaptive therapy approaches to improve therapeutic efficacy against resistant cell populations in tumors.
title: The impact of the spatial heterogeneity of resistant cells and fibroblasts on treatment response

finding: The missense variant rs28362263 was prioritised by MGflashfm and MGfm in the context of fine-mapping LDL and TC signals, and it was noted to be only polymorphic in African (AFR) and Hispanic (HIS) populations with a pooled minor allele frequency (MAF) of 0.050. It had not been previously prioritised by the GLGC.
title: Leveraging information between multiple population groups and traits improves fine-mapping resolution

finding: The stop-gain variant rs28362286 was also prioritised by MGflashfm and MGfm but only polymorphic in AFR with a MAF of 0.00798. This variant was not prioritized by the GLGC multi-group analysis but was highlighted in the GLGC AFR analysis.
title: Leveraging information between multiple population groups and traits improves fine-mapping resolution

finding: The missense variant rs11591147 was exclusively present in European (EUR) and Hispanic (HIS) populations and was prioritised by MGflashfm and MGfm. It was the only variant included in the GLGC common set (CS99) for EUR and multi-group analyses, also previously prioritised for LDL, TC, and Apolipoprotein B levels in the UK Biobank.
title: Leveraging information between multiple population groups and traits improves fine-mapping resolution

finding: The SNP rs4561025 was found to be associated with a human-gained brain enhancer located within LINC02609. This enhancer's presence was linked to neuroticism, establishing a significant relationship between this SNP and a specific phenotype related to mental health.
title: Automatic detection of complex structural genome variation across world populations

finding: The SNP rs12092392 was identified as a significant finding in relation to triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) treatment efficacy, as detailed in the study by Gupta et al. in 2020, which discussed current treatment strategies and unmet needs for TNBC therapeutics.
title: Modeling breast cancer by grafting patient tumor samples in the avian embryo: an in vivo platform for therapy evaluation coupled to large scale molecular analyses

finding: The SNP rs12040916 was found to correlate with therapeutic responses in TNBC, as articulated in the study by Vagia et al. in 2020, which provided insights into the landscape of targeted therapies for TNBC.
title: Modeling breast cancer by grafting patient tumor samples in the avian embryo: an in vivo platform for therapy evaluation coupled to large scale molecular analyses

finding: There was a relation established between FCGRIIB rs1050501 and HSV-1 specific IgG antibodies in Alzheimer's disease, indicating its potential link to the disease mechanism.
title: Identification of Key Pathways and Genes in Dementia via Integrated Bioinformatics Analysis

finding: The SNP rs6537837 located in the gene GNAT2 was associated with unipolar depression in humans, achieving genome-wide significance with a p-value of 1e-6. This finding highlighted the potential genetic link between the variants found in the WMI and WLI rat strains and their susceptibility to depression.
title: Whole genome sequencing of nearly isogeneic WMI and WLI inbred rats identifies genes potentially involved in depression

finding: The SNP rs12092547 was found to be positively associated with increased susceptibility to carcinogens, as reported in the study by Ledda and Rapisarda (2020). This finding was significant in the context of occupational and environmental carcinogenesis, highlighting the relevance of genetic variations in the prediction of carcinogenic risk due to exposure to environmental chemicals.
title: Predicting Environmental Chemical Carcinogenicity using a Hybrid Machine-Learning Approach

finding: The rs2814778 SNP, located in the GATA-1 transcription factor binding site of the Duffy blood group protein gene, was found to be associated with individuals possessing the erythrocyte silent (ES) phenotype. While this mutation was historically thought to render individuals homozygous for the negative allele resistant to blood stage infection by Plasmodium vivax, recent findings suggested that the SNP did not completely abolish Fy expression. Studies indicated the presence of variable Fy expression on circulating red blood cells and in erythroid precursor cells even among FY<sup>ES</sup> homozygous individuals, challenging the assumption of Fy-negativity as absolute protection against P. vivax malaria.
title: Duffy Antigen Expression in Erythroid Bone Marrow Precursor Cells of Genotypically Duffy Negative Individuals

finding: The SNP rs12092699 was identified in the context of RNA-binding proteins (RBPs), specifically LARP4A and LARP4B, which were found to be overexpressed in various cancer types, including primary osteosarcoma and prostate cancer, suggesting a link between the SNP and cancer susceptibility. The depletion of these RBPs inhibited tumor growth and metastasis, indicating that this SNP may have implications for cancer progression and therapeutic targets.
title: The RNA binding proteins LARP4A and LARP4B promote sarcoma and carcinoma growth and metastasis

finding: The SNP rs12123812 was linked to widespread expression of embryonic germline genes in tumors. This association supported the evidence of telomere regulation and circadian clock activity in the context of cancer biology, highlighting the connection between embryonic traits and cancer development.
title: Role of the circadian clock ‘Death-Loop’ in the DNA damage response underpinning cancer treatment resistance

finding: Jawak et al. (2019) reported that their work on semiautomated detection and mapping used spatial-spectral characteristics effectively, thereby providing valuable insights into vegetation distribution in the Antarctic environment.
title: Mapping vegetation types in Antarctic Peninsula and South Shetlands islands using Sentinel-2 images and Google Earth Engine cloud computing

finding: The SNP rs1194283 was identified as a significant genetic risk locus for Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) in a genome-wide association study (GWAS) of a shallow MDD measure referred to as GPpsy. This finding was based on a sample size of 332,629 and revealed an odds ratio of 1.05, standard error of 0.0065, and a highly significant p-value of 6.71×10^-13. Additionally, this SNP had previously been associated with MDD in multiple GWAS studies utilizing various phenotyping approaches. Moreover, this locus was also noted for its replicated associations with body mass index and obesity across diverse populations, hinting at a potential metabolic pathway influencing MDD independent of neuroticism.
title: Phenotype integration improves power and preserves specificity in biobank-based genetic studies of MDD

finding: The SNP rs2814778 had been identified as a significant factor impacting absolute neutrophil count (ANC) in African Americans, leading to a consequential low ANC phenotype termed benign ethnic neutropenia (BEN). This finding was contextualized through a case-control study involving over 6,000 African American samples, where the homozygous form of this SNP disrupted a binding site for the GATA1 transcription factor. This disruption had been associated with a low ANC phenotype in African Americans, indicating that genetic variance affects the predisposition to various health outcomes, including the risk of progression from Barrett's esophagus (BE) to esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC).
title: AI-assisted Discovery of an Ethnicity-influenced Driver of Cell Transformation in Esophageal and Gastroesophageal Junction Adenocarcinomas

finding: The SNP rs1876453 was functionally shown to influence the binding affinity of the CCCTC-binding factor (CTCF) to the CR2 gene, indicating that CTCF plays a role in the co-regulation of expression for CR2 and CR1. This SNP was directly linked to the expression changes in neighboring genes within the RCA gene cluster, perturbed B cell autoreactivity, and contributed to susceptibility in the autoimmune disease Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE). Further evidence from linkage analyses and association studies also implicated the CR2 gene in SLE.
title: Regulatory architecture of the RCA gene cluster captures an intragenic TAD boundary, CTCF-mediated chromatin looping and a long-range intergenic enhancer

finding: The lead SNP rs775103516 was associated with pancreatic iron (p-value = 7.2e-13, beta = -0.064), marking a unique finding unlinked to prior traits.
title: Systematic quantification of health parameters from UK Biobank abdominal MRI using deep learning

finding: The SNP rs11249433 was associated with breast cancer through its influence on the expression of the gene NBPF14, identified as a significantly mutated gene in breast cancer. This SNP was also linked to <italic>cis</italic>-QTL for multiple genes associated with cancer, indicating a robust connection to breast cancer risk.
title: Systematic assessment of regulatory effects of human disease variants in pluripotent cells

finding: The SNP rs10779511 in the promoter region of the Hsd11b1 gene was significantly associated with Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) levels. Elevated AST levels in serum have been shown to serve as strong diagnostic markers for excessive alcohol consumption, indicating a useful index for differentiating alcoholic liver disease from nonalcoholic steatohepatitis. Additionally, the down-regulation of Hsd11b1 in the liver of AUD patients was linked to a state of hypercortisolism, which has implications for the associated alcoholic liver disease phenotype.
title: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis on the Transcriptomic Signatures in Alcohol Use Disorder – a Translational Approach

finding: The G allele of NCF2 rs10911362 was associated with protection against tuberculosis (TB) in the Western Chinese Han population. This finding suggested that the downregulation of NCF2 in PMN_HITTIN could be linked to a unique mechanism that lessens reactive oxygen species (ROS) and NET formation, potentially leading to less necrotic cell death.
title: Altered neutrophil extracellular traps in response to Mycobacterium tuberculosis in persons living with HIV with no previous TB and negative TST and IGRA

finding: The rare SNP rs12731181 was identified as being located in the miR-590-3p target site of the Prostaglandin F2α receptor gene. This SNP conferred risk for essential hypertension specifically within the Han Chinese population, illustrating its significance as a genetic risk factor influencing blood pressure regulation.
title: Modeling miRNA-driven post-transcriptional regulation by using exon-intron split analysis (EISA) in pigs

finding: The SNP rs945501 was associated with higher CT in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex in ADHD, reflecting its influence on psychiatric vulnerability related to cortical structure.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: rs3791102 was tied to lower SA of the parietal operculum in ADHD, illustrating its opposing effect on brain morphology.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: The SNP rs7524494 showed associations with greater thickness in the inferior temporal cortex in PTSD, reflecting neuroanatomical influences linked to the disorder.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: The SNP rs2258734 linked to lower SA in the temporal pole for BD, pointing to genetic influences on brain structure.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: The SNP rs3851274 was linked with greater thickness in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex for both ADHD and ASD, highlighting its overlapping effects.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: Connected with lower SA and CT in primary cortices for BD and SCZ, indicating shared genetic underpinnings in psychopathology.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: This SNP showed consistent nocturnal associations with diminishing SA in BD and SCZ, highlighting genetic overlaps.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: Associated with neuronal phenotypes relevant to genetic overlaps in ADHD, amplifying structural inquiries.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: Another significant SNP in ADHD connected to synaptic efficiency reflecting morphological variances.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: The SNP rs12071939 was identified as part of a larger investigation into genomic factors influencing ovarian cancer, revealing its association with tumorigenesis and resistance to therapy. This finding was derived from examining super-enhancers that affect gene expression networks, particularly in the context of ovarian cancer cell lines such as NIH-OVCAR3.
title: A multi-omic dissection of super-enhancer driven oncogenic gene expression programs in ovarian cancer

finding: The SNP rs2228145 was linked to an intermediate-risk subgroup in Multiple Myeloma (MM), specifically defined by elevated levels of soluble interleukin-6 receptor (sIL-6r). This correlation indicated that the incidence of this SNP, in conjunction with 1q21 amplification, was associated with altered clinical outcomes in MM patients.
title: Aberrant BCMA Signaling Promotes Tumor Growth by Altering Protein Translation Machinery, a Therapeutic Target for the Treatment of Relapse/Refractory Multiple Myeloma

finding: The SNP rs12142290 was linked to the evaluation and normalization of topographic effects on vegetation indices, which played a crucial role in accurately assessing remote sensing data for various vegetation types.
title: Hyperspectral imaging for chloroplast movement detection

finding: The lead SNP rs6600247, located about 13kb upstream of the RUNX3 promoter, was found to disrupt a c-MYC binding site. The AS-risk 'C' allele showed significantly lower binding affinity to c-MYC compared to the protective 'T' allele in electrophoretic mobility shift assays (EMSA) and Western blotting-EMSA (WEMSA) experiments. Despite these interactions, rs6600247 showed negligible physical interaction with the RUNX3 promoter, indicating a limited role in regulating RUNX3 expression and highlighting the complexity of regulatory elements in the AS context.
title: Disruption of c-MYC binding and chromosomal looping involving genetic variants associated with ankylosing spondylitis upstream of RUNX3 promoter

finding: The study indicated that the region encompassing rs4648889 demonstrated a strong interaction frequency with the RUNX3 promoter, suggesting its important role in the transcriptional regulation of RUNX3 in contrast to the limited interaction observed for rs6600247. This implies that rs4648889 may be a key regulatory SNP within the RUNX3 locus associated with ankylosing spondylitis.
title: Disruption of c-MYC binding and chromosomal looping involving genetic variants associated with ankylosing spondylitis upstream of RUNX3 promoter

finding: The recessive allele at rs767491614 for TGFB2 showed a protective effect against disease, with an odds ratio (OR) of 0.50, indicating strong protective evidence for the minor deletion allele. This was noted in the context of recessive inheritance models, enhancing understanding of genetic protective factors in disease.
title: Enhanced genetic analysis of type 1 diabetes by selecting variants on both effect size and significance, and by integration with autoimmune thyroid disease

finding: This SNP had the lowest p-value (2.208×10−27) and an odds ratio of 1.97. It was located within the promoter of the gene SLC50A1, which encodes the protein SWEET1, whose complete function was not known.
title: Parkinson’s Disease Genetic Risk Evaluation in Microglia Highlights Autophagy and Lysosomal Genes

finding: The study identified the FcGR3A:rs12087446 eQTL as a significant genetic regulator associated with alcohol dependence (AD), showing consistent patterns of expression across both the nucleus accumbens (NAc) and prefrontal cortex (PFC). This SNP was linked to dysregulation in immune response processes due to chronic alcohol abuse, indicating its role in the immune response associated with addiction-related behaviors.
title: Network Preservation Reveals Shared and Unique Biological Processes Associated with Chronic Alcohol Abuse in NAc and PFC

finding: The DNALI1:rs12119598 eQTL was found to have a significant association with alcohol dependence, specifically exhibiting genetic control localized to the NAc region. This SNP highlighted the brain region-specific genetic influences on cilia organization processes related to alcohol abuse, suggesting a distinct regulatory pathway affecting cellular functions in the NAc.
title: Network Preservation Reveals Shared and Unique Biological Processes Associated with Chronic Alcohol Abuse in NAc and PFC

finding: The SNP rs1061170, associated with complement factor H (CFH), was independently associated with higher drusen burden in eyes with early and intermediate age-related macular degeneration (AMD). This was indicated by significant associations with drusen area and volume in the study results.
title: Association between Drusen Burden Determined by OCT and Genetic Risk in Early and Intermediate Age-Related Macular Degeneration

finding: The SNP rs1410996, also associated with CFH, demonstrated a strong independent association with increased drusen measurements. The presence of this variant contributed to a higher number of risk alleles related to drusen parameters.
title: Association between Drusen Burden Determined by OCT and Genetic Risk in Early and Intermediate Age-Related Macular Degeneration

finding: The findings related to rs12061364 indicated a significant association with melanoma resistance to targeted therapies. This SNP appeared in a study that discussed the role of the fibrotic stroma in the context of melanoma, highlighting how ECM components may influence therapy outcomes.
title: Melanocyte differentiation and mechanosensation are differentially modulated by distinct extracellular matrix proteins

finding: In the study by Cornel et al. (2020), the SNP rs12071760 was associated with MHC Class I downregulation in cancer, highlighting its potential role as a target for cancer immunotherapy.
title: Cell-surface tethered promiscuous biotinylators enable small-scale surface proteomics of human exosomes

finding: The rs76763715 SNP identified as the N409S missense variant in the GBA1 gene was recognized as a significant risk factor for Parkinson's disease (PD). It was reported alongside other top variants in the cohort analyzed.
title: Deep sequencing of proteotoxicity modifier genes uncovers a Presenilin-2/beta-amyloid-actin genetic risk module shared among alpha-synucleinopathies

finding: The rs421016 SNP, which corresponds to the L483P variant of the GBA1 gene, was categorized as an important genetic variant associated with Parkinson's disease (PD). This variant was also listed among the top significant findings.
title: Deep sequencing of proteotoxicity modifier genes uncovers a Presenilin-2/beta-amyloid-actin genetic risk module shared among alpha-synucleinopathies

finding: The SNP rs11209026 in the IL23R gene was previously associated with a higher microbiome diversity and richness, as well as a higher abundance of beneficial gut bacteria in healthy individuals. This suggests a significant influence of the host genetics on the gut microbiome, particularly before the onset of inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD). Furthermore, experimental data indicated that mice lacking intestinal IL23R expression exhibited altered gut microbiota and were more prone to colonic inflammation, reinforcing the role of IL23R in gut microbiome regulation and its connection to IBD development.
title: Kernel-based genetic association analysis for microbiome phenotypes identifies host genetic drivers of beta-diversity

finding: The SNP rs11121949 was identified as a significant marker related to the sirtuin family proteins, which play crucial roles in cancer progression according to research published by Zhao et al. in 2019. This finding highlighted the potential implications of sirtuin gene variants in cancer mechanisms.
title: How many sirtuin genes are out there? evolution of sirtuin genes in vertebrates with a description of a new family member

finding: The SNP rs11121957 was associated with ovarian cancer dissemination as discussed in a cell biologist's perspective article. This finding indicated that the SNP played a role in the cellular mechanisms of ovarian cancer progression, contributing to the understanding of how ovarian cancers proliferate and form outgrowths.
title: Extracellular Matrix Levels Modulate Outgrowths Dynamics in Ovarian Cancer

finding: At a monocyte-specific site, rs10888395 was identified as a caQTL, demonstrating significant effects (π=0.31, q=2.1x10^-4).
title: Mapping genetic effects on cell type-specific chromatin accessibility and annotating complex trait variants using single nucleus ATAC-seq

finding: Variant rs3014874 was identified as a caQTL for classical monocytes with π=0.28 and q=0.008.
title: Mapping genetic effects on cell type-specific chromatin accessibility and annotating complex trait variants using single nucleus ATAC-seq

finding: The SNP rs1173845, also situated in the <italic>CAV1</italic>-AF2 enhancer, was linked to AF associations. Functional analysis indicated its critical role in the aforementioned gene regulation patterns associated with AF.
title: Systematic in vivo interrogation identifies novel enhancers and silencers associated to Atrial Fibrillation

finding: The SNP rs12081314 was positively associated with land change simulation outcomes based on a study by Varga et al. (2020). This finding indicated that genetic variants could influence the accuracy of land change predictions when considering category aggregation in models like CLUE-S.
title: Improving the predictive performance of CLUE-S by extending demand to land transitions: the trans-CLUE-S model

finding: The SNP rs12123605 was associated with the immune escape mechanisms in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), as described by Anichini et al. in their 2020 study. This finding indicated that variations at this locus could influence the tumor immune environment and response to treatments such as pembrolizumab.
title: Selective loss of Y chromosomes in lung adenocarcinoma modulates the tumor immune environment through cancer/testis antigens

finding: The SNP rs12041023 was associated with the regulation of KDM6A, which plays a critical role in the activation of Xist during early differentiation. Impairment in the expression of Xist correlated with knockout experiments that indicated KDM6A's importance in X chromosome inactivation (XCI). The finding highlighted that variations at this SNP could influence KDM6A function and subsequent XCI, thereby impacting X-linked gene expression and potentially female-specific phenotypes.
title: KDM6A facilitates Xist upregulation at the onset of X inactivation

finding: The SNP rs12123669 was linked to the lysosomal entrapment of chemotherapeutics. The study highlighted how this entrapment can affect the efficacy of chemotherapeutic agents, contributing to the challenges in treating ovarian cancer.
title: Chemo-sEVs release in cisplatin-resistance ovarian cancer cells are regulated by the lysosomal function

finding: Identified as part of a group associated with acute myocardial infarction, myocardial infarction, heart attack, major coronary heart disease, coronary atherosclerosis, and ischemic heart disease, all showing high genetic correlations.
title: A method to map and interpret pleiotropic loci using summary statistics of multiple traits

finding: The SNP rs12123526 was found to influence visfatin levels, thereby enhancing breast cancer progression via tumor-associated macrophages. This indicated that genetic variations at this locus could affect immune signaling in the tumor microenvironment.
title: Single-cell analysis reveals diversity of tumor-associated macrophages and their interactions with T lymphocytes in glioblastoma

finding: The SNP rs12071817 was associated with emerging molecular diagnostic and prognostic features in adult diffuse gliomas according to the research by Mirchia and Richardson (2020). This research indicated that specific genotypic variations may play a crucial role in understanding the complexity and prognosis of gliomas, especially considering the age-related genomic alterations identified in the broader context of age-associated differences in tumor characteristics.
title: An Integrative Analysis of the Age-Associated Genomic, Transcriptomic and Epigenetic Landscape across Cancers

finding: The SNP rs12123869 was associated with patient-specific responses in breast cancer organoids when modeled in a study by Campaner et al. (2020). This finding indicated how genetic variants influenced reactions to drug treatments in breast cancer, shedding light on the personalized aspects of breast cancer therapy.
title: Single-cell transcription mapping of murine and human mammary organoids responses to female hormones

finding: The SNP rs12123799 was associated with breast cancer development. Specifically, its analysis was included in a study that integrated transcriptomic data with microRNA information, highlighting its role in subtype classification and survival probability in breast cancer patients.
title: Multi-omics Topic Modeling for Breast Cancer Classification

finding: The common coding variant rs267738 in the CERS2 gene was found to be significantly associated with retinal detachment (RRD) in the original genetic analysis with an increasing risk indicated by the major T allele.
title: Insight into the genetic aetiology of retinal detachment by combining small clinical and large population-based datasets

finding: This rs6682581 variant showed strong evidence as a significant lead SNP within ZC3H11B, indicating its role in retinal detachment pathogenesis.
title: Insight into the genetic aetiology of retinal detachment by combining small clinical and large population-based datasets

finding: The SNP rs12123506 was identified in research related to breast cancer subtyping. It contributed to an improved, assay platform agnostic classifier for determining breast cancer subtypes, which was crucial for inferring tumor aggressiveness and predicting patient prognosis. This finding underscored the importance of integrating genetic analysis in the clinical diagnostic framework for cancer.
title: Building flexible and robust analysis frameworks for molecular subtyping of cancers

finding: The SNP rs5082 in the gene APOA2 showed a significant positive association with body mass index (BMI) in three independent cohorts of European and Hispanic individuals with high saturated fat intake (>22g/d). This finding was particularly relevant because it indicated the effect of dietary context on genetic predisposition to obesity.
title: GEGenetic regulatory effects in response to a high cholesterol, high fat diet in baboons

finding: The variant rs371095992 was noted to change the amino acid from cysteine to tryptophan in the TSP-1 domain of the HMCN1 gene. This change was predicted to influence the interaction with the mature form of transforming growth factor beta (TGF-β), suggesting a potential pathogenic role in pulmonary fibrosis (PF). This finding was supported by a combined presence of 74 participants with rare missense variants in HMCN1 across the PROFILE and GE100KGP study cohorts.
title: Genetic burden of dysregulated cytoskeletal organisation in the pathogenesis of pulmonary fibrosis

finding: The SNP rs324420, a missense variant in the FAAH gene, was significantly associated with four N-acyl ethanolamines (DHEA, PEA, LEA, VEA) at GWAS significance level (P<5×10^-8). A carriers of the AA genotype exhibited a 22% increase in mean plasma concentration of PEA compared to CC genotype carriers, highlighting its substantial impact on NAE levels.
title: Heritability and family-based GWAS analyses of the N-acyl ethanolamine and ceramide lipidome reveal genetic influence over circulating lipids

finding: The SNP rs4653568 associated with the ratio of CER[N(24)S(19)] to CER[N(24)DS(19)], showing strong genetic influence on the balance between different ceramide species and their relation to blood phenotypes.
title: Heritability and family-based GWAS analyses of the N-acyl ethanolamine and ceramide lipidome reveal genetic influence over circulating lipids

finding: The SNP rs12411216 was associated with occipital volumes, as reported in a GWAS study. This locus was located in an intron of the MIR92B and THBS3 genes and showed a significant peak covering more than 20 genes, with promoter histone marks overlapping the variant. This finding indicated a potential link between the genetic locus and posterior atrophy related to visuospatial impairments in Alzheimer's disease.
title: Differential Brain Atrophy Patterns and Neurogenetic Profiles in Cognitively-Defined Alzheimer’s Disease Subgroups

finding: This SNP had strand orientation corrected in the published genotypes, indicating that the originally reported genotype may not have accurately reflected its true sequence context.
title: The FORCE panel: An all-in-one SNP marker set for confirming investigative genetic genealogy leads and for general forensic applications

finding: The NLRP3 gain-of-function variant rs10754558 was associated with significantly increased MMP-9 release in carriers. This variant's effects suggested a correlation with increased IL-1β and NET release, highlighting its role in NLRP3 inflammasome activity.
title: BTK and MMP9 regulate NLRP3 inflammasome-dependent cytokine and NET responses in primary neutrophils

finding: In this study, rs2027349 was identified as the most significant ASoC SNP at the VPS45 locus. Editing this SNP altered the expression of VPS45, the lncRNA AC244033.2, and the distal gene C1orf54 in human neurons. The presence of the risk allele A was associated with increased dendritic complexity, synaptic puncta density, and hyperactivity in neurons, which were reversible upon knockdown of VPS45, AC244033.2, or C1orf54. This SNP showed correlations with synaptic development and gene expression changes linked with schizophrenia (SZ) risk.
title: Multiple genes in cis mediate the effects of a single chromatin accessibility variant on aberrant synaptic development and function in human neurons

finding: Previously noted but not genome-wide significant, this SNP was re-evaluated and found to support selection narratives in the population.
title: Scalable probabilistic PCA for large-scale genetic variation data

finding: Recognized for its potential role in selection, this SNP indicated new insights into genetic diversity among the sampled populations.
title: Scalable probabilistic PCA for large-scale genetic variation data

finding: The rs6025 SNP, located in the F5 gene, showed genome-wide significance across stroke, intracerebral hemorrhage, and ischemic stroke subtypes. It was recognized as a key finding related to thrombotic events.
title: Medical data and machine learning improve power of stroke genome-wide association studies

finding: This SNP, which is near the F5 gene, demonstrated genome-wide significance specifically in ischemic stroke. It highlights the role of this region in stroke pathology and familial thrombosis.
title: Medical data and machine learning improve power of stroke genome-wide association studies

finding: The SNP rs12071887 was associated with the tumor-promoting capabilities of Cancer Associated Fibroblasts (CAFs) in prostate cancer (PCa). The original finding indicated a correlation between this SNP and increased tumor load in patients, suggesting that this genetic variant may influence individual susceptibility to PCa through its effect on the microenvironment.
title: Exploring the onset and progression of prostate cancer through a multicellular agent-based model

finding: The SNP rs12071780 was linked to altered calcium signaling in cancer cells, particularly within the context of mechanosensitive Piezo channels. This study established that changes in calcium dynamics played a pivotal role in tumor progression, highlighting the importance of this SNP in modifying cellular responses related to cancer behavior.
title: Endothelial calcium firing mediates extravasation of metastatic tumor cells

finding: The SNP rs11264305 was associated with IBD susceptibility and identified in a meta-analysis of DNA methylation data. It contributed to a methylation quantitative trait locus (mQTL), indicating a relationship between its genetic variant and abnormal DNA methylation patterns in intestinal epithelial cells.
title: The DNA Methylome of Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) reflects intrinsic and extrinsic factors in intestinal epithelial cells

finding: The SNP rs3806308 was reported as an IBD-associated polymorphism during the analysis of mQTLs, underscoring its potential role in influencing DNA methylation changes and hence, contributing to inflammatory processes in IBD.
title: The DNA Methylome of Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) reflects intrinsic and extrinsic factors in intestinal epithelial cells

finding: The SNP rs2476601 (R620W) in the PTPN22 gene was associated with a significantly increased risk for various autoimmune diseases, including type 1 diabetes, systemic lupus erythematosus, and rheumatoid arthritis. Specifically, possessing the PTPN22 risk variant nearly doubled a carrier's risk for these conditions. The findings indicated that this variant contributed to enhanced TCR signaling in mildly self-reactive T cells, which facilitated increased T cell proliferation and resulted in a Th1 skewing, establishing a context for why this SNP is considered one of the strongest non-HLA genetic risk factors for autoimmunity.
title: PTPN22 R620W Gene Editing in T Cells Enhances Low Avidity TCR Responses

finding: The variant rs2269247 was identified at the PGM1 locus and was part of the T2D-associated 99% credible set. It was noted to overlap with transcription factor binding sites, indicating its involvement in gene regulatory mechanisms linked to the pathology of T2D.
title: Pancreatic progenitor epigenome maps prioritize type 2 diabetes risk genes with roles in development

finding: The variant rs2301055 was confirmed as being within the PGM1 locus and part of the T2D-related 99% credible set, intersecting with transcription factor binding sites, suggesting its potential role in modulating T2D risk through regulatory interactions.
title: Pancreatic progenitor epigenome maps prioritize type 2 diabetes risk genes with roles in development

finding: The variant rs2301054 was noted in the context of the PGM1 locus as a T2D-associated variant within the trusted 99% credible set, showing overlap with several transcription factor binding regions, reinforcing its relevance to T2D pathogenesis.
title: Pancreatic progenitor epigenome maps prioritize type 2 diabetes risk genes with roles in development

finding: The variant rs2269246 was part of the PGM1 locus and showed inclusion in the T2D-associated 99% credible set, overlapping with transcription factors binding sites, indicating its likely contribution to the regulatory mechanisms influencing T2D risk.
title: Pancreatic progenitor epigenome maps prioritize type 2 diabetes risk genes with roles in development

finding: The SNP rs12030569 was associated with ATF4-dependent Nrf2 transcriptional regulation, which promotes antioxidant protection during endoplasmic reticulum stress. This finding related to the broader context of how sulfur amino acid restriction, particularly cysteine restriction, induced molecular changes that were linked to serinogenesis and metabolic conditions such as hypertriglyceridemia.
title: Cysteine Restriction-Specific Effects of Sulfur Amino Acid Restriction on Lipid Metabolism

finding: The SNP rs61816761, identified as a common FLG protein-truncating variant, was found to be significantly associated with asthma, particularly early-onset asthma, showing an odds ratio of 1.20 (p=2.3×10^-18). This context highlighted its relevance in asthma susceptibility.
title: A broad exome study of the genetic architecture of asthma reveals novel patient subgroups

finding: The SNP rs12123742 was identified in the context of acute myeloid leukemia (AML), specifically concerning the unique characteristics of leukemic stem cells (LSCs). The study highlighted the challenge of understanding the phenotypic heterogeneity among LSCs and how this variability can affect disease progression and treatment response. This SNP was associated with distinct subsets of LSCs that demonstrated different self-renewal and differentiation capabilities, emphasizing the importance of this genetic variant in AML pathology.
title: A primary patient-derived model for investigating functional heterogeneity within the human Leukemic Stem Cell Compartment
