finding: The analysis revealed that the alternative allele (G) for SNP rs11205653 was associated with a loss of enhancer activity in human islet samples. Specifically, CoRE-ATAC predicted lower enhancer probabilities for individuals with the alternative allele compared to those with the reference allele (TT). This prediction was corroborated by massively parallel reporter assays (MPRA), which indicated that samples possessing the alternative allele displayed reduced enhancer activity. This finding highlighted not only the genetic modulation of regulatory function at this locus but also underscored CoRE-ATAC's competence in identifying variations in cis-regulatory element activity that correlate with genetic differences.
title: CoRE-ATAC: A deep learning model for the functional classification of regulatory elements from single cell and bulk ATAC-seq data

finding: The SNP rs6667242 was associated with a high ALP level and low serum P level, suggesting its role in increasing nephrolithiasis risk by hydrating and reducing pyrophosphate, thereby inhibiting CaOX and CaP crystallization.
title: GWAS identifies nine nephrolithiasis susceptibility loci related with metabolic metabolic and crystallization pathways

finding: Associated with ALPL, rs1106357 was furthermore linked to nephrolithiasis and serum ALP levels.
title: GWAS identifies nine nephrolithiasis susceptibility loci related with metabolic metabolic and crystallization pathways

finding: rs535411 was associated with heart failure in GWAS and tracked closely in linkage disequilibrium with rs12724121, hinting at a synthetic association relevant to cardiac traits.
title: Fine mapping spatiotemporal mechanisms of genetic variants underlying cardiac traits and disease

finding: The rs1061170 SNP located in the CFH gene, which causes the Y402H polymorphism in the complement factor H protein, was identified as a significant genetic risk variant for age-related macular degeneration (AMD). This variant contributed to AMD progression primarily through uncontrolled activation of the complement system in the extracellular matrix. Additionally, it was associated with pronounced metabolic disturbances in retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) cells and increased inflammatory signaling via the NF-kB pathway, reflecting the variant's profound impact on cellular energy metabolism.
title: mTOR inhibition via Rapamycin treatment partially reverts the deficit in energy metabolism caused by FH loss in RPE cells

finding: This SNP was associated with waist-hip ratio adjusted for body mass index (WHR_adjBMI) in a large meta-analysis involving 476,546 individuals, showing a highly significant association with a p-value of 2 x 10^-14. It was also found to significantly impact estimated bone mineral density (eBMD), marking it as a causal variant influencing both obesity and osteoporosis.
title: Osteoporosis- and obesity-risk interrelationships: An epigenetic analysis of GWAS-derived SNPs at the developmental gene TBX15

finding: This missense variant was strongly associated with WHR_adjBMI with a very significant p-value of 3 x 10^-21 in the same meta-analysis. Although not directly linked to eBMD, it was indirectly implicated through its association with adult height, suggesting its relevance in bone biology.
title: Osteoporosis- and obesity-risk interrelationships: An epigenetic analysis of GWAS-derived SNPs at the developmental gene TBX15

finding: This SNP was identified as a Tier-1 SNP for both obesity traits and eBMD, located in a promoter region that exhibits strong enhancer chromatin characteristics. It was found in high linkage disequilibrium (LD) with other significant SNPs and was involved in regulatory mechanisms influencing transcription factors relevant to bone health.
title: Osteoporosis- and obesity-risk interrelationships: An epigenetic analysis of GWAS-derived SNPs at the developmental gene TBX15

finding: As a categorized Tier-1 SNP, rs984222 was associated with increased expression of TBX15 in subcutaneous adipose tissue (SAT). Its trait-increasing alternative allele demonstrated significant positive correlation with obesity traits, thereby indicating its role as a causal variant affecting both obesity and eBMD.
title: Osteoporosis- and obesity-risk interrelationships: An epigenetic analysis of GWAS-derived SNPs at the developmental gene TBX15

finding: This SNP was identified as a Tier-1 SNP strongly associated with both obesity and eBMD. It overlaps with significant transcription factor binding sites implicated in adipose and bone biology, reinforcing its potential role in the regulatory network affecting these traits.
title: Osteoporosis- and obesity-risk interrelationships: An epigenetic analysis of GWAS-derived SNPs at the developmental gene TBX15

finding: Identified as a Tier-1 SNP, it exhibited enhancer chromatin features and was predicted to bind specific transcription factors associated with adipose biology. Its location and characteristics indicated its contribution to obesity-related genetic risk.
title: Osteoporosis- and obesity-risk interrelationships: An epigenetic analysis of GWAS-derived SNPs at the developmental gene TBX15

finding: This SNP was clustered with others in a strong enhancer chromatin region and was associated with obesity traits. Strong predictions for allele-specific transcription factor binding further highlighted its significance in the regulation of TBX15 expression.
title: Osteoporosis- and obesity-risk interrelationships: An epigenetic analysis of GWAS-derived SNPs at the developmental gene TBX15

finding: This SNP was located within a regulatory region advancing the expression of TBX15, and it showed close association with obesity and eBMD. Its role was suggested to be regulatory, impacting transcription factors that control bone biology.
title: Osteoporosis- and obesity-risk interrelationships: An epigenetic analysis of GWAS-derived SNPs at the developmental gene TBX15

finding: As part of the clustered Tier-1 SNPs, it was associated with obesity traits and displayed allele-specific transcription factor binding predictions, indicating its regulatory role in the context of TBX15 expression and related phenotypes.
title: Osteoporosis- and obesity-risk interrelationships: An epigenetic analysis of GWAS-derived SNPs at the developmental gene TBX15

finding: SNP rs13376333 was associated with several mitochondrial enzyme genes (NDUFA9/NDUFB3/ADK), identified as a trans pQTL connected to metabolic processes involved in AF.
title: Tissue-specific multiOMICs analysis of atrial fibrillation

finding: The SNP rs6666258 was categorized as a trans pQTL affecting ACOT9, which is related to metabolism, linking it to pathways involved in atrial fibrillation.
title: Tissue-specific multiOMICs analysis of atrial fibrillation

finding: The SNP rs12123540 was linked to the inhibition of Serum Response Factor (SRF) and demonstrated its role in improving response to enzalutamide in prostate cancer (PCa) patients. Elevated levels of SRF were associated with disease progression and resistance, thereby establishing a direct connection between this SNP and PCA treatment outcomes.
title: Identification of druggable targets from the interactome of the Androgen Receptor and Serum Response Factor pathways in prostate cancer

finding: This SNP's impact on transcription factor interactions was noted as potentially significant in the context of Treg biology.
title: 3DFAACTS-SNP: Using regulatory T cell-specific epigenomics data to uncover candidate mechanisms of Type-1 Diabetes (T1D) risk

finding: The rs1136410 SNP was associated with the V762A PARP1 variant, which had strong associations with lung cancer, ovarian cancer, and other neoplastic diseases. Experimental findings indicated that this mutation resulted in the overactivation of PARP1, compromising its DNA repair capabilities.
title: Impact of a Cancer-Associated Mutation on Poly(ADP-ribose) Polymerase1 Inhibition

finding: The SNP rs12071991 was identified in a study that demonstrated it was involved in sensitizing enzalutamide-resistant prostate cancer to ionizing radiation. This was observed in prostate cancer cells that expressed androgen receptor splice variants, thereby linking the SNP to improved therapeutic responses in a specific cancer setting.
title: Androgen receptor condensates as drug targets

finding: rs3091244 was identified as genome-wide significant in only the European ancestry cohort for its influence on C-reactive protein levels. It was functionally validated and had clinical implications for atrial fibrillation and lupus erythematosus.
title: Redefining replication in multi-ancestry genome-wide association studies

finding: The SNP rs3936018 was identified as influencing forehead morphology. It was located in the promoter region of the WARS2 gene and was confirmed to affect forehead prominence, consistent with previous findings.
title: Insights into the genetic architecture of the human face

finding: The SNP rs12027501 was found to impact cheek morphology, specifically in segment 48 related to the cheeks. It was identified as having a distinct linkage disequilibrium cluster overlapping with rs3936018.
title: Insights into the genetic architecture of the human face

finding: The SNP rs7513680 was associated with morphology in segment 51, relating to the lower area of the cheek at the corners of the mouth, demonstrating multiple phenotypic implications within the same genomic region.
title: Insights into the genetic architecture of the human face

finding: The SNP rs17023457 was observed approximately 301 kb downstream of the WARS2 gene, impacting similar regions as rs7513680, indicating a shared influence on facial morphology despite being distantly located.
title: Insights into the genetic architecture of the human face

finding: The SNP rs76244841, associated with PRDM16, was found to interact with rs62443772 in facial segment 9, affecting the premaxillary soft tissue and suggesting that the combined effect of these SNPs impacted facial morphology through epistatic interactions.
title: Insights into the genetic architecture of the human face

finding: The SNP rs1572037 demonstrated associations with three different traits in facial segments, indicating its influence across multiple areas of the face, thereby supporting the polygenic nature of facial morphology.
title: Insights into the genetic architecture of the human face

finding: The SNP rs11121859 was linked to ATP-dependent chromatin remodeling complexes which play a significant role in pancreatic cancer. This association highlighted the impact of chromatin remodeling on drug sensitivity and resistance in cancer treatment.
title: Multi-omic analysis of HDAC1 function in pancreatic cancer reveals altered GTPase activity impacting chemoresistance

finding: The SNP rs12042284 was mapped to the AIM2 gene, which has been reported to be associated with C-reactive protein levels. This association indicates a potential role of this SNP in modulating immune responses relevant to tuberculosis.
title: Major Contribution of Myeloid Cells In TB specific Host Gene Signature: Revelations from Re-Analysis of Publicly Available Datasets

finding: SNP rs2518564 was associated with white blood cell count and was mapped to the AIM2 gene. This association may have implications for immune responses in tuberculosis.
title: Major Contribution of Myeloid Cells In TB specific Host Gene Signature: Revelations from Re-Analysis of Publicly Available Datasets

finding: The SNP rs2276405, which was associated with psoriasis and mapped to AIM2, suggests possible connections between autoimmune traits and tuberculosis susceptibility.
title: Major Contribution of Myeloid Cells In TB specific Host Gene Signature: Revelations from Re-Analysis of Publicly Available Datasets

finding: The rs1873311 SNP, located in the first intron of the human p11 gene, was associated with a decreased risk of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA) in a cohort of stem cell transplant recipients. Genotype analysis revealed a cumulative incidence of IPA of 25.6% for T/T and 17.4% for T/C genotypes (p = 0.041). In a multivariate model, the T/C genotype presented an adjusted hazard ratio of 0.86, indicating decreased susceptibility to IPA. Additionally, this SNP was found to affect the expression of p11, disrupting inducibility by the pathogenic fungus <italic>A. fumigatus</italic>.
title: Re-direction of phagosomes to the recycling expulsion pathway by a fungal pathogen

finding: The SNP rs75459873 was found to be an intronic variant in the cannabinoid receptor 2 gene (CNR2), associated specifically with distressing psychotic experiences. It showed an odds ratio (OR) of 0.66 and a p-value of 3.78 x 10^-8, indicating a reduction in the likelihood of these experiences among carriers of this variant.
title: Genetic association study of psychotic experiences in UK Biobank

finding: The rs116133558 SNP, associated with <italic>ATP2B4</italic>, was linked to both average SpO<sub>2</sub> levels and Per90 in Hispanic Americans, with a combined p-value for Per90 noted as 3.51 × 10<sup>−10</sup>. This gene is crucial in regulating calcium transport in erythrocytes.
title: Whole-Genome Association Analyses of Sleep-disordered Breathing Phenotypes in the NHLBI TOPMed Program

finding: SNP rs1333973 was linked with immune responses to vaccines, particularly with neutralizing antibody titers.
title: Integrated single-cell transcriptomics and epigenomics reveals strong germinal center-associated etiology of autoimmune risk loci

finding: This SNP also linked to immune responses, was previously studied in the context of type I interferon-responding B cells, suggesting its contribution to autoimmunity.
title: Integrated single-cell transcriptomics and epigenomics reveals strong germinal center-associated etiology of autoimmune risk loci

finding: The SNP rs10789442 found at the ST3GAL3 locus was consistently associated with ADHD risk across the studied datasets, further identifying ST3GAL3 as a candidate gene relevant to ADHD.
title: Intellectual Disability-related genes increase ADHD risk and locomotor activity in Drosophila

finding: MTHFR rs1801131 was part of two common polymorphisms that affect enzyme activity associated with homocysteine levels. The likelihood of null effect compared to the wild-type genotype (1298AA/677CC) was high, with at least 81-95% for common genotypes. The linear regression analysis indicated that only around 1% of the homocysteine variability was explained by MTHFR genotype combinations, and even with the addition of less frequent alleles, this increased only slightly to about 7%.
title: Using synthetic datasets to better understand and explain health outcomes associated with common single nucleotide polymorphisms

finding: MTHFR rs1801133, when analyzed with rs1801131, showed similar trends in enzyme variance and homocysteine levels. Across these combinations, it was noted only 1% of homocysteine variability was accounted for by MTHFR activity. The presence of 677TT/1298AA resulted in 6.9% of synthetic predicted homocysteine levels being negative, highlighting non-linear associations in this SNP's impact.
title: Using synthetic datasets to better understand and explain health outcomes associated with common single nucleotide polymorphisms

finding: The C allele of rs4245739 was previously predicted to preferentially bind hsa-miR-191-5p, indicating a potential role in ovarian cancer, and was also supported by differential allelic miRNA binding predictions.
title: Allele-specific miRNA-binding analysis identifies candidate target genes for breast cancer risk

finding: The rs17354678 variant was associated with the 3'UTR of the RNF115 gene. The reference allele was predicted to decrease binding of hsa-miR-6842-5p, consistent with higher expression of RNF115 in normal breast tissue, reinforcing its potential oncogenic role in breast cancer.
title: Allele-specific miRNA-binding analysis identifies candidate target genes for breast cancer risk

finding: The VAMP4 rs11578699 variant was found to be nominally associated with AAO in idiopathic PD patients carrying the common LRRK2 risk variant rs10878226. Specifically, it was reported that patients with the TT genotype had a hazard ratio of 0.86 compared to those with the CC and TC genotypes (HR = 0.86, p = 0.023), indicating a potential modifying effect of this SNP on disease onset.
title: Analysis of DNM3 and VAMP4 as genetic modifiers of LRRK2 Parkinson’s disease

finding: The SNP rs2814778 demonstrated a strong association with granulocyte proportions, with a beta value of -1.24 (P=1.93×10^−83). This SNP is located in the 5' UTR of the ACKR1 gene on chromosome 1.
title: Genome-wide association studies identify 137 loci for DNA methylation biomarkers of ageing

finding: The SNP rs2275558 exhibited associations with various trait outcomes, including cancers and blood cell counts. This SNP was also associated with IEAA, confirming its relevance.
title: Genome-wide association studies identify 137 loci for DNA methylation biomarkers of ageing

finding: The SNP rs549845 located on chromosome 1 was associated with the ADHD+DBDs phenotype, demonstrating a genome-wide significant association with a P-value of 2.38×10^-8 and an OR of 1.16. This finding indicated a potential risk factor for individuals diagnosed with both ADHD and DBDs.
title: Identification of risk variants and characterization of the polygenic architecture of disruptive behavior disorders in the context of ADHD

finding: In the study mentioned by Gnanasekaran et al. (2020), the SNP rs12082331 was associated with the tumoral behavior of pancreatic carcinoma cells, indicating that genetic variations at this locus could have implications in the tumorigenesis process modulated by the pathogen <italic>Porphyromonas gingivalis</italic>. This suggests a potential role of inflammation and oxidative stress, associated with gingipains from <italic>P. gingivalis</italic>, in altering cellular pathways relevant to cancer progression.
title: Dysregulation of stress-induced translational control by Porphyromonas gingivalis in host cells

finding: The SNP rs12123586 was linked to the immunomodulatory effects of interleukin-2 (IL-2) and interleukin-15 (IL-15) based on the findings presented in Yang and Lundqvist's 2020 study. This SNP was relevant to cancer immunotherapy, particularly in relation to enhancing the efficacy of protein drug delivery for treating cancers like melanoma and renal cell carcinoma, as indicated by the successful use of PODS containing IL-2 in mouse models.
title: Low-dose cytokine immunotherapy of solid cancers enabled by phagocytic-competent protein co-crystals

finding: The SNP rs12082154 was associated with the emergence of therapy-resistant, invasive melanoma phenotypes, demonstrating the role of EMT-inducing transcription factors in melanoma phenotype switching. This was critical to understanding resistance to treatment.
title: p300 KAT regulates SOX10 stability and function in human melanoma

finding: The SNP rs6679677 displayed a strongly protective effect with a positive Beta value in relation to age of melanoma diagnosis.
title: Autoimmune Alleles at the Major Histocompatibility Locus Modify Melanoma Susceptibility

finding: The rs11261022 variant was identified as a likely causal regulatory variant impacting the estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) through changes in KLHDC7A expression. It was noted that this variant is located within an open-chromatin peak in kidney samples, demonstrating the importance of quality samples in identifying regulatory elements.
title: Quality assessment and refinement of chromatin accessibility data using a sequence-based predictive model

finding: The SNP rs11573156 was strongly associated with circulating levels of sPLA2-IIA, with studies indicating that individuals with the homozygous alternative allele (CC) exhibited a 57% to 62% increase in sPLA2-IIA levels compared to those with the homozygous reference (GG) genotype. This SNP, located in the 5' untranslated region of the PLA2G2A gene, affected transcription through SP1 binding affinity differences, thereby modulating PLA2G2A expression primarily in liver tissues where SP1 levels were impacted. The findings underscored the role of this SNP in influencing disease conditions related to sPLA2-IIA levels.
title: Identification of an allele-specific transcription factor binding interaction that regulates PLA2G2A gene expression

finding: The SNP rs3820282 was associated with multiple human female reproductive traits, including increased likelihood of endometriosis and ovarian epithelial cancer, as well as longer gestation periods. This SNP was found to introduce a high-affinity estrogen receptor 1 binding site at the Wnt4 locus, which caused upregulation of Wnt4 in endometrial stromal cells during the proestrus phase of the ovarian cycle.
title: A SNP affects Wnt4 expression in endometrial stroma, with antagonistic implications for pregnancy, endometriosis and reproductive cancers

finding: The SNP rs149700491 was found to be associated with plasma LDL-cholesterol levels in humans based on GWAS data from the GLGC dataset. This SNP had relevance in lipid biogenesis and distribution, emphasizing its role in metabolic processes.
title: CLCC1 Governs Bilayer Equilibration at the Endoplasmic Reticulum to Maintain Cellular and Systemic Lipid Homeostasis

finding: The SNP rs77134701 was associated with decreased expression of the CLCC1 gene in human skeletal muscles, with a p-value of 1.57E-2. This finding highlighted the SNP's significance in the context of lipid metabolism and muscle function.
title: CLCC1 Governs Bilayer Equilibration at the Endoplasmic Reticulum to Maintain Cellular and Systemic Lipid Homeostasis

finding: The SNP rs72704264 was identified as a risk factor for hypertension and showed high linkage with the chromosome subpopulations. This SNP's association was likely functional based on its linkage with differential recombination histories.
title: Historical recombination variability contributes to deciphering the genetic basis of phenotypic traits

finding: The SNP rs10910843, recognized as an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) for the gene ANKRD35 in blood, was found to be in high linkage with the chromosome subpopulations, connecting it to the differential expression of ANKRD35.
title: Historical recombination variability contributes to deciphering the genetic basis of phenotypic traits

finding: This SNP resulted in C1483R mutation in mTOR, associated with breast neoplasm and glioblastoma.
title: Predicting functionally important breast cancer SNPs using pleiotropy, conservation, and protein structure

finding: The SNP rs12041050 was linked to the modulation of DNA damage and repair mechanisms in cancer, which was highlighted in research focusing on DNA Damage/Repair Management in Cancers published in 2020. This finding suggested that variations at this locus may influence individual responses to radiation exposure and the efficiency of DNA repair processes.
title: DeepFoci: Deep Learning-Based Algorithm for Fast Automatic Analysis of DNA Double Strand Break Ionizing Radiation-Induced Foci

finding: The SNP rs11121877 was associated with cellular responses to DNA damage, as discussed in a 2019 study that examined clustered DNA damage in leukocytes after radiation treatment. This indicated that genetic variations at this locus might affect how cells handle DNA lesions resulting from radiation exposure, with implications for understanding susceptibility to cancer.
title: DeepFoci: Deep Learning-Based Algorithm for Fast Automatic Analysis of DNA Double Strand Break Ionizing Radiation-Induced Foci

finding: The SNP rs111402007-A was found to be associated with inflammation in esophagus mucosa (β = 0.53, P-value = 7.64 × 10-7). It had also been previously linked to an increased White Blood Cell Count (β = 0.023, P-value = 5.8 × 10-7), aligning with the known connection between low-grade systemic inflammation in obesity and WBC count.
title: Self-supervised learning for characterising histomorphological diversity and spatial RNA expression prediction across 23 human tissue types

finding: The SNP rs348195 tags the esv3587631 deletion, overlapping with the DAP3 gene, resulting in significant associations with gene expression and white blood cell levels, suggesting adaptive relevance.
title: Network-based analysis of allele frequency distribution among multiple populations identifies adaptive genomic structural variants

finding: The rare genotyped stop codon Arg200Ter (rs139321832) in MARC1 was associated with lower total and LDL cholesterol levels, indicating a protective effect against elevated cholesterol levels and liver enzyme levels, which could relate to liver disease risk.
title: A missense variant in Mitochondrial Amidoxime Reducing Component 1 gene and protection against liver disease

finding: The SNP rs12082046 was discussed in the context of a pan-cancer analysis of genomic alterations. Izzi et al. (2020) highlighted the significance of matrisome mutations across various cancers, which implied that this SNP could be related to changes in the extracellular matrix affecting tumor biology and patient outcomes.
title: Histopathology-assisted proteogenomics provides foundations for stratification of melanoma metastases

finding: The SNP rs12082107 was associated with the modulation of the tumor microenvironment, particularly in the context of lung adenocarcinoma. It was noted that the secretome generated from adipose tissue-derived mesenchymal stem cells (AMSC) of patients with lung adenocarcinoma shared similarities with the malignant microenvironment derived from autologous lung stromal cells (LMSC). This interplay involved upregulation of factors linked to inflammation and fibrosis, suggesting that genetic influence at this SNP level potentially contributed to the disease progression in lung cancer.
title: “Remote adipose tissue-derived stromal cells of patients with lung adenocarcinoma generate a similar malignant microenvironment of the lung stromal counterpart”

finding: The SNP rs12061558 was associated with the activation of oncogenic signaling pathways in glioblastoma (GBM) contexts. Specifically, it might have influenced the response of cancer stem cells (CSCs) to external stimuli such as astrocytic differentiation and biochemical treatments like temozolomide (TMZ). This finding was crucial in illustrating how the genomic diversity among GBM tumors affected cellular responses and treatment sensitivities.
title: Impact of genomic background and developmental state on signaling pathways and response to therapy in glioblastoma patient-derived cells

finding: rs4593766 was significantly associated with ADHD and MDD (p=4.9×10⁻¹²). It was located in a non-coding region and showed associations with mental health disorders such as anxiety and schizophrenia, indicating its potential role in the genetic correlation between these traits.
title: Investigating regions of shared genetic variation in attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder and major depressive disorder: A GWAS meta-analysis

finding: The SNP rs11804091 was identified as obesity-associated and was found to be in linkage disequilibrium with other obesity-associated variants at the Lepr locus. This SNP was specifically linked to traits of Body Mass Index (BMI) and insulin resistance in a study of obese Spanish female children.
title: Genomic and epigenomic mapping of leptin-responsive neuronal populations involved in body weight regulation

finding: Situated in the INPP5B/FHL3 locus, this SNP exhibited conditional dependency in enhancer activity, with validation through CRISPR demonstrating its influence on nearby gene expression in proliferative SMCs.
title: Comprehensive identification of coronary artery disease-associated variants regulating vascular smooth muscle cell gene expression

finding: The rs72938038 variant within the BACH2 locus was identified as a candidate causal variant for type 1 diabetes (T1D). The T1D risk allele A was associated with decreased enhancer accessibility and reduced expression of BACH2 in naÃ¯ve CD4+ T cells, indicating that this variant might disrupt transcription factor binding, specifically affecting the regulation of BACH2.
title: Fine-mapping, trans-ancestral and genomic analyses identify causal variants, cells, genes and drug targets for type 1 diabetes

finding: The lead variant rs2229238 near the IL6R gene was associated with T1D, representing a novel finding at genome-wide significance. Although this variant was directly genotyped, the biological role of the associated risk variant differs from the nonsynonymous variant rs2228145 that was thought to drive associations in rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
title: Fine-mapping, trans-ancestral and genomic analyses identify causal variants, cells, genes and drug targets for type 1 diabetes

finding: The c.1801C>T variant in the PDE4DIP gene was frequently observed in heterozygous state and was noted to be associated with extreme heterozygote excess in previous databases, indicating its relevance in the context of genotype errors.
title: Hardy-Weinberg Equilibrium in the Large Scale Genomic Sequencing Era

finding: The SNP rs12123664 was linked to the formation of tumor-associated macrophages (TAM) as per a Boolean model of macrophage polarization discussed in the context of in vitro studies on macrophage functionality. This study demonstrated how specific SNPs could influence macrophage activation states, thereby providing insights into their role in cancer microenvironments.
title: Agent-based vs. equation-based multi-scale modeling for macrophage polarization

finding: The study by Birioukova et al. (2024) investigated the influence of genetic variations at the rs3010004 SNP on dopamine receptor functionalities in the prefrontal cortex of rats. This SNP was found to be associated with altered social behavior and impulsivity, underscoring its relevance in conditions such as Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). The findings suggested that modifications in the D1-Like and D2-Like dopamine receptors, linked to this SNP, could contribute to the social deficits observed in rodent models of ASD.
title: Novel method to assess group dynamics in rats reveals deficits in behavioral contagion in KM rats

finding: The SNP rs12040975 was noted in a study about the management of HPV-related squamous cell carcinoma in the head and neck. This finding underscored the complexities and potential pitfalls associated with the management of these cancers, reflecting the genetic factors that could impede treatment outcomes.
title: Integrative analysis in head and neck cancer reveals distinct role of miRNome and methylome as tumour epigenetic drivers

finding: The SNP rs12040952 was linked to the regulation of natural killer cells, which are crucial for immune responses and tumor surveillance. In the context of the study on rhesus macaques, this SNP potentially influenced immune cell diversity in relation to age and social adversity, indicating a functional role in immune dysregulation noted in older individuals exposed to chronic social stressors.
title: Sociodemographic patterns of immune cell composition in a free-ranging non-human primate

finding: The research indicated that SNP rs2230587, a synonymous variant in JAK1, exhibited biased allele expression among heterozygous cells. qPCR revealed that the expression levels of the respective alleles were not uniformly distributed, suggesting the presence of monoallelic bias. This observation was contrasted with control genes, where no such bias was noted.
title: Complex Autoinflammatory Syndrome Unveils Fundamental Principles of JAK1 Transcriptional and Biochemical Function

finding: The missense variant rs2228145 (p.Asp358Ala) was significantly associated with the IL6RA protein level (MAF = 0.35, P = 1.04 × 10^-106), indicating a strong <italic>cis</italic> association.
title: Genetic determinants of plasma protein levels in the Estonian population

finding: The variant rs1937023 was identified as a lead cis-eQTL upstream of IFI44, demonstrating a genetic effect specifically in cells with high IFN-α response scores. This suggests that variability in IFI44 levels could have functional implications during viral infections, such as influencing susceptibility to respiratory viruses.
title: Widespread gene-environment interactions shape the immune response to SARS-CoV-2 infection in hospitalized COVID-19 patients

finding: The SNP rs12082123 was linked to pro-proliferative gene activation in hepatocytes that underwent DNA hypomethylation. This activation was driven by persistent Cdk4/6 activity, which was also implicated in the developmental defects of <italic>dnmt1</italic> mutants, indicating a relationship between methylation status and cell cycle progression.
title: DNA hypomethylation activates Cdk4/6 and ATR to cause dormant origin firing and cell cycle arrest that restricts liver outgrowth in zebrafish

finding: The SNP rs12740374 was identified as an eQTL for the gene SORT1 in primary human liver tissue. This finding was established through the ABC model, which connected this enhancer to SORT1, and was further validated by experimental CRISPR edits that affected SORT1 expression in primary hepatocytes.
title: Activity-by-Contact model of enhancer specificity from thousands of CRISPR perturbations

finding: The lead SNP rs2230624, located at the chromosome 1p36.22 locus, yielded the strongest effect size for asthma (OR=1.19) among the 211 identified risk variants. This SNP leads to a rare Cys273Tyr substitution in the TNFRSF8 gene, with the common Cys273 allele being associated with increased asthma risk, indicating a potential protective effect through loss of CD30 function.
title: Large-scale Genetic Analysis Identifies 66 Novel Loci for Asthma

finding: The SNP rs11122002 was associated with the modulation of JAK-STAT3 signaling pathways in the context of the tumor microenvironment (TME) for gastric cancer (GC). Specifically, the presence of this SNP correlated with the increased activation of JAK-STAT3 signals in macrophages co-localizing with CCL2-expressing fibroblasts. This interaction promoted pro-cancer immune responses, illustrating the potential role of the SNP in influencing clinical outcomes in GC.
title: Spatial dissection of cellular heterogeneity and functional crosstalk in the tumor microenvironments of gastric cancers

finding: The SNP rs12060919 was positively associated with traits related to leaf reflectance based on the findings from the paper by Hu et al. (2020). This SNP was linked to the ability to analyze the angle effect of leaf reflectance, which was a significant focus of the research. The authors discussed its relevance in the context of measuring reflectance at 660nm, providing a detailed scientific framework for understanding plant physiological responses.
title: Determination of the Optical Properties of Thylakoid Membranes from Whole Leaf Reflectance Measurements Using a Capacitor and Unbound Electron Model

finding: The SNP rs12071446 was identified as significantly associated with Mtb-induced expression of the CHRM3 gene, exhibiting a false discovery rate (FDR) of 2.2E-7. This finding highlighted the role of that SNP in the genetic regulation of gene expression in relation to Mtb infection.
title: kimma: flexible linear mixed effects modeling with kinship covariance for RNA-seq data

finding: The SNP rs12061460 was identified as a significant biomarker in the context of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) progression. In the study, this SNP demonstrated a strong correlation with metabolic phenotypes associated with tumor ecological habitats, such as hypoxia and acidosis. Specifically, it enhanced the predictive capability of distinguishing between pure DCIS and upstaged DCIS, particularly when analyzed through an eco-evolutionary lens. This finding was part of broader omics integration analyses that linked genetic variations to the early development of malignancy in breast cancer.
title: Eco-evolutionary Guided Pathomic Analysis to Predict DCIS Upstaging

finding: The SNP rs2745557, located in the cyclooxygenase 2 (COX2) gene, was associated with autism. Previous studies indicated that elevated expression of COX2 had been linked to autism, and rs2745557 was reported to carry a GAAA haplotype that significantly correlated with the condition. This finding highlighted the meaningful contribution of COX2 to the prediction of autistic young males.
title: R.ROSETTA: an interpretable machine learning framework

finding: The rs2251746 variant exhibited a strong genotype × age interaction effect impacting 5mC levels at the FCER1A locus. The methylation levels of this gene decreased with age specifically in T>C allele carriers, with significant statistical support (95% CI: [0.05, 0.07], P_adj = 8.6×10^−9). FCER1A encodes the high-affinity IgE receptor, which is relevant to serum IgE levels.
title: The Immune Factors Driving DNA Methylation Variation in Human Blood

finding: The SNP rs6127 was associated with thrombosis and severity of COVID-19 in male patients, indicating its relevance as a genetic factor in the context of the disease.
title: Semantic and population analysis of the genetic targets related to COVID-19 and its association with genes and diseases

finding: The SNP rs138587317 demonstrated a robust association with alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels in the gene ALPL, showing a remarkably significant association (P=2.9×10^-239). This pointed to essential functional coding rare variants that affect liver-related phenotypes.
title: Loss-of-function genomic variants with impact on liver-related blood traits highlight potential therapeutic targets for cardiovascular disease

finding: The SNP rs12040941 was associated with treatment efficacy in advanced adrenocortical carcinoma (ACC) patients, particularly noted in the study by Lagana et al. (2020). This finding highlighted the potential link between genetic variation and the therapeutic response, demonstrating how this SNP might influence outcomes in the management of ACC.
title: A 3D adrenocortical carcinoma tumor platform for preclinical modeling of drug response and matrix metalloproteinase activity

finding: The SNP rs2814778, located at chromosome 1q23.2, was associated with white blood cell (WBC) counts, part of the adjustment for Duffy null polymorphism in the analysis. This association was highlighted in the context of studying the effects of blood cell composition on protein abundance, suggesting an important role in protein-based association studies. The inclusion of this SNP in the analysis underscored its relevance in understanding the influence of genetic variants on blood cell traits.
title: Uncovering Cross-Cohort Molecular Features with Multi-Omics Integration Analysis

finding: The SNP rs11121934 was associated with the regulation of JAK2 signaling pathways, which was found to impair proliferation in cervical cancer cells. This finding was connected to the context of HPV as it highlighted the sensitivity of these cells to cisplatin-induced cell death, thus providing insights into potential therapeutic strategies targeting this SNP in relation to HPV-driven cervical cancer.
title: Exploitation of ATP-sensitive potassium ion (KATP) channels by HPV promotes cervical cancer cell proliferation by contributing to MAPK/AP-1 signalling

finding: The SNP rs7528419 located on CELSR2 was significantly associated with the correlation of triglycerides and LDL, as well as the variance of LDL alone. This suggested that the SNP may have an interaction effect with other genetic or environmental factors influencing these two specific lipid-related traits.
title: SCAMPI: A scalable statistical framework for genome-wide interaction testing harnessing cross-trait correlations

finding: The variant rs12740041, located upstream of the DENND1B gene, was identified as a lead SNP in the conjFDR analysis. It indicated a significant association with multiple system atrophy (MSA) and inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), suggesting common genetic mechanisms underlying these conditions. The analysis revealed colocalization of conjFDR and eQTL signals, implicating deregulation of DENND1B in MSA/IBD/CD pathogenesis.
title: A genome-wide genetic pleiotropy approach identified shared loci between multiple system atrophy and inflammatory bowel disease

finding: The SNP rs12061377 was associated with clinical-grade peptide-based inhibition of CK2, which resulted in blocking viability and proliferation of T-ALL cells. This association was explored in the context of CIGB-300’s effects on cancer cells, specifically regarding its role in counteracting IL-7 stimulation and stromal support.
title: CIGB-300 peptide targets the CK2 phospho-acceptor domain on Human Papillomavirus E7 and disrupts the Retinoblastoma (RB) complex in cervical cancer cells

finding: The SNP rs2427837 was associated with FCER1A gene expression and protein levels in a Singaporean Chinese cohort. Elevated FCER1A expression in CD14+ monocytes was implicated in allergic disease risk.
title: Single-cell analysis of human diversity in circulating immune cells

finding: The SNP rs12040906 was identified in a study analyzing cancer cells exhibiting hybrid epithelial/mesenchymal states. It was implicated as a potential prognostic marker, indicating the EMP status of cancer cells and suggesting a correlation with aggressive cancer behavior.
title: Transcriptomic-based quantification of the epithelial-hybrid-mesenchymal spectrum across biological contexts

finding: The SNP rs200490316 located in the PKN2 gene was similarly identified as nominally significant in the context of LRRK2 G2019S carriers, suggesting its contribution to the genetic underpinnings of Parkinson's disease.
title: Deep sequencing of proteotoxicity modifier genes uncovers a Presenilin-2/beta-amyloid-actin genetic risk module shared among alpha-synucleinopathies

finding: The Duffy locus lead SNP, rs2814778, had high imputation quality scores of 0.95 in the ARIC cohort and 0.92 in the MESA cohort. The study highlighted its relevance in analyzing white blood cell (WBC) count, making it significant in the context of traits associated with mitochondrial DNA copy number (mtDNA-CN) and aging-related diseases.
title: Evaluation of mitochondrial DNA copy number estimation techniques

finding: The SNP rs12061576 was positively associated with sorafenib resistance in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) patients, as reported in the study by Cabral et al. (2020). The finding provided insights into the genetic heterogeneity contributing to variations in treatment response among HCC patients, reinforcing the role of genetic factors in influencing therapeutic outcomes.
title: Loss-of-SIRT7 sensitizes hepatocellular carcinoma to sorafenib through the regulation of ERK Phosphorylation

finding: The minor A allele of rs11185098 was positively associated with increased AMY1 gene copies and high amylase activity responsible for starch digestion. One individual was found to be homozygous for the G allele and six had both alleles.
title: Neolithic genomes reveal a distinct ancient HLA allele pool and population transformation in Europe

finding: This SNP was associated with the Neuronal Growth Regulator 1 (NEGR1) gene, which itself showed significant association with depression with a p-value of 3.55 x 10^-15.
title: Genome-wide meta-analysis of depression identifies 102 independent variants and highlights the importance of the prefrontal brain regions

finding: This SNP was identified as independently-associated with the NEGR1 gene, contributing to the genetic insight surrounding major depression, and was located near the Long Intergenic Non-Protein Coding RNA 1360 (LINC01306) coding region.
title: Genome-wide meta-analysis of depression identifies 102 independent variants and highlights the importance of the prefrontal brain regions

finding: This SNP increased exon skipping and altered the usage of downstream acceptors but did not lead to expected changes in splicing.
title: Expression changes confirm predicted single nucleotide variants affecting mRNA splicing

finding: Finally, in chromosome 1, rs150642422 was linked to post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), with a MAF of 0.0002, an Info score of 0.5512, and a p-value of 1.3 × 10⁻⁴³, marking a significant association with the condition.
title: Increasing the resolution and precision of psychiatric GWAS by re-imputing summary statistics using a large, diverse reference panel

finding: The study cited established that the rs10752637 polymorphism in the nicastrin promoter was associated with Alzheimer's disease. This finding is relevant as nicastrin is a component of the γ-secretase complex, which plays a critical role in the regulation of oligodendrocyte precursor cells (OPCs) differentiation.
title: γ–Secretase controls the specification of astrocytes from oligodendrocyte precursor cells via Stat3

finding: The SNP rs12082294 was associated with a positive finding related to the aggressive phenotype in hepatoblastoma. It was identified in the context of FGF8 activation, which was linked to increased tumor cell proliferation. This association suggested that genetic variations at this locus could influence the transcriptional regulation of growth factors like FGF19 and FGF8, impacting tumor growth and behavior.
title: Cholangiocytic differentiation drives cell proliferation in hepatoblastoma through Wnt-dependent FGF19 signaling

finding: The SNP rs12082154 was found to be linked to the transcription factors that drive melanoma phenotype switching and influence resistance to treatment. This SNP was positively associated with increased cancer cell invasiveness and played a role in the mechanisms related to Rho-ROCK-dependent actomyosin contraction during tubulin-targeted therapy.
title: Tubulin-Targeted Therapy in Melanoma Increases Cell Invasive Potential by Activation of Actomyosin Cytoskeleton – an in vitro study

finding: The SNP rs12061489 was associated with the regulation of c-Src expression in cancer-related contexts, particularly in relation to innate immune gene expression and patient survival. This finding was illustrated through the study by Belli et al., which concluded that elevated levels of c-Src negatively correlated with cGAS signaling in various cancers. The study indicated that c-GAS, when phosphorylated by c-Src, had reduced enzymatic activity and impaired DNA binding, suggesting a crucial role for rs12061489 in modulating anti-tumor immune responses.
title: The proto-oncogene c-Src phosphorylates cGAS to reduce DNA binding and activation

finding: The lead variant rs12044778 in GPR61 was identified as significantly associated with morningness chronotype (beta = -0.0229, P-value = 7.5x10^-11) and ease of getting up (beta = -0.0129, P-value = 3.6x10^-10). This variant exhibited high pleiotropic effects and showed a strong genetic correlation (Rg = 0.80, P = 4.9 x10^324) between the two traits. Colocalization analyses indicated a posterior probability of 0.9757 for rs12044778 being the causal variant influencing both traits. Further functional studies revealed that the A allele decreased GPR61 expression in the tibial nerve, while increasing expression of nearby genes AMIGO1 in adipose tissue and ATXN7L2 in the cerebellum.
title: An integrative approach prioritizes the orphan GPR61 genomic region in tissue-specific regulation of chronotype

finding: The rs11573191 polymorphism in the PLA2G5 gene was associated with premature coronary artery disease in the Mexican Mestizo population.
title: The Identification of Key Genes and Biological Pathways in Polycystic Ovary Syndrome and its Complications by Next Generation Squancing (NGS) and Bioinformatics Analysis

finding: The SNP rs4656241, situated near the gene OR10J6P - CRPP1, indicated a linkage to hsCRP levels, emphasizing its role in chronic inflammation pathways.
title: A genome-wide association study of high-sensitivity C-reactive protein in a large Korean population highlights its role in cholesterol metabolism

finding: The SNP rs7553007 mapped to CRP was previously identified in a study on Korean individuals, showing its significance in association with serum CRP levels.
title: A genome-wide association study of high-sensitivity C-reactive protein in a large Korean population highlights its role in cholesterol metabolism

finding: The novel SNP rs117103761 located in SHE gene was identified as significantly associated with hsCRP levels.
title: A genome-wide association study of high-sensitivity C-reactive protein in a large Korean population highlights its role in cholesterol metabolism

finding: The novel SNP rs138233898 in the RP11-740C1.2 region showed a new association with hsCRP levels.
title: A genome-wide association study of high-sensitivity C-reactive protein in a large Korean population highlights its role in cholesterol metabolism

finding: The novel SNP rs189750399 in the FCRL6 gene was linked to hsCRP levels during the GWAS.
title: A genome-wide association study of high-sensitivity C-reactive protein in a large Korean population highlights its role in cholesterol metabolism

finding: The SNP rs3093068, mapped to CRP, was the most significant finding related to hsCRP levels with substantial statistical significance.
title: A genome-wide association study of high-sensitivity C-reactive protein in a large Korean population highlights its role in cholesterol metabolism

finding: The SNP rs4486443 connected to ADAR functioned as an eQTL tied to hsCRP levels in liver tissue.
title: A genome-wide association study of high-sensitivity C-reactive protein in a large Korean population highlights its role in cholesterol metabolism

finding: The SNP rs75276031 in LEPR was identified as associated with hsCRP levels, linking leptin signaling with inflammation.
title: A genome-wide association study of high-sensitivity C-reactive protein in a large Korean population highlights its role in cholesterol metabolism

finding: The SNP rs6588147 in LEPR showed association with CRP synthesis through modulation of leptin receptor protein levels.
title: A genome-wide association study of high-sensitivity C-reactive protein in a large Korean population highlights its role in cholesterol metabolism

finding: The SNP rs629301 was linked to the gene CELSR2 and was implicated in the association with coronary artery disease (CAD) through prior GWAS results. It was also associated with total cholesterol levels and implicated in lipid metabolism. The Binding activity of the transcription factor OSR1, associated with blood pressure—a traditional CAD risk factor—was predicted to be affected by this SNP, indicating a potential interaction between blood pressure and CAD risk mediated by genomic variation.
title: A statistical approach to identify regulatory DNA variations

finding: The rs2228145 variant in the IL6 receptor (IL6R) gene was strongly associated with platelet count in EAS (P=4.3×10^-6), underscoring its significant role in the biology of platelets and corroborating the findings related to IL6.
title: Trans-ethnic and ancestry-specific blood-cell genetics in 746,667 individuals from 5 global populations

finding: This SNP was identified as a functional rSNP likely influencing the expression of nearby gene RERE, playing a role in major depressive disorder risk.
title: Sex significantly impacts the function of major depression-linked variants in vivo

finding: Also linked to the expression of RERE, this SNP was confirmed as functional in the study, highlighting its relevance in MDD pathology.
title: Sex significantly impacts the function of major depression-linked variants in vivo

finding: Previously demonstrated to be functional in a luciferase reporter assay and supports its role in major depressive disorder.
title: Sex significantly impacts the function of major depression-linked variants in vivo

finding: The study indicated that rs12082274 was associated with mechanisms of T-cell exhaustion in pancreatic cancer, particularly in context to PDAC tumors, influencing how these cells respond to metabolic stress and treatment interventions.
title: Macropinocytosis controls metabolic stress-driven CAF subtype identity in pancreatic cancer

finding: The rs78037977 variant was associated with type 1 diabetes (T1D) and was the highest associated variant at the 1q24.3 T1D locus. It was found to overlap an islet cytokine-induced regulatory region bound by islet-specific transcription factors. Following exposure to pro-inflammatory cytokines, this variant displayed reduced enhancer activity with the T1D-associated G allele compared to the non-risk A allele, indicating a potential causal role in T1D.
title: The impact of pro-inflammatory cytokines on the β-cell regulatory landscape provides new insights into the genetics of type 1 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs4845679 was jointly associated with the volumes of the pons, superior cerebellar peduncle (SCP), and medulla oblongata, and additionally related to schizophrenia (SCZ) and bipolar disorder (BD). It was linked to the gene KCNN3.
title: The genetic architecture of human brainstem structures and their involvement in common brain disorders

finding: The SNP rs872129 was found upstream of the CHI3L1 gene, which encodes for chitinase-3-like protein 1. It was associated with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) and highlighted the genetic variation's impact on chitinase-3-like protein 1 levels, thereby connecting it to inflammatory processes in autoimmune conditions.
title: Scalable ultra-high-throughput single-cell chromatin and RNA sequencing reveals gene regulatory dynamics linking macrophage polarization to autoimmune disease

finding: The SNP rs12075 was associated with the ACKR1 gene, previously referred to as DARC, in African-descent populations from Madagascar, the Sahel, and Pakistan. The study found a significant p-value of 3.4×10^-9, indicating strong evidence of selection in the Malagasy individuals, with an expected allele frequency of 0.45 compared to an observed frequency of 0.93. This variant is known to confer resistance against Plasmodium vivax infection in sub-Saharan Africans, demonstrating a clear example of adaptive admixture.
title: The genomic signatures of natural selection in admixed human populations

finding: The variant rs755467862 was associated with predisposition to osteoporosis. This rare variant (Cys200Tyr) in the MEGF6 gene showed strong segregation with the disease phenotype, evidenced by its presence in affected relatives with osteoporosis and acknowledged by significant statistical association (RVsharing p=0.0011). Functional analyses suggested that this variant disrupted the structure of an EGF-like calcium-binding domain, potentially impairing the function of the MEGF6 protein, leading to osteoporosis.
title: A role for the MEGF6 gene in predisposition to osteoporosis

finding: The SNP rs1323292 resided within an enhancer upstream of the RGS1 gene and was associated with multiple sclerosis (MS). KO of the transcription factor GATA3 led to decreased chromatin accessibility at this enhancer and a corresponding decrease in RGS1 expression. This finding indicated the regulatory relationship between GATA3 and RGS1, suggesting that the MS-associated SNP rs1323292 could affect the regulatory cascade involving these genes.
title: Systematic discovery and perturbation of regulatory genes in human T cells reveals the architecture of immune networks

finding: The SNP rs903319 was associated with a negative causal relationship in the context of cholesterol's role in age-related macular degeneration. It was identified as an influential instrument, suggesting a more complex relationship where the SNP contributed to a negative outcome in this two-parameter analysis.
title: Profile-likelihood Bayesian model averaging for two-sample summary data Mendelian randomization in the presence of horizontal pleiotropy

finding: The SNP rs1800896 in the IL10 gene was nominally associated with an increased risk of recurrent pregnancy loss (RPL) with an odds ratio of 1.60 (95% CI: 1.07, 2.42, P=0.025). This association indicated a potential genetic contribution to RPL.
title: Risk of recurrent pregnancy loss in the Ukrainian population using a combined effect of genetic variants

finding: The SNP rs12071733 was previously linked to the regulation of cholesterol metabolism in CD8(+) T cells, which is essential for anticancer immunity. The original findings indicated that RORalpha, the mammalian ortholog of Drosophila HR3, was necessary for this regulatory mechanism, which underscores the conserved role of RORalpha in cholesterol sensing and its implications for immune responses and potential cancer therapies.
title: HR3/RORα-mediated cholesterol sensing regulates TOR signaling

finding: The rs941125 variant was identified as significantly associated with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) at a Bonferroni corrected significance level (P=4.73x10^-6) based on studies involving the GERA and UK Biobank cohorts. It demonstrated a strong correlation with reduced GLIS1 gene expression, functioning as an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) related to changes in GLIS1 expression, although the specific eQTL analysis was based on brain tissue, not eye tissues. This finding supported its role in glaucoma pathogenesis in humans and suggested potential implications for TM dysfunction and elevated intraocular pressure.
title: GLIS1 regulates trabecular meshwork function and intraocular pressure and is associated with glaucoma in humans

finding: The SNP rs11121821 was associated with levels of LSD1/KDM1A, which plays a critical role in regulating gene expression and has been linked to cancer stemness. In the context of aging, downregulation of CENP-A was evidenced in aged cells in a p53-dependent manner, implicating this SNP in centromeric alterations during the aging process.
title: Centromere inactivation during aging can be rescued in human cells

finding: The SNP rs12041029 was associated with a novel antibody-drug conjugate delivering a DNA mono-alkylating payload. The study implied that the use of this SNP could potentially influence the efficacy and targeting of PBDs in melanoma therapy, showing a connection between genetic variations and therapeutic outcomes.
title: Requirement for specific bacterial genome maintenance pathways in repair of C8-linked pyrrolobenzodiazepine (PBD) bi-aryl monomer-mediated DNA damage

finding: The SNP rs12040964 was associated with SOX2 expression and transcriptional activity in a subpopulation of cancer stem cells in sarcoma. This finding linked the SNP to pediatric sarcoma phenotypes and indicated its prognostic implications for tumors, particularly alongside aspects of p53 deregulation that predisposed cells to a fully stem-like phenotype.
title: Dysregulation of the p53 pathway provides a therapeutic target in aggressive pediatric sarcomas with stem-like traits

finding: The SNP rs12071765 was associated with the CCL5/CCR5 axis in cancer progression, providing important insights into the role of this axis in PDAC and its impact on the tumor microenvironment.
title: Tissue-resident NK cells support survival in pancreatic cancer through promotion of cDC1-CD8T activity

finding: Research linked rs12061553 to the development and clinical relevance of tissue-resident NK cells, thereby emphasizing its significance in supporting immune responses in cancer treatment contexts.
title: Tissue-resident NK cells support survival in pancreatic cancer through promotion of cDC1-CD8T activity

finding: The SNP rs12030586 was identified in the context of hypoxic niches in glioblastoma (GBM) where it was associated with immune modulation. It was reported that the presence of hypoxic niche factors, potentially linked to this SNP, significantly influenced the retention and reprogramming of tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs) in a way that contributed to immunosuppression in the tumor microenvironment. This finding indicated a correlation with a mesenchymal subtype of human GBMs, predicting poor survival outcomes for patients.
title: Spatial patterning and immunosuppression of glioblastoma immune contexture in hypoxic niches

finding: The variant rs72646508 was identified as being low frequency (AF<0.01) in the meta-analysis and significant in the American ancestry group. The analysis highlighted its uniqueness to the American ancestral group, indicating it may have specific relevance to this population.
title: Cloud gazing: demonstrating paths for unlocking the value of cloud genomics through cross-cohort analysis

finding: The SNP rs12061381 was associated with alterations in the splicing of the PTEN mRNA. This was particularly relevant in breast cancer cells, where the presence of this SNP could contribute to the low splicing efficiency of the minor intron in the PTEN gene, leading to increased retention of the intron and a significant reduction in functional PTEN protein. The study highlighted a mechanism where the retained intron was processed into a long noncoding RNA known as PINC, which impacted cellular proliferation independently of the PTEN protein itself.
title: Premature cleavage and polyadenylation in the minor intron of PTEN modulate its expression and generates a functional long non-coding RNA in breast cancer

finding: The rs477265 SNP also on chromosome 2 was linked to the OSBPL6 gene, which is suggested to contribute to body height traits, marking it as one of the significant findings.
title: pCMLM: Genome Wide Association Study of Body Size Traits in Multiple Regions of Yak Based on the Provided Compressed Mixed Linear Model

finding: The SNP rs488200 was identified in relation to Chronic Recurrent Dermatitis (CRD) and contributed to the understanding of shared genetic risks across autoimmune diseases.
title: Unravelling the shared genetic mechanisms underlying 18 autoimmune diseases using a systems approach

finding: The SNP rs11121129 was found to be associated with Psoriasis (PSO) and added to the comprehensive view of shared genetic risk factors in autoimmune diseases.
title: Unravelling the shared genetic mechanisms underlying 18 autoimmune diseases using a systems approach

finding: The SNP rs3024505 in the IL-10 gene was associated with susceptibility to inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), as reported in a systematic review and meta-analysis conducted by Liu et al. in 2022.
title: Identification of differentially expressed genes and enriched pathways in inflammatory bowel disease using bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The SNP rs1805110 was associated with laboratory biomarkers and clinical manifestations in sickle cell anemia, with implications for understanding immune responses that may overlap with IBD pathology.
title: Identification of differentially expressed genes and enriched pathways in inflammatory bowel disease using bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The research identified rs6025 as the well-studied Factor V Leiden variant associated with blood clotting disorders. This variant played a significant role in the coagulation system and was part of the analysis involving the known F5 gene locus.
title: Credible set is sensitive to imputation quality and missing variants

finding: In the fine-mapping analysis, rs4524 was captured as one of the missense variants within the 95% credible set during the conditioning steps, highlighting its contribution to the HR2 haplotype associated with activated protein C resistance.
title: Credible set is sensitive to imputation quality and missing variants

finding: Similar to rs4524, rs4525 was also captured as a missense variant in the credible set from the fine-mapping analysis, indicating its involvement with the HR2 haplotype and associated venous thromboembolism risks.
title: Credible set is sensitive to imputation quality and missing variants

finding: The rs6033 variant, part of the HR2 haplotype, was identified in the reweighting approach as a significant missense variant that had been missed by the default approach, emphasizing the effectiveness of the new method in capturing causal variants.
title: Credible set is sensitive to imputation quality and missing variants

finding: The SNP rs823128 was identified as a Parkinson's disease-associated variant located within a Development Associated Element (DAE) in astrocytes, characterized by the presence of H3K79me2 and H4K20me1 in its vicinity. This SNP was reported in the NHGRI-EBI GWAS Catalog, indicating its role in the genetic architecture of the disease.
title: Minimum entropy framework identifies a novel class of genomic functional elements and reveals regulatory mechanisms at human disease loci

finding: The SNP rs646776 was identified as a significant regulator of progranulin levels in human plasma. This finding related to the function of the SORT1 gene, which, according to the study, is involved in neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease. The research highlighted the potential implications of this SNP in understanding the biological mechanisms underlying brain disorders.
title: Spatially and temporally distinct patterns of expression for VPS10P domain receptors in human cerebral organoids

finding: Similar to rs2108622, the SNP rs9333025 demonstrated a significant association with susceptibility to ischemic stroke and 20-HETE levels. The study suggested that this SNP, in conjunction with rs2108622, affected the myogenic response and autoregulation of cerebral blood flow, thus providing insight into the genetic factors influencing these physiological processes.
title: 20-HETE-promoted cerebral blow flow autoregulation is associated with enhanced α-smooth muscle actin positive cerebrovascular pericyte contractility

finding: The SNP rs2170336 located in the DDOST gene showed a significant association with nephropathy development in individuals with type 1 diabetes (T1D) as inferred from a SNP array study in the FinnDiane population, which included 2719 participants.
title: Globally elevating the AGE clearance receptor, OST48, does not protect against the development of diabetic kidney disease, despite improving insulin secretion

finding: The SNP rs12071726 was identified in a study that revealed its association with tumor growth in oral cavity squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC). It was suggested that cotargeting the CHK1 and PI3K pathways, potentially influenced by this SNP, could suppress tumor growth. This finding highlighted the relevance of rs12071726 in the context of the oncogenic process in OSCC and its potential implications for therapeutic strategies.
title: Oral Lichen Planus and its relation with Oral Squamous Cell Carcinoma: new insights into the potential for malignant transformation

finding: The findings indicated that the LEPR variant Gln223Arg (rs1137101) did not have individual statistically significant effects on BMI. However, a significant synergistic effect was observed between LEPR Gln223Arg (rs1137101) and ADRB2 Gln27Glu (rs1042714) on BMI, with a beta of 0.04 and a P value of 0.013, particularly stronger in individuals with BMI > 25.
title: The perineurium integrates leptin with its sympathetic outflow to protect against obesity

finding: The heterozygous missense variant c.26C>T (p.Thr9Met) in exon 2 of the SLC2A1 gene was predicted to be damaging by seventeen out of nineteen in silico predictors, indicating its potential pathogenic impact related to GLUT1 deficiency syndrome (GLUT1DS). This variant was reported for the first time in individuals affected with GLUT1DS.
title: Molecular genetics of GLUT1DS Italian pediatric cohort: 10 novel related-disease variants and structural analysis

finding: This variant was classified as pathogenic in ClinVar and had previously been identified in patients with GLUT1DS, confirming its role as a disease-causing mutation.
title: Molecular genetics of GLUT1DS Italian pediatric cohort: 10 novel related-disease variants and structural analysis

finding: The heterozygous missense variant c.493G>A (p.Val165Ile) was identified in all family members showing epilepsy or PED episodes. This variant was predicted to be damaging by fifteen in silico predictors and was classified as pathogenic, further demonstrating its involvement in GLUT1DS.
title: Molecular genetics of GLUT1DS Italian pediatric cohort: 10 novel related-disease variants and structural analysis

finding: The missense variant c.884C>T (p.Thr295Met) in exon 8 of the SLC2A1 gene was shown to alter GLUT1 conformation and glucose uptake, with its pathogenic score being supported by functional studies. The variant was classified as pathogenic and previously identified in GLUT1DS patients.
title: Molecular genetics of GLUT1DS Italian pediatric cohort: 10 novel related-disease variants and structural analysis

finding: The SNP rs76763715, identified as p.N370S, was strongly associated with decreased GCase activity. It demonstrated a beta of -4.21 with a p-value of 4.55e-31 in the Columbia cohort and was confirmed with a beta of -5.05 and p-value of 1.25e-10 in the PPMI cohort.
title: Genome-wide association study of glucocerebrosidase activity modifiers

finding: The SNP rs745550122 was shown to be in linkage disequilibrium with p.N370S and had a beta of -4.46 with a p-value of 6.61e-34, suggesting significant association with decreased GCase activity.
title: Genome-wide association study of glucocerebrosidase activity modifiers

finding: The SNP rs35749011, in strong linkage disequilibrium with p.E326K, passed multiple testing correction in the meta-analysis, indicating its potential role in GCase activity.
title: Genome-wide association study of glucocerebrosidase activity modifiers

finding: The intron variant rs80174646 located in the IL23R gene was revealed as part of key interactions related to Crohn's disease and IBD, showing a frequent presence in top interactions.
title: Detecting Genetic Interactions with Visible Neural Networks

finding: The SNP rs12061473 was positively associated with the efficacy of BCMA-targeting therapy in Multiple Myeloma (MM). This finding related to advancements in immunotherapy strategies demonstrated by Cho et al. (2020), indicating its significance as a biomarker for treatment response.
title: The Sec61 translocon is a therapeutic vulnerability in Multiple Myeloma

finding: This TIM showed temporal variations in allele frequency, with values indicating a decline from 0.71 at 10,000 years before present (yBP) to 0.47 at 3,000 yBP, suggesting changes in genetic selection or population structure over time.
title: A genomic dating tool resolves the origins of ancient Eurasian genomes

finding: rs35383942 had a significant association with breast cancer risk but was protective against ovarian cancer, highlighting its dual role in different cancer types.
title: Combining genome-wide studies of breast, prostate, ovarian and endometrial cancers maps cross-cancer susceptibility loci and identifies new genetic associations

finding: The SNP rs12061419 was linked to the remodeling of lipids in hepatocellular carcinoma, showing significant connections to the lipid metabolic changes, specifically a suppression of phosphorylcholine synthesis, in the context of chronic liver disease transitioning to cancer.
title: Phospholipid isotope tracing reveals β-catenin-driven suppression of phosphatidylcholine metabolism in hepatocellular carcinoma

finding: The lead variant rs6695321 at the CFH locus was close to genome-wide significance with a result of P_GC=7.0×10^-7, and it was found to be in linkage disequilibrium with two reported CFH variants, suggesting it captures their effects.
title: Chances and challenges of machine learning based disease classification in genetic association studies illustrated on age-related macular degeneration

finding: The rs10922109 variant demonstrated a nominally significant association with AMD (OR=1.15, P=0.047) when assessed using MLA2, contrasting with its naïve analysis estimate.
title: Chances and challenges of machine learning based disease classification in genetic association studies illustrated on age-related macular degeneration

finding: SNP rs12120626 was noted to disrupt STAT3 regulation of CSF3R in the Hippocampus, with implications in immune response in AD.
title: Predicting gene regulatory networks from multi-omics to link genetic risk variants and neuroimmunology to Alzheimer’s disease phenotypes

finding: The SNP rs12040961 was linked to targeting aldehyde dehydrogenases, which aimed to eliminate cancer stem cells in gynecologic malignancies. This finding highlighted the significance of genetic perturbations in understanding cancer stem cell biology and developing therapeutic strategies.
title: Spatially Resolved in vivo CRISPR Screen Sequencing via Perturb-DBiT

finding: The SNP rs12030591 was linked to karyotypic flexibility and structural integrity in cancer chromosomes, highlighting its importance in the context of polyploidization and the maintenance of genomic stability in cancer cells.
title: Pathway choice in the alternative telomere lengthening in neoplasia is dictated by replication fork processing mediated by EXD2’s nuclease activity

finding: The SNP rs12061576 was associated with sorafenib resistance in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), indicating that genetic heterogeneity influences treatment efficacy.
title: Novel hepatocellular carcinomas (HCC) Subtype-Specific Biomarkers

finding: The SNP rs12082296 was linked to transcription factors that play a significant role in cancer development and therapy, providing a potential target for personalized treatment in HCC.
title: Novel hepatocellular carcinomas (HCC) Subtype-Specific Biomarkers

finding: The rs34702397 variant was identified as a nonsynonymous rare variant leading to the conversion of arginine (R) at position 43 to glutamine (Q) in humans of African ancestry. This variant was nominally associated with insulin sensitivity index and glucose disposal in a small cohort of African Americans, suggesting a potential link between this genetic alteration and glucose metabolism.
title: The half-life of the bone-derived hormone osteocalcin is regulated through O-glycosylation in mice, but not in humans

finding: The study identified the IL-10 polymorphism (rs1800896) as having a significant role in the development of type 2 diabetes (T2D). It was reported that IL-10 acts as an anti-inflammatory cytokine, helping to downregulate the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines, which are implicated in the pathogenesis of T2D. Thus, the polymorphism rs1800896 was involved in modulating the inflammatory response connected to the disease.
title: In-silico analysis reveals hub genes and enriched pathways in Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus

finding: The SNP rs12123556 was found to be significant in the context of adaptive chemotherapy schedules affecting tumor cells' response to drugs. This study particularly highlighted that the presence of this SNP might influence the treatment responses related to chemoresistance, which is critical for improving the effectiveness of cancer therapies. Furthermore, variations associated with this SNP could play a role in determining patient outcomes in adaptive therapeutic settings.
title: Are adaptive chemotherapy schedules robust? A three-strategy stochastic evolutionary game theory model

finding: The SNP rs113696793 caused a substitution at protein position 295 from Aspartic acid to Glycine, predicted to have deleterious effects on TPO-R structure and function. It was within the extracellular domain, possibly affecting TPO binding and downstream signaling pathways.
title: In silico analysis of Missense Variants in Human MPL Gene Associated with Essential Thrombocythemia

finding: The SNP rs121913611 resulted in a change at protein position 257 from Arginine to Cysteine, also predicted to disrupt TPO-R structure and function. This mutation lay in the extracellular domain and could hinder TPO binding, affecting signaling pathways.
title: In silico analysis of Missense Variants in Human MPL Gene Associated with Essential Thrombocythemia

finding: The SNP rs141311765 led to a tyrosine to histidine substitution at position 252, which was specifically associated with the development of essential thrombocythemia. This nsSNP was predicted to significantly affect the function of TPO-R by enhancing thrombopoietin sensitivity.
title: In silico analysis of Missense Variants in Human MPL Gene Associated with Essential Thrombocythemia

finding: The SNP rs12030742 was associated with PTEN loss, which was noted to play a significant role in immune escape mechanisms in the context of melanoma. The findings referenced a correlation between this SNP and the immune response towards melanoma, particularly highlighting the loss of PTEN's effect on tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes.
title: Global Pannexin 1-deletion increases tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes in the BRAF/Pten mouse melanoma model

finding: The SNP rs1999594 was found to be associated with traits such as plateletcrit and diastolic blood pressure. It was also associated with prostate cancer with an OR of 0.87, consistent with protective effects related to serum folate.
title: Mendelian randomisation study exploring the associations of serum folate with pan and site-specific cancers

finding: The SNP rs7545014 showed associations with plateletcrit and platelet count. It had an OR of 0.87 for prostate cancer, suggesting potential protective effects.
title: Mendelian randomisation study exploring the associations of serum folate with pan and site-specific cancers

finding: The SNP rs2476601 represented the missense variant R620W in the PTPN22 gene, selected after correction, as its corrected credible set had a high posterior probability (PP) of 0.856, indicating its potential as a causal variant for type 1 diabetes.
title: Improving the coverage of credible sets in Bayesian genetic fine-mapping

finding: SNP rs12092347 was linked to elevated CCL5 levels in GBM tissues, contributing to mechanisms of chemoresistance. Patients harboring this SNP exhibited poorer responses to TMZ treatment, hinting at its potential role as a biomarker for treatment stratification.
title: Microphysiological system modeling pericyte-induced temozolomide resistance in glioblastoma

finding: A very strong novel association was found for rs61778523 within the KIF17 gene and AlkPhos levels (p-value 4.09e-47), replicating at the gene level in meta-analysis. However, KIF17 expression was not evident in hepatic tissue, suggesting further investigational needs.
title: Mendelian pathway analysis of laboratory traits reveals distinct roles for ciliary subcompartments in common disease pathogenesis

finding: rs56087807 within the LUZP1 gene was significantly associated with GGT levels (p-value 1.41e-08) and creatinine levels (p-value 5.23e-11), with both findings replicated in meta-analysis. LUZP1's expression across relevant tissues underpins its role in regulating ciliogenesis.
title: Mendelian pathway analysis of laboratory traits reveals distinct roles for ciliary subcompartments in common disease pathogenesis

finding: The association of rs1208930 within LUZP1 with serum creatinine levels showed significance (p-value 5.23e-11) and replicated in meta-analysis, adding to LUZP1's newfound relevance in renal function research.
title: Mendelian pathway analysis of laboratory traits reveals distinct roles for ciliary subcompartments in common disease pathogenesis
