finding: This SNP was associated with inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD) and had a significant p-value of 4.157e-09. The study highlighted the overlap of SNP anchors at Group 3 in GM12878, which points to the involvement of local CRE activities in relation to the risk and non-risk alleles.
title: GTAGMe-seq: joint profiling of genetic variants, DNA methylation, GpC methyltransferase footprints, and 3D genome in the same DNA molecules

finding: The SNP rs12030644 was identified as significantly associated with Ewing Sarcoma (EwS) through the analysis of the gene expression of BCL11B and GLG1, which exhibited high specificity for EWSR1-FLI1 and EWSR1-ERG positive Ewing Sarcoma. This finding suggested a contribution of this SNP to the pathophysiology of EwS and indicated potential avenues for targeted therapies.
title: Oncofusion-driven de novo enhancer assembly promotes malignancy in Ewing sarcoma via aberrant expression of the stereociliary protein LOXHD1

finding: rs74460673 was identified in connection with long sleep duration of more than 10 hours. It was previously associated with Body Mass Index (BMI) and located at gene TMEM39B.
title: Automated Feature Extraction from Population Wearable Device Data Identified Novel Loci Associated with Sleep and Circadian Rhythms

finding: Exclusive overlap was found with CAMBUS+ OCR in non-classical monocytes for this SNP. It was connected to the gene FCGR3B, which encodes a receptor expressed in non-classical monocytes, linking it to the Albumin/Globulin ratio.
title: Predicted constrained accessible regions mark regulatory elements and causal variants

finding: The SNP rs12071768 was associated with an increased effectiveness of IGF-1R targeted therapy in Ewing sarcoma (EwS) patients. Data indicated that individuals with this variant showed improved treatment outcomes in a meta-analysis comparing five IGF-1R-related trials.
title: YAP1 is a key regulator of EWS::FLI1-dependent malignant transformation upon IGF-1 mediated reprogramming of bone mesenchymal stem cells

finding: The SNP rs12030644 was positively linked to the differentiation of EwS subtypes, with findings suggesting that carriers had increased specificity in tumor identification related to EWSR1-FLI1 and EWSR1-ERG fusion genes, potentially aiding in targeted treatment strategies.
title: YAP1 is a key regulator of EWS::FLI1-dependent malignant transformation upon IGF-1 mediated reprogramming of bone mesenchymal stem cells

finding: The SNP rs1412825 was located within a locus positively associated with drinks per week and showed a negative association with the expression of PPP2R3C in both oligodendrocytes and D1/D2 MSNs. Given that individuals with AUD presented significantly lower expression levels of this gene, it implied a potential protective effect of PPP2R3C against AUD.
title: Integrated Single-Cell Multiomic Profiling of Caudate Nucleus Suggests Key Mechanisms in Alcohol Use Disorder

finding: The SNP rs6668295 was part of the positively selected haplotype in the JPT/CHB population spanning the SMCP-IVL region, indicating its role in epidermal evolution.
title: An enhancer:involucrin regulatory module impacts human skin barrier adaptation out-of-Africa and modifies atopic dermatitis risk

finding: This SNP was identified along with rs6668295 in the linkage disequilibrium analysis for the JPT/CHB haplotype, showcasing its contribution to skin-related positive selection.
title: An enhancer:involucrin regulatory module impacts human skin barrier adaptation out-of-Africa and modifies atopic dermatitis risk

finding: SNP rs78730108 was part of the JPT/CHB-LINC01527 haplotype, indicating positive selection for skin-related traits in the JPT/CHB population.
title: An enhancer:involucrin regulatory module impacts human skin barrier adaptation out-of-Africa and modifies atopic dermatitis risk

finding: This SNP was in high linkage with rs78730108, further supporting its identification within the positively selected haplotype in JPT/CHB.
title: An enhancer:involucrin regulatory module impacts human skin barrier adaptation out-of-Africa and modifies atopic dermatitis risk

finding: The SNP rs4845327, a tagging SNP for the CEU-IVL haplotype, exhibited a positive correlation with increased IVL expression and latitude, signifying its key role in positive selection in European populations.
title: An enhancer:involucrin regulatory module impacts human skin barrier adaptation out-of-Africa and modifies atopic dermatitis risk

finding: This SNP was associated with decreased IVL expression in the JPT/CHB haplotype, suggesting negative selection pressures for skin traits in that population.
title: An enhancer:involucrin regulatory module impacts human skin barrier adaptation out-of-Africa and modifies atopic dermatitis risk

finding: The enhancer variant rs78868757 was linked to decreased IVL expression and protein presence in atopic dermatitis patients, highlighting its relevance in disease contexts.
title: An enhancer:involucrin regulatory module impacts human skin barrier adaptation out-of-Africa and modifies atopic dermatitis risk

finding: As a strong candidate for a causal variant, rs1854779 was linked to a gain-of-function transcription factor binding site, demonstrating a potential enhancer's role in positive selection for IVL expression.
title: An enhancer:involucrin regulatory module impacts human skin barrier adaptation out-of-Africa and modifies atopic dermatitis risk

finding: The SNP rs12082287 was linked to a positive finding related to fascin inhibition and its effects on cancer growth. Specifically, it was shown that anti-metastasis fascin inhibitors, associated with this SNP, resulted in decreased growth of specific subtypes of cancers. This indicated a potential therapeutic target in the context of fascin expression and its contributions to tumorigenesis and metastasis.
title: Anchorage-independent cell proliferation promoted by fascin’s F-actin bundling

finding: The SNP rs74767794 demonstrated a PBS-specific effect on splicing and colocalized with a THR GWAS signal tied to COLGALT2.
title: Response splicing QTLs in primary human chondrocytes identifies putative osteoarthritis risk genes

finding: The SNP rs1327123 was the index variant for a THR GWAS signal, supporting its role in the regulatory landscape for COLGALT2.
title: Response splicing QTLs in primary human chondrocytes identifies putative osteoarthritis risk genes

finding: The SNP rs11583641 was previously linked to OA risk and now also implicated alternative splicing as a mechanism affecting COLGALT2.
title: Response splicing QTLs in primary human chondrocytes identifies putative osteoarthritis risk genes

finding: The non-coding variant rs3790604 in WNT2B was associated with an increased risk of primary aldosteronism (PA). This finding was replicated in a case-controlled multi-ancestry cohort study using data from the All of Us Database, which confirmed the association with an odds ratio of 1.53, indicating that the A allele of this variant correlates with heightened risk for PA, consistent with prior studies. Thus, it identified WNT2B as a potentially key regulatory factor in adrenal function and aldosterone production.
title: Non-canonical Wnt signaling triggered by WNT2B drives adrenal aldosterone production

finding: The SNP rs10911362 in the human NCF2 gene was associated with a protective effect against pulmonary tuberculosis (TB). This SNP, corresponding to a G nucleotide, was linked to lowered odds ratios for pulmonary TB, indicating a significant role in disease susceptibility. In the context of Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection, the absence of the Ncf2 gene on specific mouse models (C57BL/6) led to reduced resistance due to impaired superoxide production, although overall survival was not affected thanks to compensatory mechanisms mediated by T cells. This finding highlighted the potential relevance of the NCF2 polymorphisms in TB susceptibility.
title: Systems genetics uncover new loci containing functional gene candidates in Mycobacterium tuberculosis-infected Diversity Outbred mice

finding: In the Look AHEAD Study, GLUL rs10911021 was found to have a prospective association with cardiovascular morbidity and mortality among individuals with type 2 diabetes, as reported by the Look AHEAD Research Group in 2016.
title: Identification of biomarkers and pathways for focal segmental glomerulosclerosis using next generation sequencing data and bioinformatics analysis

finding: The polymorphism rs3123554 in the cannabinoid receptor gene CNR2 revealed effects on body weight and insulin resistance in obese subjects, as reported by de Luis et al. in 2017.
title: Identification of biomarkers and pathways for focal segmental glomerulosclerosis using next generation sequencing data and bioinformatics analysis

finding: The SNP rs3024496 in IL10 was determined to be functional, affecting IL10 promoter activity with the C allele associated with higher expression levels. Its distribution of genotypes also varied significantly between Memphis and Nicaragua populations, correlating with hospitalization and symptom severity during influenza infection.
title: Integrated Drivers of Basal and Acute Immunity in Diverse Human Populations

finding: The irisin gene FNDC5 rs16835198 was associated with type 2 diabetes mellitus and diabetic nephropathy, which relates to metabolic conditions that could overlap with NAFLD.
title: Bioinformatics analysis of differentially expressed genes in non alcoholic fatty liver disease using next generation sequencing data

finding: The rs6025 variant (F5 c.1601G>A; p.Arg534Gln), commonly known as Factor V Leiden, was associated with significantly increased risk for venous thromboembolism (VTE). It exhibited higher frequencies among individuals of European ancestry. Multiple meta-analyses and case-control studies reported odds ratios for heterozygous carriers ranging from 2.2 to 4.93, and for homozygous carriers from 7.0 to 11.45, indicating a robust connection between this variant and VTE susceptibility. This finding was supported by both in vivo and in vitro functional studies demonstrating its impact on protein function, and thus, it was classified as an established risk allele for VTE.
title: Considerations for clinical curation, classification and reporting of low-penetrance and low effect size variants associated with disease risk

finding: The single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) rs1797052, located in the 5'-untranslated region of the PDZK1 gene, was linked to altered visual contrast sensitivity, an endophenotype associated with schizophrenia and autism spectrum disorder (ASD). In a genome-wide association study (GWAS), it was found that each additional copy of the minor allele of rs1797052 increased sensitivity by more than half a standard deviation, supporting the contribution of PDZK1 variation to visual deficits in multiple neurodevelopmental disorders.
title: Altered visual function in a larval zebrafish knockout of neurodevelopmental risk gene pdzk1

finding: The SNP rs1048238 was associated with hypertension as identified in a recent GWAS and affected a pG4 G-tract in the 3'UTR of HSPB7. Analysis revealed a substantial imbalance in the expression of the alternative allele in heterozygous individuals, suggesting that the pG4-disrupting variant led to increased expression of the alternative allele at this locus. This finding was in line with previous observations that 3'UTR pG4 eQTLs generally lead to increased gene expression, linking the SNP to its phenotypic associations with hypertension.
title: Integrative analysis reveals RNA G-Quadruplexes in UTRs are selectively constrained and enriched for functional associations

finding: This SNP was identified within some of the 94 iiSNPs with a higher average MAF and significance in analysis.
title: The forensic landscape and the population genetic analyses of Hainan Li based on massively parallel sequencing DNA profiling

finding: The SNP rs2642438, resulting in the p.A165T mutation in the mARC1 gene, was associated with protection from NASH and all-cause cirrhosis. This variant exhibited lower protein stability and showed significant mislocalization affecting its enzymatic function, despite being functionally similar to the wild type in certain in vitro conditions. This suggests a protective mechanism relevant to liver diseases.
title: Biochemical and functional characterization of the p.A165T missense variant of mitochondrial amidoxime-reducing component 1 in HepG2 cells

finding: The SNP rs12061439 was linked to the upregulation of SPON2 through the notch signaling pathway, which promoted tumor progression in gastric cancer, highlighting its role in cancer biology.
title: A consensus single-cell transcriptomic atlas of dermal fibroblast heterogeneity

finding: The SNP rs679515 was found to be an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) for Complement Receptor 1 (CR1) in oligodendrocytes, where the minor allele T (the Alzheimer’s disease (AD) risk allele) was associated with higher CR1 expression. This finding was validated through direct association tests and was shown to affect hematological parameters, including significant associations with hematocrit and other blood traits in AD subjects, aligning with neuropathology-specific interactions.
title: A public resource of single cell transcriptomes and multiscale networks from persons with and without Alzheimer’s disease

finding: SNP rs9429780 was identified as an eQTL for CR1 expression in oligodendrocytes, and conditional eQTL analyses indicated it had an independent signal of association, although not as strong as rs679515. Furthermore, it was cited in correlation with other hematological modifications, but the specific interactions were less detailed compared to those observed with rs679515.
title: A public resource of single cell transcriptomes and multiscale networks from persons with and without Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The variant rs148475636 (V459M) was associated with a significantly increased risk of chronic pain, particularly linked to hip pain and headache, with odds ratios of 56.1 and 30.5 respectively (P = 5.0×10^-5 and P = 3.95×10^-4). It exhibited a pleiotropic effect across multiple body sites, contributing to an overall significant risk in a meta-analysis with a meta odds ratio of 16 and P = 1.0×10^-10. This non-synonymous variant displayed a high CADD score of 8.0, indicating substantial pathogenicity and potential loss of function.
title: Satellite glial GPR37L1 regulates maresin and potassium channel signaling for pain control

finding: The variant rs767987863 (E296K) was linked to widespread pain, with an odds ratio of 1816 (P = 3.9×10^-4). However, a meta-analysis for this SNP did not yield significant results. This variant also showed a high CADD score of 27.3, suggesting it is deleterious, leading to a loss of protein stability, which was confirmed through in-silico prediction of protein stability across multiple simulations.
title: Satellite glial GPR37L1 regulates maresin and potassium channel signaling for pain control

finding: The SNP rs12040861 was associated with the expression of nucleolin-Sle A glycoforms, which served as E-selectin ligands. This association was particularly relevant to gastric cancer cells, where altered glycosylation played a role in tumor aggressiveness and could potentially serve as a targetable biomarker for precision oncology.
title: Metabolomics, Transcriptomics and Functional Glycomics Reveals Bladder Cancer Cells Plasticity and Enhanced Aggressiveness Facing Hypoxia and Glucose Deprivation

finding: The SNP rs12123563 was associated with immune regulation and cancer progression, particularly in the context of extracellular vesicles (EVs). In the study referenced, the SNP was linked to the interactions between cancer stem cells (CSC) and immune cells, specifically MHC-II+ macrophages and PD1+ T cells. This association suggested potential implications for combination therapies targeting CSCs and the immune microenvironment in improving outcomes for head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) patients.
title: Cancer stem cell-derived extracellular vesicles preferentially target MHC-II– macrophages and PD1+ T cells in the tumor microenvironment

finding: The SNP rs6656401 had been associated with reduced grey matter volume in the entorhinal cortex among young adults. This brain area is frequently affected in Alzheimer’s disease (AD) patients, indicating that the presence of this SNP could contribute to neuroanatomical changes linked to disease pathology.
title: A novel mouse model expressing human forms for complement receptors CR1 and CR2

finding: The SNP rs4844609 was reported to influence the rate of cognitive decline in Alzheimer’s disease, particularly in individuals carrying the APOE4 allele. It was associated with a single amino acid change in the C1q binding region of the CR1 protein, potentially affecting the clearance of amyloid beta (Aβ) and thereby impacting cognitive function.
title: A novel mouse model expressing human forms for complement receptors CR1 and CR2

finding: The rs324420 variant (FAAH C385A) was identified as a common genetic polymorphism in the FAAH gene that resulted in reduced FAAH expression, increased levels of anandamide, and an increased risk of obesity. Specifically, A-allele carriers exhibited elevated body mass index (BMI), correlating with the known role of anandamide in promoting feeding and energy storage. However, some studies documented inconsistent associations between rs324420 and obesity, suggesting that the environmental context may influence its impact on metabolic outcomes.
title: A Genetic Variant of Fatty Acid Amide Hydrolase (FAAH) Exacerbates Hormone-Mediated Orexigenic Feeding in Mice

finding: The SNP rs7528419 located in the SORT1 locus exhibited allelic expression imbalance (AEI) in liver samples, indicating a functional regulatory role in gene expression.
title: Interpreting coronary artery disease GWAS results: A functional genomics approach assessing biological significance

finding: The SNP rs12740374 marked a functional variant associated with SORT1, contributing to the complexity of CAD risk.
title: Interpreting coronary artery disease GWAS results: A functional genomics approach assessing biological significance

finding: The pro-autoimmune allele rs2476601 of PTPN22 was positively associated with a lower incidence of melanoma and other malignant neoplasms of the skin (C43-C44) in the Gene Atlas UK biobank population, indicating its influence on tumor immunity.
title: Pro-autoimmune allele of tyrosine phosphatase, PTPN22, enhances tumor immunity

finding: The SNP rs12123556 was associated with modifying adaptive therapy to enhance competitive suppression in cancer treatment. Previous studies indicated that genetic variations at this locus may influence the efficacy of adaptive therapies and their ability to maintain drug-sensitive populations, which is critical in preventing drug resistance in cancer.
title: Containing Cancer with Personalized Minimum Effective Dose

finding: The study identified rs646776 as a significant trans-pQTL for the SORT1 locus, which modified coronary artery disease (CAD) risk by altering plasma LDL cholesterol levels through regulation of hepatic SORT1 expression. This finding highlighted the role of rs646776 in CAD risk despite a lack of support for a direct causal effect from GRN on CAD, indicating that GRN operates downstream in the relevant biological pathway.
title: Integrative analysis of the plasma proteome and polygenic risk of cardiometabolic diseases

finding: The rs273259 SNP, located within the IFI44L gene, was identified as a top-hit in a genome-wide association study regarding adverse responses to a live virus vaccine (MMR). It was reported that cells carrying the risk allele of rs273259 exhibited reduced expression levels of IFI44 and altered splice isoform levels of IFI44L. These findings suggested that polymorphisms, such as rs273259, could influence the predisposition to a severe response during viral infections.
title: Interferon-induced Protein-44 and Interferon-induced Protein 44-like restrict replication of Respiratory Syncytial Virus

finding: The SNP rs12061521 was linked to enhanced ovarian cancer proliferation, invasion, and chemoresistance through mechanotransduction mediated by CDC42 in a 3D bioreactor. This finding demonstrated the role of mechanical stimulation on cancer cell behavior, emphasizing the significance of the microenvironment in cancer progression.
title: Application of sequential cyclic compression on cancer cells in a flexible microdevice

finding: CFH rs1061170 demonstrated significant ASE within 2 out of 6 intermediate AMD RPE samples and 1 out of 7 normal RPE samples, indicating its relevance in different AMD stages.
title: Patterns of gene expression and allele-specific expression vary among macular tissues and clinical stages of Age-related Macular Degeneration

finding: The study reported significant ASE for CFH rs1061147 in 5 out of 6 intermediate AMD RPE samples, 3 out of 4 neovascular AMD RPE samples, and 7 out of 7 normal RPE samples, emphasizing its differential gene regulation in AMD.
title: Patterns of gene expression and allele-specific expression vary among macular tissues and clinical stages of Age-related Macular Degeneration

finding: The SNP rs12040822 was linked to therapy-induced senescence, where it was revealed that drug-induced senescent cells could contribute to drug resistance in cancers. This finding emerged from research focusing on the senescence phenotype exhibited by persister cells, suggesting that modulating this phenotype could combat therapy resistance.
title: mTOR is a Major Determinant of Chemosensitivity

finding: The SNP rs61229077 was located in the CR1 gene on chromosome 1 and showed a strong association with adaptive features conferring Malaria resistance in the Bouyei population.
title: Malaria resistance-related biological adaptation and complex evolutionary footprints of Tai-Kadai people inferred from 796 genomes

finding: The SNP rs61822977 on chromosome 11 was noted for its high PBS value and exhibited robust biological adaptation, correlating with the adaptive immune responses in the Bouyei population.
title: Malaria resistance-related biological adaptation and complex evolutionary footprints of Tai-Kadai people inferred from 796 genomes

finding: The SNP rs7542544 associated with the CR1 gene exhibited high frequencies in Southern China and Malaria-endemic regions, supporting notions of strong natural selection linked to Malaria resistance.
title: Malaria resistance-related biological adaptation and complex evolutionary footprints of Tai-Kadai people inferred from 796 genomes

finding: The SNP rs35761884 was connected with mood disorders (p=5.3×10−7) and tobacco use disorder (p=1.15×10−6) in a PheWAS, positioned in LINC01360.
title: Genomic Characterization of Posttraumatic Stress Disorder in a Large US Military Veteran Sample

finding: The SNP rs12071971 was positively associated with the JAK-STAT signaling pathway in cancer, as discussed by Brooks and Putoczki in their 2020 publication. This finding was significant within the context of integrative gene expression and protein-protein interaction analyses, particularly when examining their effects across 27 cancer types.
title: Integrated analysis of gene expression and protein-protein interaction with tensor decomposition

finding: The SNP rs12061579 was associated with enhanced activity in the context of deubiquitinating enzyme regulation, which was linked to the therapeutic potential in treating cancer through modulation of proteins like TP53 and c-Myc. This finding was confirmed through systematic mining of functional genomic databases, establishing a connection to cancer therapies involving DUBs.
title: Integrating multi-omics data reveals function and therapeutic potential of deubiquitinating enzymes

finding: The SNP rs12082163 was associated with the study of EF-24, which elucidated its effects in triggering apoptotic cell death via p38 MAPK activation in acute myeloid leukemia cells, providing insights into the therapeutic mechanisms of the curcumin analogue.
title: Genomic Discovery of EF-24 Targets Unveils Antitumorigenic Mechanisms in Leukemia Cells

finding: Linkage of the SNP rs12082037 was established with the investigation of S100 proteins in cancer, suggesting their role in the cellular responses that may affect tumor signaling pathways, particularly in the context of EF-24 treatment.
title: Genomic Discovery of EF-24 Targets Unveils Antitumorigenic Mechanisms in Leukemia Cells

finding: At SNP rs2814778, which corresponds to the erythrocyte-specific Duffy null allele Fy<sup>ES</sup>, high frequencies were identified in Omani individuals. This allele has been associated with protection against <italic>P. vivax</italic> malaria. The allele demonstrated strong positive selection with a selection coefficient estimated at 0.031 and was predicted to have originated at least 59 generations ago. This finding was corroborated by genetic predictions aligning with Duffy serological phenotypes observed in Omani individuals.
title: Adaptive admixture at ACKR1 (the Duffy locus) may have shaped Plasmodium vivax prevalence in Oman

finding: The SNP rs12030650 was associated with the regulation of mitochondrial respiration in chronic lymphocytic leukemia, as described in a study exploring its correlations with prognostic markers. This finding suggested that the presence of this SNP might influence metabolic pathways relevant to inflammation and immune responses.
title: Omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids modify glucose metabolism in THP-1 monocytes

finding: This SNP was significantly associated with severe UC cases only, showing an odds ratio of 1.82, highlighting genetic differences in severity.
title: An extremes of phenotype approach confirms significant genetic heterogeneity in patients with ulcerative colitis

finding: The study noted the protective role of the R381Q polymorphism (rs11209026) in the IL-23R gene related to immune-mediated diseases. This finding was particularly relevant in the context of T-helper (T<sub>H</sub>17) mediated inflammatory diseases as the IL-23 pathway is crucial in regulating T<sub>H</sub>17 cell differentiation and activity. The polymorphism was implicated in modifying the risk of developing autoimmune conditions.
title: Serum Amyloid A Proteins Induce Pathogenic TH17 Cells and Promote Inflammatory Disease

finding: The SNP rs12041050 was associated with the DNA damage response (DDR) in a study examining the role of cryptochromes (CRYs) and UBP12/13 deubiquitinases. It was found that CRYs are required for DNA repair mechanisms, particularly in the context of UV-induced DNA damage. This SNP was linked to variations in DNA repair capacity observed in different plant genotypes, thus contributing to the understanding of DNA damage and repair processes as referenced in the study on the management of DNA damage in cancers.
title: Cryptochromes and UBP12/13 deubiquitinases antagonistically regulate DNA damage response in Arabidopsis

finding: The SNP rs2476601 in PTPN22 was characterized as a significant risk factor for Type 1 diabetes (T1D). The minor allele (R620W) encoded by this polymorphism was found to blunt T cell receptor (TCR) and B cell receptor (BCR) signaling in humans, impacting immune response pathways leading to the disease's pathogenesis.
title: Use of Induced Pluripotent Stem Cells to Build Isogenic Systems and Investigate Type 1 Diabetes

finding: The SNP rs6667279 was identified in the eQTL fine-mapping analysis of TDRKH, where it showed a strong association (SPIP > 0.9). This SNP was linked to increased gene expression related to CAD risk.
title: Analyzing and Reconciling Colocalization and Transcriptome-wide Association Studies from the Perspective of Inferential Reproducibility

finding: The SNP rs1521185 was also identified in the eQTL fine-mapping analysis of TDRKH. It was associated with strong variant-level colocalization (RCP = 0.92) and exhibited an inverse association where increased expression was linked to decreased CAD risk.
title: Analyzing and Reconciling Colocalization and Transcriptome-wide Association Studies from the Perspective of Inferential Reproducibility

finding: The rs11249215 SNP in the promoter of the RUNX3 gene was associated with a significant shift in the gut microbiome of both AS patients and healthy controls, with a combined P-value of 0.0097. It was determined that the alteration in microbiome composition depended on whether the genotype was heterozygous or homozygous, where the homozygous genotype (GG) exhibited a more substantial shift. The study re-confirmed the influence of this SNP across two independent cohorts and highlighted that while the SNP did not affect the abundance of previously documented dysbiotic bacteria, it did impact species richness and community composition, suggesting potential involvement in AS pathogenesis linked to the gut microbiome.
title: Shotgun metagenomics reveals an enrichment of potentially cross-reactive bacterial epitopes in ankylosing spondylitis patients, as well as the effects of TNFi therapy and the host’s genotype upon microbiome composition

finding: This SNP was previously shown to alter enhancer function for the shear stress-induced transcript PPAP2B, serving as a positive control for validating functional non-coding SNPs associated with vascular disease.
title: Functional non-coding SNPs in human endothelial cells fine-map vascular trait associations

finding: The missense SNP rs11803731 in TCHH was significantly associated with male pattern baldness and hair curl traits. It acted independently of the TCHH VNTR length, explaining around 4% of the variance in hair curl phenotypes.
title: Protein-coding repeat polymorphisms strongly shape diverse human phenotypes

finding: The SNP rs12061419 was associated with lipid metabolism, particularly in the context of hepatocellular carcinoma, underscoring its relevance in hepatic lipid regulation and potential implications for understanding cancer progression related to fatty acid metabolism.
title: ATGL-dependent white adipose tissue lipolysis controls hepatocyte PPARα activity

finding: The ASCA-SNP rs2774290 exhibited correlations with the integrity of several major RNMs, suggesting its role in influencing the cellular pluripotency state transitions in hiPSCs.
title: Unsupervised Machine Learning Identifies Chromatin Accessibility Regulatory Networks that Define Cell State Transitions in Pluripotency

finding: The ASCA-SNP rs188702962 was found to disrupt the integrity of major RNMs, further implicating its potential effect on the diversity of pluripotency states in hiPSCs.
title: Unsupervised Machine Learning Identifies Chromatin Accessibility Regulatory Networks that Define Cell State Transitions in Pluripotency

finding: SNP rs58650325, located near the FCER1A gene, was associated with initiating the allergic response, noted with a p-value of 1.57e-163 and a beta value of -0.097. This association underscored its relevance in the context of white blood cell count.
title: Low generalizability of polygenic scores in African populations due to genetic and environmental diversity

finding: This variant was linked to total cholesterol levels and was located adjacent to the USP1 and DOCK7 genes, contributing to the understanding of genetic influences on lipid regulation.
title: Genetic impacts on DNA methylation help elucidate regulatory genomic processes

finding: It co-localised with methylation changes associated with the DOCK7 gene, reinforcing its significance in pathways regulating plasma lipid levels.
title: Genetic impacts on DNA methylation help elucidate regulatory genomic processes

finding: The study highlighted the significance of the SNP rs11122002 in relation to type I interferon signaling and its impact on versican expression in macrophages. Specifically, this finding was contextualized within the framework of macrophage-derived versican serving as a type I interferon-stimulated gene, thus linking the SNP to inflammatory response mechanisms.
title: Regulation of Versican Expression in Macrophages is Mediated by Canonical Type I Interferon Signaling via ISGF3

finding: The splice donor variant rs146249964 was reported to be associated with mCAs at the MPL locus, replicating earlier findings with a high odds ratio (OR = 296) and a p-value of 9.5e-8. This variant was significant in the context of clonal expansions and was previously linked to congenital amegakaryocytic thrombocytopenia, particularly in the Ashkenazi Jewish population.
title: Mosaic chromosomal alterations in blood across ancestries via whole-genome sequencing

finding: The SNP rs2230624 was identified as a lead genetic variant at the TNFRSF8 locus associated with asthma and the combined phenotype of asthma, hay fever, and eczema. It was a missense variant causing a cysteine to tyrosine substitution and was predicted to be 'probably damaging', with a role in the development of allergic asthma.
title: Genome-wide association analysis of 350,000 Caucasians from the UK Biobank identifies novel loci for asthma, hay fever and eczema

finding: The SNP rs12067046 was discovered as part of the HFpEF loci, associated with its pathophysiology, located 500 Kb downstream of the PLXNA2 gene, which is involved in the development of blood vessels.
title: Biological Pathways and Gene Networks Link Inflammation and Vascular Remodeling to Both Heart Failure with Preserved and Reduced Ejection Fraction in Women across Ethnicities

finding: The SNP rs114553497 was associated with HFpEF, with proximity to ACTA1, a gene related to smooth muscle contraction, reinforcing its relevance in cardiac function.
title: Biological Pathways and Gene Networks Link Inflammation and Vascular Remodeling to Both Heart Failure with Preserved and Reduced Ejection Fraction in Women across Ethnicities

finding: This SNP, located in the PARP1 gene, was reported to be associated with melanoma susceptibility specifically in a Spanish population. The finding indicated that individuals with certain alleles of this SNP had a higher risk of developing melanoma, suggesting its relevance in understanding genetic predispositions to skin cancer.
title: Multi-omic signatures identify pan-cancer classes of tumors beyond tissue of origin

finding: The SNP rs6699825 was identified as the top associated eQTL for ADAR, explaining 5.5% of the variability in total editing rates (p-value 3.46e-4). This SNP's effects on both ADAR expression and CES total editing rate were detailed in the analysis, providing insight into its role in RNA editing.
title: Genome-wide analysis of consistently RNA edited sites in human blood reveals interactions with mRNA processing genes and suggests correlations with cell types and biological variables

finding: The SNP rs11265393 was identified in association with regional asymmetries in left-handed individuals, linking it to heritable traits related to hand preference and potentially language. This finding emerged from a sample of imaging-genetic data drawn from a significantly large population, which connected genetic factors to structural brain characteristics.
title: Left-handedness and its genetic influences are associated with structural asymmetries mapped across the cerebral cortex in 31,864 individuals

finding: The SNP rs66513715, for which rs11265393 served as a proxy, was also associated with regional surface area asymmetries in the brains of left-handed individuals. This association highlighted its relevance to the genetic architecture underpinning hand preference and its neuroanatomical correlates.
title: Left-handedness and its genetic influences are associated with structural asymmetries mapped across the cerebral cortex in 31,864 individuals

finding: The common MUC1 polymorphism rs4072037 was associated with altered bone density in humans. This finding suggests that variations in the MUC1 gene might influence skeletal characteristics and calcium homeostasis.
title: Influence of MUC1 on trafficking of TRPV5 and TRPV6 and in vivo Ca2+ homeostasis

finding: The variant rs9332599 was designated as the lead SNP in the F5 locus, with a meta-P-value of 7.17 × 10^-12. This finding was novel and highlighted its potential influence on the cytokine network.
title: Multivariate genome-wide association analysis of a cytokine network reveals variants with widespread immune, haematological and cardiometabolic pleiotropy

finding: The MVA-significance replication revealed a multi-trait association for rs905938, indicating significant pleiotropic effects across six traits analyzed in the GIANT consortium. This finding supported the hypothesis that single genetic variations can affect multiple traits.
title: Beyond power: Multivariate discovery, replication, and interpretation of pleiotropic loci using summary association statistics

finding: The rs4603 SNV was observed in the gene PSMB4 and analyzed for its cellular expressed single nucleotide variant (sceSNV) frequency across neuroblastoma sample types. The study revealed a germline homozygous variant in the sample SAMN12799266, a heterozygous variant in samples SAMN12799264 and SAMN12799263, and an absence of the variant in sample SAMN12799269. This was visually represented using UMAP projections, where the VAF_RNA showed red color intensity corresponding to the differential expression of the variant across the samples.
title: SCExecute: cell barcode-stratified analyses of scRNA-seq data

finding: The LYPLAL1 rs12137855 SNP was linked to obesity and metabolic dysfunction, further establishing genetic contributions to these conditions.
title: The Identification of Key Genes and Biological Pathways in Cardiac Arrest by Integrated Bioinformatics and Next Generation Sequencing Data Analysis

finding: The study revealed that the genotype at the rs12049454 SNP was correlated with changes in chromatin accessibility, observed in both non-infected and flu-infected cells. This finding highlighted the impact of this specific SNP on the chromatin state, serving as a significant marker for understanding genotype-chromatin interactions in the context of viral infection.
title: EpiVar Browser: advanced exploration of epigenomics data under controlled access

finding: The interactome analysis of rs11552449 implicated HIPK1 as a novel gene target associated with SLE, linking it to modulation of IL-21 production in TFH cells.
title: Human follicular helper T cell promoter connectomes reveal novel genes and regulatory elements at SLE GWAS loci

finding: SNP rs11805303 was associated with susceptibility to cutaneous leishmaniasis in individuals infected with Leishmania guyanensis, emphasizing its role in infectious disease.
title: Bioinformatics and next generation data analysis reveals the potential role of inflammation in sepsis and its associated complications

finding: The SNP rs2274907 demonstrated influence on genetic susceptibility to nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, indicating its role in metabolic liver conditions.
title: Bioinformatics and next generation data analysis reveals the potential role of inflammation in sepsis and its associated complications

finding: The SNP rs17712208 was identified as potentially regulatory at the PROX1 locus, with a significant impact on H3K27ac mark loss and confirmed through luciferase assays to repress enhancer activity linked to T2D risk.
title: Deep learning models predict regulatory variants in pancreatic islets and refine type 2 diabetes association signals

finding: The SNP rs12740374 exhibited significant allelic heterogeneity driven by sex, with female cohorts from East Africa showing greater effect sizes and was also associated with both ancestry and urban status.
title: Accounting for heterogeneity due to environmental sources in meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies

finding: The SNP rs28362286 was identified as genome-wide significant for LDL-cholesterol and showed allelic heterogeneity driven by environmental factors.
title: Accounting for heterogeneity due to environmental sources in meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies

finding: The SNP rs11576986 displayed heterogeneity due to ancestry alone, contributing to the found associations in the study.
title: Accounting for heterogeneity due to environmental sources in meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies

finding: The rs12143842 SNP, located in the NOS1AP locus, was established as the top QT interval-associated SNP. It was linked to increased SCD risk, particularly among female victims with non-ischemic disease, displaying an odds ratio (OR) of 1.37 (95% CI, 1.07-1.75) for SCD risk. Mendelian randomization provided additional support for the causal relationship between prolonged QT interval and SCD, with an odds ratio of 3.60 (95% CI, 1.22-10.49) for a standard deviation increase in QT interval. The overall association was more pronounced in non-ischemic than ischemic disease cases, indicating a potential sex- and disease-specific influence on SCD risk.
title: The effect of sex and underlying disease on the genetic association of QT interval and sudden cardiac death

finding: The SNP rs12030581 was linked to the effects of MCT1-mediated cellular import of lactate on the stemness properties of human pancreatic adenocarcinoma cells, demonstrating its potential role in tumor biology and cancer metabolism.
title: ME3BP-7 is a targeted cytotoxic agent that rapidly kills pancreatic cancer cells expressing high levels of monocarboxylate transporter MCT1

finding: The SNP rs12092546 was identified as a significant factor related to the CCAAT/Enhancer-Binding Protein Delta (C/EBPδ), which was characterized as a previously unrecognized tumor suppressor. The presence of this SNP limited the oncogenic potential of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma cells, indicating its critical role in cancer biology and the potential regulatory impact in gene networks associated with this disease.
title: A Data-Driven Optimization Method for Coarse-Graining Gene Regulatory Networks

finding: The SNP rs551359143 was identified in intron 10 of the PIK3C2B gene and was linked to S-HSCR risk. The A>T conversion at this locus was found exclusively in patients and was predicted to disrupt the binding site for NFIA, a regulatory factor involved in neural stem cell differentiation. Deleting a 171 bp region adjacent to this variant led to significantly increased expression of PIK3C2B, indicating that the disruption of NFIA binding resulted in aberrant gene expression related to HSCR.
title: Whole-genome analysis of noncoding genetic variations identifies multigranular regulatory element perturbations associated with Hirschsprung disease

finding: The SNP rs1047303 was identified as a variant in the gene encoding HSD3B1, which was associated with resistance to androgen deprivation therapies in prostate cancer. This variation allowed approximately 30% of the population to produce pro-proliferative androgens independently, thus contributing to the aggressiveness of castration-resistant prostate cancers.
title: SDR enzymes oxidize specific lipidic alkynylcarbinols into cytotoxic protein-reactive species

finding: The SNP rs638348 was included in the FDA5 PRS and linked to a significant positive effect on obesity-related metrics. It was located within the gene RHOU, associated with type 2 diabetes.
title: Polygenic risk score based on weight gain trajectories is predictive of childhood obesity

finding: The study reported a heterozygous coding SNV in the <italic>LMNA</italic> gene identified as rs4641 (C>T), where Patient cells exhibited primarily monoallelic expression from only the normal allele. This underexpression of <italic>LMNA</italic> in Patient-derived cells was significant as it related to the context of dilated cardiomyopathy, emphasizing the impact of Lamin A/C haploinsufficiency on cardiac cells.
title: LMNA-Related Dilated Cardiomyopathy: Single-Cell Transcriptomics during Patient-derived iPSC Differentiation Support Cell type and Lineage-specific Dysregulation of Gene Expression and Development for Cardiomyocytes and Epicardium-Derived Cells with Lamin A/C Haploinsufficiency

finding: The study demonstrated that the SNP rs2814778, also known as the Duffy-null allele (FY*O), was under strong selection in the admixed population of Cabo Verde due to its protective role against the malaria parasite Plasmodium vivax. This protective allele was nearly fixed in West African populations, whereas it was rare elsewhere. The finding indicated that the Duffy-null allele emerged as an adaptation mechanism against malaria infection by disrupting the binding of an erythroid-specific transcription factor, leading to reduced Duffy antigen expression and thereby conferring protection against P. vivax.
title: Rapid adaptation to malaria facilitated by admixture in the human population of Cabo Verde

finding: The SNP rs12123723 was identified as significant in relation to the CCR2/MCP-1 chemokine pathway and its role in lung adenocarcinoma. This finding highlighted the potential impact of CCR2-related genetic variations on tumor microenvironment composition and inflammatory responses in lung cancer contexts.
title: Molecular determinants of antagonist interactions with chemokine receptors CCR2 and CCR5

finding: The SNP rs11589479 was shown to regulate the skipping of the 19th exon in ADAM15 across all tested tissues. ADAM15 is involved in inflammation and is associated with Crohn's Disease.
title: Junction-skipping regulation in complex disease

finding: The SNP rs267738 was identified as a glycated haemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) associated variant regulating junction-skipping in CERS2.
title: Junction-skipping regulation in complex disease

finding: This synonymous variant in <italic>MTFR1L</italic> was associated with mean reaction time while identified as an eQTL influencing gene expression relevant to cognition.
title: Exome-wide analysis reveals role of LRP1 and additional novel loci in cognition

finding: This missense variant in <italic>AMIGO1</italic> was linked to episodic memory and acted as an eQTL influencing cognitive relevant genes in the brain.
title: Exome-wide analysis reveals role of LRP1 and additional novel loci in cognition

finding: This intronic variant in <italic>MAST2</italic> was associated with visual attention and shown to control gene expression related to cognitive processing.
title: Exome-wide analysis reveals role of LRP1 and additional novel loci in cognition

finding: The SNP rs12123556 was identified in the context of tumor natural selection dynamics. It was linked to adaptive chemotherapy responses, particularly influencing the balance among healthy, sensitive, and resistant populations of cells during chemotherapy treatment. Findings indicated its role in managing competitive release, thereby avoiding chemo-resistance under adaptive therapy schedules. This research contributed to understanding how genetic variations can impact treatment outcomes in cancer.
title: Stochastic competitive release and adaptive chemotherapy

finding: This SNP was identified in the CDC20 gene, which encodes the cell-division cycle protein 20. It was reported in association with acute lymphoblastic leukemia, indicating a significant clinical relevance in the context of protein-RNA interactions through the POP-seq methodology.
title: Transcriptome-wide high-throughput mapping of protein-RNA occupancy profiles using POP-seq

finding: The SNP rs12071802 was associated with the immunogenic potential of <italic>M. brumae</italic>, as demonstrated in the study by Noguera-Ortega et al. (2020). This SNP highlighted the comparison of <italic>M. brumae</italic>'s immunogenic properties, which were found to be as high as those of <italic>M. bovis</italic> BCG. However, it was noted that the genomic content related to T cell and B cell antigens in <italic>M. brumae</italic> was significantly lower than in <italic>M. bovis</italic> BCG, indicating that while the immunogenic potential exists, the overall antigenic diversity and profile might differ.
title: Genomic analysis of Mycobacterium brumae sustains its nonpathogenic and immunogenic phenotype

finding: This SNP was present in Patient 19, associated with Dyssegmental dysplasia as a compound heterozygous mutation, and had an allele frequency of 0.00084, highlighting its clinical relevance.
title: Rare disease research workflow using multilayer networks elucidates the molecular determinants of severity in Congenital Myasthenic Syndromes

finding: The SNP rs2843128 was associated with the CDK11A gene splicing, demonstrating colocalization with GWAS data (CLPP=0.155), which suggested involvement in the COPD association.
title: Analysis of genetically driven alternative splicing identifies FBXO38 as a novel COPD susceptibility gene

finding: The SNP rs2843126 was shown to be significantly associated with splicing of CDK11A, indicating that it could be a relevant variant influencing COPD risk through modulation of alternative splicing.
title: Analysis of genetically driven alternative splicing identifies FBXO38 as a novel COPD susceptibility gene

finding: The SNP rs10798002 was identified as the lead SNP associated with telomere length (TL) in the SWT1 gene. This finding emerged from a detailed analysis that included a Manhattan plot representation highlighting its significance, indicating a notable connection between this variant and TL modulation.
title: Unraveling the causal genes and transcriptomic determinants of human telomere length

finding: The SNP rs12061584 showed a correlation with the optimization of light delivery in PDT. The study indicated that this SNP could affect blood circulation parameters and consequently influence personalized therapy strategies for patients undergoing PDT.
title: In vivo, online label-free monitoring of heterogenous oxygen utilization during phototherapy with real-time ultrasound-guided photoacoustic imaging

finding: The SNP rs12092579 was found to be associated with the modulation of metabolism and polarization of tumor-associated macrophages. This finding was particularly relevant in the context of lung adenocarcinoma, where the tumor microenvironment plays a crucial role in tumor progression and therapeutic responses.
title: Spatiotemporal Profiling Unveiling the Cellular Organization Patterns and Local Protumoral Immune Microenvironment Remodeling in Early Lung Adenocarcinoma Progression

finding: The synonymous SNP rs3736907 in the CD101 gene was found in the Chilean cohort, classified as under selection post-admixture with an AdaptMix P-value of 1.05×10^-9, associated with neutrophil and total white blood cell counts.
title: Disentangling signatures of selection before and after European colonization in Latin Americans

finding: In the Mexican cohort, SNP rs1171148 was identified in the BRINP3 gene and suggested to be under selection with an AdaptMix P-value of 2.31×10^-8, associated with body mass index and hip circumference.
title: Disentangling signatures of selection before and after European colonization in Latin Americans

finding: The SNP rs2230288, which corresponds to the missense variant p.E365K in the <italic>GBA</italic> gene, was associated with higher odds of cognitive impairment at baseline (OR 2.05 [1.33, 3.18], P-value = 1.3E-3), faster development of cognitive impairment (HR 2.58 [1.71, 3.89], P-value = 5.5E-6), and a lower MoCA score over time.
title: Genome-wide association study of Parkinson’s disease progression biomarkers in 12 longitudinal patients’ cohorts

finding: The SNP rs75548401, which encodes the variant p.T408M in the <italic>GBA</italic> gene, was associated with a faster rate of progression to Hoehn and Yahr stage 3 (HR 2.35 [1.58, 3.49], P-value = 2.5E-5). This information further supports the relationship of <italic>GBA</italic> variants with Parkinson's disease progression.
title: Genome-wide association study of Parkinson’s disease progression biomarkers in 12 longitudinal patients’ cohorts

finding: The SNP rs12071887 was examined in relation to cancer-associated fibroblasts and their role in tumorigenesis. The connection drawn in the publication highlighted the influence of this SNP on tumor microenvironments, possibly contributing to tumorigenesis opportunities in melanoma. The research underscored the need to consider such genetic variants when analyzing complex cancer mechanisms involving fibroblast activity.
title: Uncovering Minimal Pathways in Melanoma Initiation

finding: The variant rs2356553 was associated with the expression of MAST2, demonstrating significant interaction effects across different chondrocyte subtypes.
title: Comprehensive profiling of transcriptional regulation in cartilage reveals pathogenesis of osteoarthritis

finding: rs1408829 was linked to the expression of TOR3A, with significant interaction identified in different chondrocyte subtypes, emphasizing the regulatory role in cartilage.
title: Comprehensive profiling of transcriptional regulation in cartilage reveals pathogenesis of osteoarthritis

finding: The SNP rs12082154 was associated with melanoma phenotype switching and treatment resistance as discussed in the context of the research by Tang et al. This study identified various EMT-inducing transcription factors that drive melanoma's phenotypic changes, suggesting that this SNP may contribute to these processes and potentially affect the response to therapies in BRAF-mutant melanoma patients.
title: The CoREST Repressor Complex Mediates Phenotype Switching and Therapy Resistance in Melanoma

finding: The SCZ risk allele rs12033824-T disrupted the binding motif of ZBTB6 within distal fCRE1 at the TRAPPC3 locus, which played a role in neuronal differentiation.
title: Functional characterization of gene regulatory elements and neuropsychiatric disease-associated risk loci in iPSCs and iPSC-derived neurons

finding: The SNP rs12123752 was associated with the regulation of pro-inflammatory cytokines involved in the formation of the pre-metastatic niche (PMN) in Triple Negative Breast Cancer (TNBC). The findings indicated a significant correlation between this SNP and the upregulation of CCL2 expression, which is mediated by EYA3 and linked to a decrease in cytotoxic Natural Killer (NK) cells at the PMN, suggesting its role in promoting metastasis in breast cancer. This association underscored the SNP's relevance to the modulation of the innate immune response and the metastatic process in TNBC.
title: An EYA3/NF-κB/CCL2 signaling axis suppresses cytotoxic NK cells in the pre-metastatic niche to promote triple negative breast cancer metastasis

finding: The SNP rs199703974 was significantly associated with QTc interval trajectory probability, supporting its relevance as a variant linked to cardiovascular outcomes.
title: Trajectory analysis of cardiovascular phenotypes from biobank data uncovers novel genetic associations

finding: The SNP rs4536035 was identified as a significant variant related to the QTc interval, with an eQTL analysis revealing an association with the WLS gene in coronary artery, reflecting its potential role in cardiovascular function.
title: Trajectory analysis of cardiovascular phenotypes from biobank data uncovers novel genetic associations

finding: The SNP rs4506498 was significantly associated with QTc interval trajectory probability and was part of an LD block with rs4536035, reinforcing its relevance in the context of heart failure.
title: Trajectory analysis of cardiovascular phenotypes from biobank data uncovers novel genetic associations

finding: The SNP rs4244620 showed suggestive significance in association with QTc interval and was implicated in enhancer activity related to WLS, indicating its potential role in cardiac regulatory mechanisms.
title: Trajectory analysis of cardiovascular phenotypes from biobank data uncovers novel genetic associations

finding: The SNP rs112611436, previously associated with QT interval, showed relevance but did not have new findings in this analysis.
title: Trajectory analysis of cardiovascular phenotypes from biobank data uncovers novel genetic associations

finding: The SNP rs12124078, associated with kidney function, showed significant dominance deviation with a p-value of less than 5e-8. This finding suggested a small contribution of dominance variance explaining the trait, consistent with the overall trend of negligible dominance variance for most traits analyzed.
title: Estimation of non-additive genetic variance in human complex traits from a large sample of unrelated individuals

finding: The SNP rs12040964 was originally identified in a study by Menendez et al. (2020), in which it was associated with SOX2 expression and transcriptional activity that delineated a subpopulation of cancer stem cells in sarcoma, indicating its relevance to cancer stem cell behavior.
title: WDR5 represents a therapeutically exploitable target for cancer stem cells in glioblastoma

finding: The WNT3A rs752107(C > T) polymorphism was linked to an increased risk of essential hypertension, potentially impacting kidney health indirectly.
title: Identification of novel prognostic targets in acute kidney injury using bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The association of rs2280275 was noted in the context of cardiovascular disease, which could indirectly influence renal health.
title: Identification of novel prognostic targets in acute kidney injury using bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: This SNP was associated with Rikenellaceae and replicated at nominal significance, confirming previously reported associations.
title: Inter-determination of blood metabolite levels and gut microbiome supported by Mendelian randomization

finding: The T allele of rs1338681 reduced transcription factor (TF) binding affinity by disrupting a CTCF binding motif. This disruption was significant enough to be associated with a reduced binding score, demonstrating how genetic variation at this locus influenced TF activity.
title: Quantitative assessment of association between noncoding variants and transcription factor binding

finding: Found associated exclusively with tumor grade (P=3.09×10⁻³).
title: Common breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: Identified as significantly associated with tumor grade (P=1.84×10⁻²).
title: Common breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: The rs5275 polymorphism in PTGS2 was associated with an increased risk of invasive ovarian carcinoma when combined with the use of NSAIDs, suggesting its relevance in cancer susceptibility.
title: Screening and identification of key biomarkers associated with endometriosis using bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The rs3753581 variant in NPPB was implicated in the regulation of pulse pressure hypertension, involving several transcription factors including IRF1 and PRDM1.
title: Screening and identification of key biomarkers associated with endometriosis using bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The rs689466 polymorphism in PTGS2 was connected with breast cancer recurrence specifically in obese patients, suggesting its relevance in cancer prognosis.
title: Screening and identification of key biomarkers associated with endometriosis using bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The CYP2J2 rs2280275 genetic variant was linked to a risk for diabetic nephropathy in Egyptian type 2 diabetic patients.
title: Screening and identification of key biomarkers associated with endometriosis using bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The SNP rs798000 (PIP=1.00) showed significant overlap with an accessible chromatin peak primarily in T cells (Wilcoxon p=2.35e-05) and was associated with the T_A-2: CD4+ PD-1+ TFH/TPH chromatin class. This finding linked rs798000 to the gene CD2, a co-stimulatory receptor expressed on T and NK cells, suggesting a potential regulatory role in the JAK/STAT pathway relevant in RA.
title: The Chromatin Landscape of Pathogenic Transcriptional Cell States in Rheumatoid Arthritis

finding: The SNP rs11209051 was found overlapping with a chromatin peak accessible in T cells, specifically linked to the IL12RB2 gene. The statistical analysis (Wilcoxon T versus non-T class one-sided p=4.17e-04) indicated a significant association with T cell chromatin classes, underscoring its potential role in RA pathogenesis.
title: The Chromatin Landscape of Pathogenic Transcriptional Cell States in Rheumatoid Arthritis

finding: The SNP rs3010003 was identified in a study discussing the role of hepatic cytochrome P450 2E1 (CYP2E1) in metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD), previously known as non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). Increased activity of CYP2E1 was linked to higher oxidative stress and the likelihood of acetaminophen-induced hepatotoxicity in obese individuals with fatty liver. The findings suggested that the genetic variations related to rs3010003 might be involved in regulating CYP2E1 activity, impacting susceptibility to steatosis and hepatotoxicity from acetaminophen.
title: Fatty acid-mediated induction of CYP2E1 activity in HepaRG cells is not systematically associated with exacerbated acetaminophen cytotoxicity

finding: The SNP rs12137855 was associated with ultrasound-defined non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) in a Chinese Han population, suggesting that it had a significant impact on metabolic traits related to liver health. This finding was consistent with the effects observed in the mouse model where knockout of Lyplal1 demonstrated reduced liver triglycerides and steatosis, indicating a relationship between this SNP and fat distribution or metabolic processes.
title: Knockout of murine Lyplal1 confers sex-specific protection against diet-induced obesity

finding: The SNP rs12123586 was found to be associated with the IL-2 and IL-15 signaling pathways, which were relevant to the study’s focus on improving anti-tumor immune responses. Specifically, the research pointed to how these interleukin pathways influenced the efficacy of treatments such as RT + IL15c and their dependence on T cell functionalities during the immune response.
title: IL15/IL15Rα complex induces an anti-tumor immune response following radiation therapy only in the absence of Tregs and fails to induce expansion of progenitor TCF1+ CD8 T cells

finding: The SNP rs12082114 was associated with oncogenic processes in colorectal cancer, specifically related to the susceptibility of Serine 45-deleted β-Catenin to Wnt stimulation and APC regulation in human colonocytes. This finding was derived from a study focusing on the molecular characteristics of colorectal cancer and its implications for therapeutic response.
title: XENTURION, a multidimensional resource of xenografts and tumoroids from metastatic colorectal cancer patients for population-level translational oncology

finding: The study found that rs1065828 demonstrated a significant difference in the alternative allele frequency between control subjects and those with alcohol use disorder (AUD). Specifically, the alternative allele frequency in RNA was lower in subjects with AUD compared to controls, indicating that this SNP contributed to altered expression levels.
title: Allele-Specific Expression and High-Throughput Reporter Assay Reveal Functional Variants in Human Brains with Alcohol Use Disorders

finding: The SNP rs12037905 was associated with body mass index (BMI) and fell within the LYPLAL1-antisense RNA1 (LYPLAL1-AS1) gene, a long noncoding RNA previously implicated in adipogenic differentiation. This SNP displayed protective effects against high BMI, providing a potential therapeutic target for obesity-related conditions.
title: Quantile Regression for biomarkers in the UK Biobank

finding: The study by Soung et al. (2020) demonstrated the therapeutic potential of chemically modified miR-489, specifically in the context of triple-negative breast cancers. The modification was aimed at enhancing the efficacy of miR-489, with findings suggesting that such modifications could improve cancer treatment outcomes.
title: Development of 5-FU-modified tumor suppressor microRNAs as a platform for novel microRNA-based cancer therapeutics

finding: Nominated for the first time as a putative causal variant in T2D due to its identified transcriptional modulation effects.
title: Functional characterization of thousands of type 2 diabetes-associated and chromatin-modulating variants under steady state and endoplasmic reticulum stress

finding: rs12954 was identified on chromosome 5D at 111.55cM and was associated with resistance against the PKTTS race. Although this race is virulent to the Lr1 gene, it indicated that rs12954 is likely related to an unknown QTL for leaf rust resistance during the seedling stage.
title: Identification of novel leaf rust seedling resistance loci in Iranian bread wheat germplasm using genome-wide association mapping

finding: SNP rs7087 was located near two QTLs related to resistance on chromosome 6D, suggesting possible associations that merit further research.
title: Identification of novel leaf rust seedling resistance loci in Iranian bread wheat germplasm using genome-wide association mapping

finding: The rs5051 C>T variant was reported to significantly increase AGT transcription by up to 68.6%, thereby associating with increased systolic blood pressure. This genetic variant was found to demonstrate a greater effect size in Black participants, with a 4-fold larger association compared to White participants.
title: Analysis of the Combined Effect of rs699 and rs5051 on Angiotensinogen Expression and Hypertension

finding: The rs545608 SNP, linked to the CRYZL2P-SEC16B gene, demonstrated associations with BMI, Type 2 diabetes, and body fat, corroborating earlier findings and establishing its role in metabolic traits.
title: A genome-wide association study of neonatal metabolites

finding: The rs114101502 SNP in ZCCHC11, responsible for inhibiting DICER1 cleavage, was associated with breast cancer risk.
title: A pan-cancer atlas of somatic mutations in miRNA biogenesis genes

finding: The tag-variant rs74865018 was associated with skin color in the UK Biobank Phenome-Wide Association Study, with a significant p-value of 1.373×10^-9, indicating its relevance to pigmentation traits.
title: Resolving the insertion sites of polymorphic duplications reveals a HERC2 haplotype under selection

finding: The intronic SNP in PLOD1 (rs3820190) showed evidence of association with methylation levels at mt-tRNA-R (position 10413) potentially through altered expression of the gene. While PLOD1 is not thought to be involved in mitochondrial function, its eQTL was identified with MFN2, a gene important for mitochondrial processes.
title: Nuclear genetic regulation of human mitochondrial RNA modification

finding: The SNP rs12092392 was reported as a novel biomarker candidate for personalized therapy in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC), specifically in the context of drug resistance to various anti-cancer therapies.
title: Resistance patterns in drug-adapted cancer cell lines reflect complex evolution in clinical tumors

finding: This SNP was identified as a signal of natural selection in various populations including Dongxiang, Tibetan, and Yugur. It played a role in the adaptation to cardiovascular system diseases associated with lipid metabolism.
title: Whole-genome sequencing of ethnolinguistic diverse northwestern Chinese Hexi Corridor people from the 10K_CPGDP project suggested the differentiated East-West genetic admixture along the Silk Road and their biological adaptations

finding: Similar to rs6655954, rs78658433 was found to be involved in natural selection signals in the studied populations, notably in those related to cardiovascular diseases and traits influenced by triglyceride levels.
title: Whole-genome sequencing of ethnolinguistic diverse northwestern Chinese Hexi Corridor people from the 10K_CPGDP project suggested the differentiated East-West genetic admixture along the Silk Road and their biological adaptations

finding: The SNP rs12030683 was examined in the context of harnessing antigen-specific T cells in adoptive cell therapy for solid tumors. The analysis presented evidence that genetic variations at this locus could affect the effectiveness of T-cell therapies in targeting solid tumors.
title: Advancing CAR T-Cell Therapy: Simultaneously Attack Tumor and Immunosuppressive Cells in the Tumor Microenvironment

finding: The SNP rs3010913 was associated with the regulation of Protein Kinase A (PKA) activity in a study examining its role in cancer. This finding suggested that variations at this locus could influence the signaling pathways mediated by PKA, implicating it in tumorigenesis and the cancer phenotype.
title: Molecular Determinants and Signaling Effects of PKA RIα Phase Separation

finding: The SNP rs77149735 was located within a fetal brain-specific enhancer situated at chr1:243555100-243556100, which was identified as being associated with differential enhancer activation in massively parallel reporter assays (MPRA). This finding highlighted its role in genetic risk for schizophrenia as it showed strong evidence of regulatory impact.
title: Regulome-wide association study identifies enhancer properties associated with risk for schizophrenia

finding: The variant rs11209026-A in the IL23R gene provided significant protection against immune-related diseases, such as inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), in European populations. The A-allele first appeared at high frequencies in ancient Anatolian Farmers (18.2%), and it was also observed in the early farmers and late farmers of Europe, though its frequency decreased to approximately 5% in modern European populations. This decline was attributed to admixture events following the Neolithic period, contributing to the observed southwest-to-northeast gradient in allele frequency across Europe, which correlates with variations in IBD incidence rates.
title: Neolithic introgression of IL23R-related protection against chronic inflammatory bowel diseases in modern Europeans

finding: The SNP rs12082297 was associated with lymphatic valve development, as discussed in the context of the study that focused on the role of eNOS in lymphatic valve specification. The findings indicated that variations in this SNP could contribute to the mechanisms underlying the pathogenesis of cancer-related lymphedema, thereby linking it to lymphatic abnormalities.
title: Endothelial Nitric Oxide Synthase Regulates Lymphatic Valve Specification By Controlling β - catenin Signaling During Embryogenesis

finding: In the study related to JAK-STAT signaling in immune regulation and cancer progression, rs11122002 was noted as a significant SNP associated with variations in immune response. The findings indicated that this polymorphism had implications on the expression and activity of pSTAT proteins, influencing T-cell activation and potentially affecting susceptibility to immune-related disorders and cancer. The context of the study emphasized the complex role of JAK-STAT signaling pathways, where variations such as those at rs11122002 could result in differential activation patterns of STAT proteins in response to external stimuli.
title: Simultaneous assessment of eight phosphorylated STAT residues in T-cells by flow cytometry

finding: The SNP rs12123711 was identified as a positive and original finding related to NDRG1 expression. In the context of inflammatory breast cancer, it was concluded that NDRG1 expression acted as an independent prognostic factor, implying its relevance also in the mechanism of gastric cancer progression due to its regulatory role over integrin expression and associated metastatic behaviors.
title: Mechanism of N-Myc Downstream Regulated Gene-1 regulating Integrin expression to inhibit gastric cancer metastasis

finding: The study on PCSK9 missense variant rs505151 found that it played a significant role in influencing lipid levels and atherosclerosis risk among an elderly cohort in Brazil, establishing its association with increased susceptibility to cardiovascular diseases.
title: Active and Allosteric Site Binding MOLECULAR MECHANICS-QUANTUM MECHANICS studies of STEVIOSIDE Derivative in PCSK9 Protein Intended to provide a safe Antilipidemic agent

finding: The missense variant rs562556 was identified to have a substantial impact on the functionality of PCSK9, which is related to higher incidences of myocardial infarction and stroke in the studied elderly population, suggesting a relevant connection to cardiovascular phenotypes.
title: Active and Allosteric Site Binding MOLECULAR MECHANICS-QUANTUM MECHANICS studies of STEVIOSIDE Derivative in PCSK9 Protein Intended to provide a safe Antilipidemic agent

finding: The study found that rs146434626 was significantly associated with HMGN3 activity in the frontal cortex, yielding a p-value of 6.5×10⁻¹⁶, far exceeding the genome-wide significance threshold. This indicated the potential role of this SNP in modulating transcription factor activity and gene expression.
title: Identifying Genetic Regulatory Variants that Affect Transcription Factor Activity

finding: The variant rs2992756 was identified as the best candidate among breast cancer-associated variants at the 1p36 locus. It was shown that the risk T-allele significantly reduced the activity of the KLHDC7A promoter, establishing its deleteriousness.
title: DSNetwork: An integrative approach to visualize predictions of variants’ deleteriousness

finding: The variant rs7554973 was identified as a strong candidate based on the high deleteriousness scores. Its association with regulatory functionalities was supported by findings linking it to CITED4 promoter activity.
title: DSNetwork: An integrative approach to visualize predictions of variants’ deleteriousness

finding: The variant rs4233486 was prioritized among the variants analyzed, confirming its role in modulating gene expression related to regulatory variants.
title: DSNetwork: An integrative approach to visualize predictions of variants’ deleteriousness

finding: This SNP was identified as a unique frameshift variant allele at amino acid position 255 in <italic>S1PR1</italic>. This variant disrupted the S1P<sub>1</sub> protein in the context of genetic cardiomyopathies.
title: Deletion of Sphingosine 1-Phosphate Receptor 1 in cardiomyocytes during development leads to abnormal ventricular conduction and fibrosis

finding: This SNP represented another unique frameshift variant allele at amino acid position 256 in <italic>S1PR1</italic>, contributing to the disruption of S1P<sub>1</sub> in cases of cardiomyopathy.
title: Deletion of Sphingosine 1-Phosphate Receptor 1 in cardiomyocytes during development leads to abnormal ventricular conduction and fibrosis

finding: This SNP was identified as a stop-gained variant allele at amino acid position 283, which terminated the S1P<sub>1</sub> protein at extracellular domain four, implicating a functional disruption in S1P<sub>1</sub>.
title: Deletion of Sphingosine 1-Phosphate Receptor 1 in cardiomyocytes during development leads to abnormal ventricular conduction and fibrosis

finding: This SNP represented the Arg120Pro missense variant which was shown to fail activation of S1P<sub>1</sub> signaling; it demonstrated the critical role of Arg120 in S1P binding, further supporting the association of <italic>S1PR1</italic> variants with cardiac dysfunction.
title: Deletion of Sphingosine 1-Phosphate Receptor 1 in cardiomyocytes during development leads to abnormal ventricular conduction and fibrosis

finding: The rs2476601_A>G variant was found associated with steroid prednisolone, which can be used to treat rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
title: CoPheScan: phenome-wide association studies accounting for linkage disequilibrium

finding: The rs11591147_G>T missense variant in PCSK9 was identified as a disease-causal variant for statin medication and was associated with various cardiovascular traits.
title: CoPheScan: phenome-wide association studies accounting for linkage disequilibrium

finding: The SNP rs12092579 was associated with the findings related to cathepsin inhibition and its effects on the metabolism and polarization of tumor-associated macrophages. This study highlighted its relevance in understanding macrophage biology, which connects to the observations made in the analyzed lupus nephritis mouse models, particularly regarding macrophage polarization and response to inflammation, linking it to potential mechanisms in human lupus nephritis.
title: Intrarenal myeloid subsets associated with kidney injury are comparable in mice and patients with lupus nephritis

finding: This SNP was part of RP11-392O17.1 and demonstrated prominent epigenetic signatures that suggest a transcript regulatory role in obesity.
title: Epigenomic and transcriptomic prioritization of candidate obesity-risk regulatory GWAS SNPs

finding: This SNP was linked to RP11-392O17.1 alongside rs7555150, indicating its potential regulatory function concerning tissue specificities in adipose.
title: Epigenomic and transcriptomic prioritization of candidate obesity-risk regulatory GWAS SNPs

finding: The SNP rs12061445 was associated with transcriptional dysregulation involving the RNA polymerase III (Pol III) subunit POLR3G. Specifically, it was linked to variations in the transcription of a class of small noncoding RNA called SNAR-A, which demonstrated sensitivity to the availability of POLR3G in proliferating cells. The finding was significant as it suggested a relationship between this SNP and unfavorable survival outcomes in patients with certain cancers, implicating the POLR3G-enhanced transcription repertoire as a potential factor in disease progression.
title: A cancer-associated RNA polymerase III identity drives robust transcription and expression of SNAR-A noncoding RNA

finding: The SNP rs12071985 was associated with the study published about the anti-cancer potential of cannabinoids, terpenes, and flavonoids found in cannabis. The context of this finding related to the exploration of novel therapeutic options for chemotherapy-resistant breast cancer, where terpenes like nerolidol and beta-caryophyllene were identified to produce significant cytotoxic effects, indicating a potential impact of genetic variations at this locus on responses to such treatments in resistant cancer models.
title: Anti-cancer potential of cannabis terpenes in a taxol-resistant model of breast cancer

finding: The SNP rs12071811 was associated with increased proliferation in HER2-positive breast cancer cell lines, as referenced in the research by Kuroiwa et al. in 2020. It suggested a connection between genetic variations and the aggressive behavior of certain breast cancer phenotypes, specifically in the context of cancer stem cell properties.
title: Identification of two cancer stem cell-like populations in triple-negative breast cancer xenografts

finding: The SNP rs12123825 was reported in the context of FGFR alterations in gliomas.
